reviews.review: Well worth the price of admission . At 15 sols this is good value. It is interesting how the Spanish just built on top of the Incan buildings, and this is displayed well here where you can see the Incan foundations and lower walls below the Spanish building.

Weather permits ?. Unfortunately haven opened during our visit. Strong showers did not permit us to enjoy as much as we should. Check the weather forecast before you book for this tour and if possible do it earlier than October. Anyway from the safety of our van it looks impressive.

Well worth the price of admission . At 15 sols this is a bargain, the interior includes elements of the older Incan temple complex which the Spanish built around. It is an easy self guided tour which takes about an hour at an easy pace

Mix of Inca and spanish architecture in one place. The sacred temples of the Incas that were then used to build a huge catholic church!! But then and earthquake ruined the spanish construction letting out some inka temples again. This place is magical and with a lot of interesting things to learn
Old and Interesting. This place is well worth a visit as you learn a lot about the cusco people and what happened way back when the conquistadors came to town!
WANTON DISREGARD. Very disturbing to see what the catholic church and spanish conquerors did to the local culture and religion.

mash-up of cultures. So interesting to see the mash up of cultures here. The Spanish building a religious site over an existing Inka site, and yet not destroying all of their structures. It's all been beautifully preserved. Odd that you can't take pictures of paintings that are hung outside in the courtyard though.

Very important site, worth seeing. Paid 15 soles in. Just walked around on my own and read all the information, plenty in English, and it was very interesting. If you're interested in the history of the area and important cultural sites of the Inka, check it out. Also amazing colonial art to be seen.

Mixed place and feelings. Lonely Planet kind of tells you to go here and I don't say you shouldn't but... It's a beautiful building in Spanish style and lots of the expositions are on Catholic art. So if you want to visit because you want to see Quecha remains, know that that's just a small part of what's to be seen. It's is impressive though, the tightly fitted building blocks and ancient remains. Furthermore there was a photo expo worth a visit in the second floor.

Combination of ancient incan architecture and monastery.. The monastery is built on the foundations of Qurikancha, an Incan sun temple. Visiting this place is sad because the spanish essentially built over the sun temple in an attempt to eradicate an ancient religion and belief system. Overall, its a beautiful combination of ancient and 'modern' architecture.

Outside view. The view is better from the outside. The inside isn't worth the effort and gets very crowded with tour groups. Plus it's an extortionate 15 soles entry. If you are in Cusco you won't miss this as it's on Avenida del Sol.

Fascinating place. This is a fascinating site, combining as it does a Dominican monastery and an Incan temple. The Incan temple makes it stand out from the numerous other churches in Cusco and the way the Dominicans used the temple is really interesting. The garden is also lovely with lots of spring flowers out in October. From the choir loft you can look down into the church, where on my visit a choir was singing (in Quechua, I think). Well worth a visit.

Worth the visit. Finally got around to visiting the Convento de Santo Domingo on my third visit to Cusco. And, I found it worth the time. Arrived around 1 pm on a Saturday and had a good hour before the hoards arrived. The Convent was built on the site of the Inka Templo del Sol, a sacred site. I found it interesting to see the mix of Spanish Colonial architecture and the remains of the Inka site blended together. Much of the Cathedral was damaged in the 1950 earthquake, revealing Inka walls that are now being restored to some degree.I enjoyed wandering in the gardens after exploring indoors, and examining some of the Inka structure up close.In my opinion, an English-speaking guide wasn't necessary. There is English signage.

If you like ancient ruins, this is an insult.. This place was built on top of ancient Inca ruins. You can get inside and see reconstructions of how the Incas built door frames (interesting) but other than that it's just a sad reminder of how destructive some invaders were. Oh, and they charge you extra... Do yourself a favour and visit the Inca ruins still standing. Wanna see a convent, go to your city/province and visit one.

Definitely Worth Seeing. There are a lot of Catholic sites in Cusco. A lot. I live in Europe and get "cathedraled out" very quickly, so I decided to narrow my religious tourist activities down to this place and one other. It was super interesting to see how the Inca walls had been used as a part of the Catholic complex and to imagine how the place must've looked when the Inca sections were covered in silver and gold. The upstairs section had an exhibition of contemporary local art that I really enjoyed, and the gardens were a really nice place to sit, relax and read. There will be tour guides outside telling you that there is no signage in English and offering tours for around 40-80 soles. Based on reviews here, I took up one of these offers after a small group formed and I could reduce the price to 20 soles for myself. Our particular guide was very knowledgeable but rushed us through the complex and probably told us less than we could've learned by reading a guidebook before going in. Also, there was a lot of signage in English, so I'm not sure a guide is completely necessary. Just so you know.

Building on an Incan Foundation . The Convento de Santo Domingo is well worth your time and a visit to see another example of Incan engineering and practicality. I find it historically intriguing to think of one religion building their place of worship on the literal stone foundation built by another culture and religion for worship.

Lovely architecture, not enough Inca exhibits. Visited during our stay in Cusco. Great building with lovely courtyard and gardens but expected more Inca exhibits than we got. Very largely Catholic Church bias (as you would expect in a convent!) but given its location and history I expected more information on Inca history and tradition than we saw. Well worth a visit though.

A must for Cusco. The convent is built on spectacular Inca stonework - exemplified inside and outside. The courtyard is very attractive and the paintings reflect the struggles between Catholicism and Traditional cultures.

Well worth a visit. Good place to visit for about an hour or so. There is not a huge amount to see, but the convent is a lovely building, there are some outside areas you can visit, you get to walk around at the church, and there are some Inca ruins there too

Very interesting history and arhitecture. We stopped here on our Cusco city tour. It's a beautiful cathedral, with amazing artwork. The exterior is also interesting and overlooks the grassy area that was formerly a river running through town. It's best with a guide to learn the history and feature of the building.

Great History in Downtown Cucso. This is a working convent with 18 Friar's living here. Tourists are able to access half the convent. Here you will see original paintings, exquisite ceilings and the fallout from the last earthquake which destroyed much of the second level. Inca architecture throughout so more likely an Inca temple back in the 1400's. You will find rooms dedicated to the Inca Gods such as rain, sun, and moon.

The amazing Incan Sun Temple lies here. Right next to this convent lies the ancient sun temple of the Incas. This Sun temple and the fresco of the stars are definitely worth a visit. Make sure you first hire a guide outside.

Excellent example of spanish Architecture built into existing inca Architecture. While can be crowded, well worth visit. Take the time to look at the stone work of the Inca's verse the Spanish. Here you can see how the Incas designed their interlocking stone work. When you are on the out side garden, you can see a cross section of the Inca double walled retaining wall. As you look at the exposed Inca stone work. Note the obvious similarity of the Inca carved grooves into the stones to the Roman/Greek carved groves for the use of melted lead.
Beautiful. What a setting plus interesting small Inca temples are contained inside. There are great painting plus some explanations of the history of the Incas.

Interesting church on the foundation of an Inca temple. This church is one of the 'must-see' churches in Cuzco. It provides a good insight in the construction of the Inca temple, with different astronomical features. The church and museum have also a great collection of religious art.

Hire a Guide at the front door around noon time. You will need a guide to understand the very rich history of the sacred grounds. We hired a guide at the front door for 40 Sol. She explained in detail the Convento's history. I was amazed how much of the Inca's stones still existed even after the Spanish Conquest. We visited around 12:00 p.m. There were no crowds. Around 1:30 p.m., the Convento had a rush of at least four very large group tours so it is a good idea to arrive around lunch time. I loved the art. Our guide showed us the signficance of the Arch Angels wings which were similar in shape to a Condor's wings. Impressive!!!
Great Experience. Nice place to see. Your need a guide, great explanations. Very clean and well preserved. Excellent experience
New, new and old. Interesting to see the Inca palace ruins inside a Dominican Church that subsequently fell to the 1950 earthquake. A guide is very useful.

Interesting Museum!. I breezed through this museum on a hot afternoon in Cusco, and was very pleasantly surprised by the quality of the exhibits and the beautiful ruins maintained inside under the convent. Cusco is a remarkable city, and this museum is a nice way to spend a few minutes on a hot afternoon! Walking distance from the JW Marriott and the plaza de armas!

Real view of Incan building methods o in a church. We were suggested that this would be worth a look by a local tour company. 15 soles entry and we opted for 50 soles for a guide which was worth it.Just having him explain and show the building techniques and the methods were fascinating. Much better than the Machu Pichu museum in town.Recommended.

interesting place, mixed with Inca Ruins. The convent is OK< not one of the best, actually restored after a big earthquake. Toward the back are some very interesting Inca Ruins. Nice to visit if it is raining.

Impressive Layout. I'm not that into churches/monastery, but this one is pretty good. What's really the most impressive things is the layouts. Often churches/monasteries just open the doors and take your money. This one had gone to great effort to describe the story of the the Incan ruins and religious history, which the monastery was built over as well as the background on the Dominicans role in Peru. The paintings are really amazing (and I"m not an art guy), but they are made better by some good descriptions of what you're looking at. It costs 15 sole per person to enter which is a bargain.

A sun's temple under a spanish church. The place is great, if you've been to Machu Picchu and compare the size of the two sun temples you can get an idea of the size of Cusco when it was the Inca empire capital.

One of the best churches/museums in Cusco. Definitely worth it, the area outside the cloister is great, you can have an idea of where the Inca temple stood. The museum down the road is small but the one inside the church is impressive.

interesting and worthwhile. Whilst this is a definite must, I was a little disappointed with what I was able to see. I got there right on opening time, as did a couple of tour groups. Some of the rooms were not open, in fact when I poked my head into one filled with art work, a cleaner told me to come back in 5 minutes, 15 minutes later it was still closed. I managed to walk into one room with amazing gold embroidered robes, only to find someone loudly closing doors and waiting for me to exit, so he could lock up. I felt like I was trespassing on private property.

Clash of Inca and Spanish cultures. Large temple where the clash of Inca and Spanish influences are apparent. The place itself is large and peaceful with amazing views of Cusco. It doesn't open until 1400 so don't go too early.

Interesting mixture of cultures. This church/monastery with original Inca walls was one of my favourite visits in Cuzco. On the inside, there are still some Inca temples, showing the clear differences between the Spanish building style and the Inca style. Not a very big museum, but very much worth it to go in!

Lovely Church. We had visited Koricancha, and we didn't visit this place. Towards the end of our holidays we managed to go and it was amazing! it has a very different feel to other churches! it is a must!

Must visit!!!. This was for me the most interesting place to visit in Perou even more than Machu Pichu that we Loved but found very touristical...This temple explains to you everything about the inca history and specially when Pissaro and the spanish took over the region with gunfires that scared the incas who should have won the battle...It is a great visit to do with children I,I just suggest that you take a guide...the peruvians speak a perfect english or french !!!

Don't miss the church. It was very interesting to see the mix of Inka and Spanish architecture. The church besides it holds very interesting paintings, including angels as Peruvian kids and others with a hint of satire, which makes it the most interesting if all. Free entrance!

This is the QORICANCHA: the temple at the heart of the Incan Empire!. This site was the highlight of our visit to Cusco! The Inca's Qoricancha temple, preserved, and displayed, inside this colonial monastery. You can see several well-preserved very important Incan ritual buildings, including the probable "House of the Moon", the possible "House of Rainbows" and "House of Lightening", and well preserved portions of the "House of the Sun" and the heart of the Qoricancha, itself, where the P'unchau, or image of the Sun, was mounted, all of which were exposed by the earthquake in 1950, which cause the colonial structures to crumble around these robust Incan walls. Besides these breathtaking examples of the finest Incan masonry, they have a fascinating exhibit explaining the Incan understanding of their cosmos. Plus, you get to tour exhibits of colonial religious art, visit the choir-loft to the church, attractive gardens, and view temporary exhibits of modern Peruvian art. It's best to visit in the morning before the tour groups arrive, and these were the nicest public bathrooms we found in Peru!

Favorite sightseeing spot in Cuzco . This is a very interesting tourist site, both for Incan history and Catholic history. If you are interested in Catholicism, spend time reading all the descriptions in the room containing art from the Cusco school of art.

Amazing building but so busy.... We went here as part of a tour. The building and history are great but it was so busy you were literally shoulder to shoulder and couldn't get a feel for the place or really concentrate on reading or take Amy photos. They need to do a ticket system like Barcelona cathedral and you pay for your ticket and have a time slot which you visit, thus they can have a maximum amount of people at any one time.

Incredible history site . This was a great stop on our trip, we learned so much about the history of the area and the convent set atop the Incan ruins is eye opening. It was very crowded when we were there, there are a lot of huge tour groups that make the stop.
Inka fusion. Fascinating to see how the Conquistadors built a Dominican Monestry over an Inka palace. It is clear to see who were the better builders, it was not the invaders!

Amazing Site. At a recent visit to Cusco, i visited the Convento. After making my way through the many vendors, I paid my ticket price and enjoyed this amazing historical site with a great view on the city. It is not allowed to take photos of the Spanish art pieces or sanctuary. However, photos can be taken of the Inca ceremonial grounds. It is a site easy to navigate for visitors with walking problems.

Beautiful Cathedral. The cathedral is definitely worth the visit: the Sagrada Familia church is very interesting, the Cathedral has a beautiful silver altar and a painting of the "Last Supper" with a peculiar "menu". Also the altar of "Señor de los Temblores" gives you a very good notion of the importance of this Christ in the local culture. The "Iglesia del Triunfo" is also very interesting, especially once you learn the story its Cross.

Poorly maintained exhibition in musuem. No proper maintenance on collection; although we visited during peak season we were nearly unable to walk due to multiple school classes visiting a room at the same time.

Quechua/Catholic Syncronicity. Our guide was excellent and told us story after story about the history of this place and how the Quechua people managed to insert their native religion into the Catholic icons. Notice in the choir room how the female saints are painted above the male saints. Also notice the copies of paintings from Europe and how they differ from the originals. Instead of two angels in one painting there are five - representing the minimum of five children as a blessing to the family. Many, many examples. If you can find a guide, I would highly recommend hiring one so as not to see this as just another church.

Not covered by the Boleto Turistico. We were approaching the entrance and some random lady ran up and started yelling at us that we have to pay 15 soles to go inside. We showed her our boleto turisticos and she said it doesn't cover the Koricancha, even though it says it does. Than she kept standing over us for no reason. I thought she didn't know what she was talking about, so I went inside to ask the guard and he told us the Boleto Turistico only covers a tiny museum, and not the Temple of the Sun, which is the main attraction of the site. I was about to pay, when I was a sign that you are not even allowed to take pictures of the temple. That was enough for me to turn around. What a rip off! The church itself is beautiful, but IDK why they include the site on the Boleto if it does not even get you access to the temple. Save yourself 15 soles and just enjoy it from the outside.

Interesting Spanish-Incan history. We visited as a couple in July, and would highly recommend a tour (about 30 soles for 2 people). The history between how the Spanish built on top of the famous Incan 'lego-piece' foundations is fascinating, especially how during earthquakes the colonial structures would fall but the Incan structures would stay. It's a beautiful church as well, and is an important temple in Incan history.

Worth visiting but a bit strange. We very much wanted to visit this site but it's a bit strange seeing the remains of the Inca temple surrounded by the triumphant Catholic religious buildings--which were destroyed twice by earthquakes (1659 and 1950) while the better engineered and constructed Inca walls remained. It's worth visiting for the sake of surviving and preserved Inca walls and rooms. Don't miss the impressive view from below. A guide really helps, as many important features of the site are unmarked.

Beautiful architecture and art with an interesting back story. We stopped in as we were staying across the street and had read good things about this place.Entry was 15 sols per person and we opted to go without a guide. The convent is one built around an old Incan temple and it was quite beautiful. The melding of the architecture was lovely and it's one of the few places we've ever seen where two types are so well maintained The courtyard outside has a number of large paintings and was nice to walk around in. Overall however we found the art pieces the most impressive. There were a number of rooms dedicated to them with plenty of good explanations of the pictures. Many were huge and dated back 300-400 years. The funniest thing we learned was that some of the painters put a portrait on their creations after finishing them. It was like a terrible game of Where's Waldo!Make sure to go upstairs and see the balcony of the church as well. The main area up there is amazing and the ancillary rooms have some additional impressive paintings and furniture.An amazing church/museum to walk through and do some learnin' in!

Take the guided tour! . You can walk around the rest of Cuzco and grab a good idea of the city and what it might looked like 500 years ago, before the Spanish destroyed everything that the Inca Empire built. But the Convento de Santo Domingo, built on top of Qoricancha, deserves a guided tour. So you can understand the immensity of the Inca and how far did the Spanish go to break their mind. If you get a good guide, he will explain you how this old construction is related with the rest of the ruins around the city and how Qoricancha was the center of power in old Cuzco. It's an essential part of your visit to the city.

Gorgeous! Great for Photography!. I never went inside the Convento de Santo Domingo, but walked around the grounds a few times. The architecture of this church is gorgeous as well as the scenery. I recommend walking around here both during the day and night. If you are into photography, this is a very photogenic area. It seems like a huge place, and is easy to get to from the main square.
History. Beautiful location go with a tour guide you will spend about 2hrs maybe less. Lot of Inca history .Good time of the year to see the Milky Way the 2months is July August.

Superb yet tragic history. A great place to visit to see how an Incan temple was converted into a monastery. Awesome visuals and the many plaques let you know what went on on this location. Hard to imagine it as it used to be noted that it has been assimilated into a different culture. Insightful.

Spanish Convent Built with Inca Walls . Great site to visit with great views of the city. Your visit will not take too long (I had a teen who wasn't thrilled about being here). Convent was built on top of an Inca temple. (Beware there is a tiny museum in the park next to the convent, which we thought was the entrance to the convent. The guard wanted us to pay him In cash, not the cashier.)
History and contemplation. A important place to the Ink Culture. There is possible to see the mix of cultures between spanih and inka/peruvian culture. Go there!
Amazing!. Our hotel was located just in front of it, so we felt in love since the very beginning of our stay in Cuzco, its church in incredible!!!!

Amazing history. If you visit Machu Picchu and you visit this place, it just makes you realize how amazingly intelligent this civilization was. They truly did do a lot and knew a lot of things. It is a beautiful building with a wonderful history. Only $5 for a great tour.
Very interesting . We hired a tour guide outside the Coricancha and that made the visit very interesting. I highly recommend anyone who plans to visit to do that.
Why?. All you can think,is why did the Spanish destroy the original inca building for just another convent and church. You can not wonder about what was here prior to the Spanish !

Interesting Inca Insight. If you're in Cusco and have some time to fill - this is worth a quick visit. The Spanish influence has overshadowed the Inca bits - but some idea of the seamless stone block construction that the Inca masons mastered, can be obtained.There is a large one room art gallery on the ground floor - with paintings depicting stories from the bible and other paintings that follow the walls bordering the courtyard.

Lots of History!. We really enjoyed visiting this museum and convent. It was interesting to see a convent built on an inca temple. There was a lot of history included in the museum. I would recommend hiring a guide or someone to go through the museum with you as the inca ruins are not marked and there are no signs on or near them explaining about them. We saw guides spend a lot of time with people here. There were several outside the museum when we arrived and we had wished we had hired one! Overall the museum was great and we learned a lot about what happened to the Incas when the Spanish invaded.

Quite amazing. Visited here and hired a guide for 30 soles. Glad we did. Got to understand a bit more about the Incas and the impact of the spanish. It is very pretty inside with amazing views. Definitely worth visiting
Nice area to visit.. Can take a tour, or do it on your own. can spend 30-120 min. touring,All depends on what you want out of visit - Nothing terribly unique, however.

Lots of history in one place. The Convento is founded on the former sun tempel of Inca Cusco and is more than worth a visit. The impressive remains of the tempel are still well visible. The displays are beautiful and very informative. What makes this place even better is the adjacent garden: more Inca walls, beautiful flowers and a great place to rest and spot humming birds!
Erected on top of Incan temple site. An incredible church erected on top of one of the holiest Incan religious sites in Cusco. Be sure to tour the ruins of the Inca site as well as the church.

Interesting to find out how the INCAs joined stones together. We went to visit this as part of a city tour, so did not have long to spend here. Our guide was very knowledgeable and showed us how the INCAs joined the stones together for their building. It was strange to find the INCA temple in the Roman catholic church. It would have been nice to have had longer to spend here, but we had a short amount of time before the sun went down and lots of places to visit.

Worth it!. This was a really neat and unique site to visit right in the heart of Cusco and no far at all from the main plaza. We had been outside taking pictures at night the night before the tour and it was beautiful all light up at night with Christmas lights. A nice stop on the city tour.
Qorikancha!. You must go! No words can describe how awesome it is to find an ancient temple (okay, 20% of it at least) within a seemingly traditional Spanish convent.
No pics allowed. It was very crowded the day of the visit. No pictures are allowed in parts of the convent. Pictures allowed in the center of facility.
Mass. We walked to Mass there. it was right around the corner from Casa Andina so it was really convenient. The church was beautiful and we lived the Mass.

Inca Architecture. This church was built on top of what was a very impressive Inca temple, and some of the walls of that temple can be seen at this site. This is a good place to see the ingenuity and precision of the Inca builders up close.

Archeological site and convent in the city centre. Few still remains from the most important Inca place in Cuzco. Spanish used Inca stones to built their church and convent.
Some of the Inca structures were rebuilt after last century earthquake.
Nice collection of religious paintings from XVII century.
It is private, and ticket is not included in either archeological ticket nor religious ticket.
Fascinating mix of Inca and Colonial history and architecture. A beautiful church built over Inca temples. Fascinating history, be sure to use a guide so you can understand what you are seeing.

One of the top 3 places to visit in Cusco!. Cusco is full of historical places and the Convento de Santo Domingo cannot be missed! You will discover a lot about Peru's History and Architecture and specially about the Spanish conquests and the Inca Empire. Outside is also gorgeous!
Nice to walk by or briefly enter. Very pretty on the outside, but with so many other things in Cusco, I wouldn't spend a ton of time here unless you were trying to see absolutely everything.

Beautiful inside courtyard, a surprise based on the outside. There is a lovely courtyard in here, as well as great Inca walls and history. Even the walk to the washroom is lined with beautiful fuchsia flowers.

Imposing in Cusco. This attraction was located across the boulevard from our hotel. The visit to the actual location showed more than I thought. Great construction on the shoulders of original Incan walls. Wonderful views. A great visit.
a blend of new/old. There's not too much of the old temple left and the convent is nice but not spectacular. It does have a good museum however.
Worth a visit. A really serene place in the middle of the hussle and bussle of the city. Great to see the inka buildings and learn how they stay together in earthquakes.

Fee not included in tourist ticket. You have to pay 15 soles for the entrance fee. It's not included in the full tourists ticket for the sacred valley. There's museum inside the church such as paintings and part of the Inca stone wall. Photos not allowed on certain areas. This's used to be the very important temple of the Incas filled with gold and silver. But when the Spaniards came, they tore down the temple and built the church on top of it.

So interesting and fascinating!. It's worth to take a bit of your time to visit the Convento de Santo Domingo, first of all is the most important temple from the Inka empire, secondly is fascinating to see the Inka architecture and to understand how it was working. The Convento itself does not offer a guide in the price of the tickets, but outside there are many women that offer you this service. I suggest to get one as you will not find many comments around the Convento so you will not really understand what was happening there. Get a guide and you will see deep inside the Inka architecture!

Imposing complex thats worth a visit. Qorikancha is an impressive site in Cusco. It has a fascinating history as well. We did have the advantage of a guide to explain it all to us. It is interesting to see how the building was changed over time. Be sure to visit the restrooms, as you get a great view of the gardens on the way!

Once an Inca temple, now a Dominican church. The Dominican church near the historic city center was once the site of an Inca temple. Parts of the temple still stand within the church complex. Be sure to notice the earthquake-resistance architectural style of the original structure. Also don't miss the fabulous paintings that line the inner courtyard!

Inca Culture vs Spanish Colonialism. See how the Spanish profoundly changed an entire culture and people in this example of a conqueror replacing another peoples architecture with their own to impose their beliefs on them.

Mixture of two cultures. This is a marvelous place. You can see the pre-columbian inka culture as well as colonial culture. You can go inside too. There are many local people waiting for your picture opportunity with llamas - do not miss it too.

Stunning paintings. Now I understand the cusco school of paintings. Fascinating how the indigenous artists added their incan views to classical depictions of catholicism. Jesus on the cRoss depicted with facial features and hair color of indigenous south Americans is one on many examples.

Pretty and interesting . Pretty cathedral that houses Incan ruins. Good to visit while in Cusco. The Catholic Church preserves the Incan site. It is an interesting mix of Catholic paintings and Incan ruins.
It's ok. I didn't like this as much as the Cathedral...no pictures allowed on the inside, it's lovely but not super engaging.

Beautiful from the outside. We walked over to Qurikancha after lunch on our last day in Cusco and the line was wrapped around the block with all the tour groups trying to get in. So we just walked around the block and looked at the grounds from the outside. I was still able to see how the Spanish built directly on top of the Inca construction and take some beautiful pictures. This is definitely something to see first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds.
Very Enjoyable. Such a tranquil and beautiful place! This is a convent worth a visit. You will enjoy the tranquil surroundings and the history and beauty of the convent itself.
Interesting. We visited as part of our city tour and learned a bit about how the Spanish built over the Inca city. It was an interesting visit.
Great Garden. A convent built during colonial times. The convent has a beautiful garden in the back. Look for the Inca symbols etched in the grass.
A great visit combined with Santa Catalina. If you visit here, make sure you also visit Santa Catalina. They are both wonderful, and our guide was very informative.
Craftsmanship at its best. Words can not describe how beautiful this church was. A must see. Benches outside to sit and look at the grounds and people watch. Truly extraordinary easy to find.
Nice to see. It was ok, not as beautiful as I expected based on the recommendations in my travel guide. We walked around by ourselves.

Beautiful Church Amongst Many In Cusco. This is a site that should be on your list of places to visit while in Cusco, Peru. You can't mistake that the Cusco people are Catholic and the churches and cathedrals are something to behold - it reminded me of my visit to Spain. This church stood out - so many things to see and our tour guide was very knowledgeable.

Awesome place to visit if you're one that appreciates a variety of architecture and stonework. Some old, some new and some newer yet but mostly very old.Peru in general is not a very camera friendly country. Most of the people don't like having their pictures taken (unless you're paying them but that's another story altogether) and they don't like people taking pictures in the cathedrals, convents or monasteries. Other than the photo-phobia Peru is definitely one of the countries that everyone should make significant efforts to visit.If you have the time to do the research one can plan your own tours and adventures, arrange all your transportation and save loads your of hard earned currency.

A large colonial building integrated to remains of the main Inca temple. The temple of Santo Domingo and the adjacent convent present magnificent colonial architecture and are integrated to the remains of the Inca Sun Temple or Qoricancha in a most impressive and unique way.
Historically significant. A very interesting and informative visit. It was fascinating to see and hear about the colonialism of the Quechen natives.
Worth a visit. Very interesting place, amazing collection of paintings. Free guide provided to explain the history. Only 10 sol entry fee.
Convento de Santo Domingo.. Convento Santo Domingo is a beautiful contrast between ruins and a church on top of them. Worth visiting and taking pictures.
Fusion of Inca and Spanish Heritage. Another fine example of how colonial (Spanish) Cusco was built upon the remains and/or ruins of great Inca buildings. Interesting coexistence of both cultures.
Santo Domingo. Decided not to take a guide and found enough English posts at items of interest to feel that I was well informed at the end of my visit.

Inca Ruins Fantastic. The Inca build walls without mortar that withstood earthquakes. Fascinating visit here helps you discover how they did it.Tip: We hired a local guide Yerusa (yerusatours@hotmail.com) who gave us a focused tour. We didn't care to know anything about the church, just the Inca ruins.

But $15.00. Another big ticket item in Peru. Taxis are cheap but everything else is big bucks! You can visit the church for free, what a relief. Beautiful grounds and a lot of interesting stories make it worth. Recommended MeuterMedia

Another odd mixture of pre-Inca, Inca and Catholicism. Like most old buildings in this area, the fundaments are pre-Inca or Inca or both and the Spanish built there own creations on the fundaments after destroying the old structures first. That alone gives the building an interesting touch and often story!
another important place to go. if you like something new, dont hesitate and go visit this place, it has a lot of stories running about it, it will fascinate you like it did with us.
Happy Traveler. Beautiful and interesting convergence of ancient Inca walls and Spanish convent architecture ($15 entrance fee). Visiting church is free.

full of local life. We visited many times. It is surrounded by stores and restaurants. Locals are enjoying their days socializing, and it seems there is one parade after another. It is a great place to get a feel for Cusco.

Best church visit in Cusco.. Having visited a number of churches in this city,this was the one for us that really stood out.Loved the story of both how it was built and the detail behind some of the paintings and altars.Loved the wooden altar in one of the side churches ,ahead of the ornate ones with tons of gold/ silver leaf.We were extremely lucky as well because the organ was being trial led for a festival and that created a lovely atmosphere.One of the paintings with the Guinea pig as the main dish at the Last supper is also worth seeing.Overall a calming and lovely experience.

Both Beautiful and Educational. The inside of the convent is beautiful and provides great views. What I really appreciated here is that you learn so much about both the history of Cusco and how the massive building rocks were shaped to withstand both the years and the frequent earthquakes. You will also see examples of how the Inca built parts of the structure are still intact while much of the Spanish built part has crumbled away.
Beautiful cathedral. This was a nice tour that showed the progression from the Incan ruins to Spanish immigration and Catholisism. Definitely worth taking a tour if you have the time.

Beautiful mixture of cultures. A tour round this convent reveals how the Spanish built on top of the Inca foundations. As I understand it, there was an earthquake some years ago that exposed some of the Inca foundations when the more modern (15th century) Spanish building fell. As a visitor, it makes for a fascinating view of both cultures side by side. I believe the upstairs is still a convent, while downstairs is a museum, open to the public and well worth visiting.

Mix of Inca and Catholic. From the outside this looks like a typical Catholic monastery, inside the Inca remains are the main draw. You can actually only visit part of the building as the rest is still a working monastery. Interesting how the Spanish retained some of the Inca buildings, which makes it a good introduction to Macchu Picchu later.
Inca treasure. At this Convent, we saw well preserved Incan temples despite the Spaniards assimilation. Well worth seeing!

A must see!. The history here is amazing! A Dominican cathedral on top of an Inca ruin. The grounds are beautiful, the ruins are amazing and very interesting (and in tact) and the church (despite the circumstance) is beautiful with local/historical art. Definitely worth visiting and if you can- get a guide to get all of the intriguing details about the Inca architecture, artifacts and history.

Mad House. I was really looking forward to see this Church that shares its site with Incan ruins, however it was a mad house of tour groups, tourists and guides. People were taking photos with the no photo signs behind them and were inconsiderate of others trying to enjoy the site. Felt I wasted my money. There is a lovely garden behind the church, reached by a scary set of stairs.

Nice place, sad history . The place is nice, but the history about it is sad, especially when you know what the Spanisch people have done 100 years ago. Also, all the money they make on this place is for the catholic church in Rom. And that is a lot - 5.5$ per visitor. But for sure it's impressive how the place got constructed hundred of years ago.
Unique Ancient Architecture. An old Inca temple of the Sun once covered by gold converted into Cathedral by Spanish colonists. Inca stone walls & ancient masonry can still be seen.
Incan ruins and Spanish architecture. Pretty neat to go inside and see the remains of the Incan temple that once was here. The Spanish built around and over the Incan site, but a lot is still there.
Wonderful. The convent is a mix of Inca and Catholic religions, it has a lot of history. The grounds are beautiful. This is still an active convent.
So interesting. So much history, architecture, art, foliage, and other things to look at. One of the most interesting structures

Spainish Church Built Over Inca Temple. Qoricancha Sun Temple was the most important temple of the Inca's empire. However, most of the temple was destroyed by the Spanish when they built a church over the ruins. But enough remains to show how good the Incas were in stone construction. Be sure to take a guided tour of the place to best understand this place.

Interesting, but confusing. This place has a lot of really fascinating history, but it is really convoluted. The ancient ruins have been built upon by more modern religions so deciphering what is what and why is a little much. That being said, it is interesting to see the results.
Mix of spanish and peruvian. It is amazing that the foundations of this Spanish convent are the Peruvian foundations of an old citadel. The stone work is amazing.

Great comparison of two cultures. Must see in Cusco, but get a guide to fully understand context! They can be hired at the entrance for about 40 soles for 1 hour tour. Great way to understand how those beautiful and grandiose inca walls were built
Tourist walk around. Lots to see in Cusco you have to look in to all the possibilities and choose what you have time and energy for

Impressive stone, beautiful gardens . Visited this place with a CITY tour, the exhibits justify its entrance fees.
There are several temples with impressive stonework, a beautiful courtyard and garden full of flowers.
The toilet is superbly modern & clean ( compared to stops in city tour)

Nice, a bit touristy at first.... Probably one of the four major place to visit in the Cusco valley leading to Machu Picchu. It has nice views of the valley but not much remains. Although, it is a good site to see how the Spanish built over the incas.

Inka/Colonial Mix. This notorious site is a must see in Cusco for its mix of Inka and colonial/catholic influences. Per usual (in Peru), there is very little information or historical context posted inside the site so make sure you do your research and/or bring a guidebook.
nice to visit in cusco. nice place,and have a very unique and interesting history,super mysterious and charmy at the same time

Qorikancha.. It was fascinating. I would not recommend hiring one of the guides outside, because there are signs all over o the inside and you will be fine. Make sure to stop by the gardens of Qorikancha a block away (free) which are wonderful and have mummies.
Contrast between inca and colonial, a must in Cusco!. Qorikancha is certainly a must in Cusco, it shows the amazing contrast between colonial and Inca architecture, is a really good place to visit.

Personal family tour . Gina our tour guide did a great job explaining the history of the incas and Spanish. It helped connect everything we had already learned at Machu Picchu. Amazing place with a rich history!!!

Fascinating place, beautiful views. Loved wandering through this place. In my opinion, you don't need a guide - Google the info before you go. Nice views of the city and, still amazed at how the Quechua people were able to fit together multiton stones with no mortar.

Real insight to Incan architecture. Really awesome. A convent that was built on top of the Inca Sun Temple. You can see the old base of the Incan temple and how they built these massive structures to be earthquake proof. Plus great views of the town and a modern art display on the second floor. Definitely worth it.

Korikancha is a must see in Cusco. This was a fantastic start to prepare us for all that we would see and here over the next few days of our journey to Macchu Pichu. But don't make the same mistake we did. Korikancha is in the church. It is NOT the same as the Museo Arceologico de Korikancha, which is a weird little underground place with mummies and elongated skulls. The Korikancha for real is awe-inspiring. It is also amazing how the Spanish just decided to build on top of Inkan architecture, taking advantage of it while at the same time destroying it. Don't miss the painting of the Inkan constellations and its explanation!
It was a nice visit . I much preferred other sites since this one lacked true incan character as it was completely redone by the Spaniards in the 1600s.

A Beautiful Building. This place is steeped in so much history from an Inca temple through to how the Spanish built a church over the Inca temple to show their dominance over them. The stones of the temple of the Incas were so precisely match to fit together, not even a piece of paper could be inserted between them, even today! Fascinating place.

Worth having a guide. Arrive early & have a guide. This location played such an important role in Incan culture & helps you understand the other things you'll see in the area. This is a great tour to do on your first day in Cusco. Enjoy!

Kind of cool. With it's beautiful grounds and historic buildings Convento de Domingo Qorikanchan is worth a look. A short walk from the town center of Cusco the monastery is beautiful with it's historic buildings and grounds. I would not however go out of my way to visit.

Interesting overlap of two cultures. They architecture is the Spanish influence set on top of the older but ancient and durable Temple of the Sun. Both cultures revere it. We were on guided Gate 1 tour and having a guide explain to you makes a huge difference Saw previous review call it a quick stop and we found we could have studied it for hours. Right across from Incredible Palacio Del Inka Hotel
Beautiful. Qorikancha is a must see when visiting Cusco. Beautiful scenery and a nice view from the castle. Interesting tour.
Quick visit but worth it. You want to see the history of Cusco and the Inca people. Nice way to take it in. Historically relevant a must see.

Definitely worth a visit. Touch the walls and try to see the past.. The perfect illustration of Catholicism built over Inca architecture. I had two favorite pieces here. One was a gold depiction of Inca symbols and the other, a painting showing how the Inca viewed the heavens. I stood there, touching a wall, wishing that I had the power to see the past.... The landscaping is beautiful, too.

Amazing place. We did the temple complex as part of our Cusco day tour. It was the most interesting of all places visited that day. The complex which used to be an important Incan religious shrine and subsequently converted to a church complex by the colonizers, is a good take off point of understanding the Incan culture and history. The remaining Incan structures demonstrates the skill and knowledge of the ancient Incans in construction and architecture. This is a must-do for every Cusco visitor.

Interesting site in Central Cusco. We did a quick run thru the place with a guide we hired out front for about $10. In 30-49min she gave us an amazing insight to Quirikancha and the Incan building process. A beautiful place with great history re the Incans and their Spanish conquerors!

Enjoyed. This Temple was the most important temple in the Inca Empire dedicated to the Sun God. Hard to believe that the walls were covered in sheets of gold and gold statues throughout. This is a very busy tourist stop, so pick your time. We did the tour ourselves with written material, everything is clearly identified and if tour groups are walking around you can hear the talk given if they stop where you are viewing, otherwise hire a guide, up to you. Can walk from the main town square or catch a taxi - very cheap.
Its ok. Too many people inside, entrance fee ok, history good! I will recommend it as last activity in cusco
Amazing and rich history!. Must visit site in Cusco and the garden is beautiful with a beautiful valley views of Cusco in the background.

EXCELLENT EXAMPLE OF TWO DIFFERENT CULTURES. As previous reviewers have stated, this is an amazing mix of Inca and Spanish architecture. There is not much more to add, except that there is also excellent markets down from here that are also worth the visit.
The real pearl of the Inca engineering. Literally the Temple Of The Sun, where walls used to be covered in sheets of solid gold. The dream of your Indiana Jones inner.

Beauty beyond beliefe. Someone pinch me!There was so much going on, in just one place that I was afraid that I wasn't going to be able to absorb it all. I know I was there, I saw it all with my own eyes but I still am at a loss for words. History comes to life, right before your eyes.

amazing place. this was an old Inca temple in which the Spanish built a church. It was amazing. Both architectures combined made for a beautiful building and seeing the Inca stonework next to the Spanish masonry was fascinating. It was beautiful, serene and magical. I highly recomend visiting this site with a guide, who can explain things to you.

Layers of history. The complex hosts one rare example of inca curved wall remembering the wall of the temple of the sun in Macchu Picchu, a few structural inca terraces and a couple of buildings which have been inglobated in the convent of Santo Domingo. The guides as in many locations have different versions, so i keep suggesting to leave the hotel with the wiki page of the complex in your phone and enjoy the tour yourself. Interesting also the church museum, the paint exposition is nothing of special but it's worth the canonical ten minutes visit.

Cultural centre of former Inca Empire. We took a guide whose enthusiasm was evident. "Yerusa".She told of the history of the Inca and how the building evolved over the centuries. 30 soles each for guide and 10 soles each to enter. Our guide had good english. Personally disappointed to hear only one version of what may have happened as research has moved on from the academic standpoint.

A bit underwhelming but still something you don't want to miss.. There is a great deal of historical information offered in a few areas which is nice to read, however it does tend to get busy which can make this difficult. Walking around the grounds was quite nice as there was a lot to see. The paintings in the room on the far side of the convent are a can't miss. Also, if you make it up to the third floor near the library there's a door that will let you out onto a small roof deck!
Good value for money. Beautiful place with mix of Inca and colonial architecture. Very nice garden as well. A nice educational relaxed visit.

Beautiful mix between inca and spanish architecture. If you've already visited lots of ruins in the region, you might find the place a little underwhelming. For me, since this was the first ruin site I visited, I very much enjoyed it. The Spanish conquistadors built a church over the inca's temple of sun and the mixture of both architectures is simply incredible! Entrance fee is 10soles. You can hire a guide at the entrance, which is probably worth it if you are not accompanied by a local friend, as you will want to understand the historical background, to help appreciate the beauty of the place. A must if you are in Cusco and should perhaps be done before heading to Machu Picchu. Visit is about 1hour but you can decide to stay longer: visitors have access to the beautiful garden which is a great place to relax with a book on a sunny day.

Gorgeous grounds, interesting exhibits inside. The Qurikancha used to be the capital building of the Incas, and now it is a museum. What I love most about this ancient building is its grounds. They are filled with beautiful flowers and a vibrant green lawn. The building itself is a great example of how ancient Incan and Spanish and colonial art hybridize into the modern Peruvian landscape. The exhibits inside are a little less interesting; they more or less say "all of this used to be covered in gold before the Spanish stole it all. It used to look great... but now it doesn't...." It is worth a pass through, but not super thoroughly. A tour guide may not be necessary since most of the plaques have an English side as well.
Impressive is all I can say. Impressive is all I can say. We went as a part of a tour group and had a guide that was able to explain all about the church and Inca buildings.

Great starting point.. This was a great starting point for our introduction to Inca construction with our tour guide.It is absolutely amazing as to how they built these constructions as well as a background to the reasonsDefinitely worth the visit.

The HEART of the Incas.. I escort groups to Peru every year and this is where we ALWAYS start the tour about the Incas. The stone work is beautiful and the history of both the Incas and the Spanish come together in a very informative way. A MUST visit to begin your Inca experience.

The most enjoyable museum in town for me. Really love this place when decided to stop by.It has a huge front yard which faces the main street and is archeological it itself that people can walk through and hang about after u been through the main entrance. The main entrance is actually behind the "front" and up a little hill. The convent was apparently the sun temple before the missionaries converted it to a convent. It has lots of original inca and christian architectures within and outside of the structure. Touch the original stones and fee the passage of time Lots of arts and artifacts housed in thereEntry fee was cheap enough.I do recommend going with a spanish speaking friend so u dont get tempted to hire and translator/guide althought they seem quite goodVery impressive place that u can get lost in and submerge urself in the magic of their history
Not to be missed. It's a place that need to be visited while in Cusco.The inka history is overwhelming explained from this place.

Great and sad. A great site. Too bad it was looted by conquistadors and then covered up by a Catholic Church. But the Incans built their civilization by the sword so I suppose you can't feel sorry for them. Too bad the Catholic Church in Peru seems to have a unique policy against taking pictures inside their churches, even in the sacristy which is not even used to say mass.
we really were crazy about this place. this fortress encompasses all the admiration we feel for peru and its people, this was the center of all religious activity those times and was sacred to them.

A interesting place to view both Inca and Spanish Architecture. A stunning place which bridges two cultures together. It was originally a Incan place but when the Spanish took over much of Peru they destroyed the Incan parts. The Spanish rebuilt the place to fit there standards and views. Now it offers both views of the Incan and Spanish ways of architecture. I would recommend it to anyone who is taking a trip to Cusco.

Don't miss the Sun Temple in Cusco. Great example of a colonial church built over an original Inca sun temple. Surprising amount of impressive Inca architecture still visible in and around the Spanish colonial buildings. If you have the time a local guide will take you round in about 40mins for 40sols.

Beautiful garden and interesting historical grounds. We heard about this from a friend and decided to go check it out. It's really not far from the main square, but not many people seemed to go here. The grounds are a a very interesting mix of Inca and Spanish architecture and there is a beautiful garden in the back of the site with thousands of gorgeous flowers. Definitely worth a visit!

An interesting place, the guide made it better . A beautiful place, but not much Inca there. The Spanish took over the place in 17th century and destroyed a lot of the Inca parts which was sad but there was still alot to see. There was some description in English but the tour guides outside who you can hire for £8 made it much more interesting

Very interesting. A lot of history and architecture bridging several periods. Monastery was built around the Incan temples. Notice the temples and the corner stones that have only moved an inch during centuries of earthquakes. Just amazing engineering.

Staying Power. Qurikancha is an odd to the Inca's building prowess. Even after all the plaster, that was put on by the Spaniards, was shaken off by an earthquake the original 1000 plus year old structure stands beautifully still. If you want to go to the museum part of this site, make sure to show up with plenty of time left to closing. The museum closed early unannounced.

Once you visit this place you really understand about the Inkas and how amazing they were. As I was visintg the diferent rooms and looked at the excellent way the fitted the stones in a perfect way, you love it get a good guide so its better to enjoy and bring back alive those times and grandiosity of this culture

Worth the Visit. We were within walking distance to this attraction. It is always pleasant to visit places of Historical value. The gardens are well manicured. The inside is fabulous. Sorry I can not produce my pictures. They tell the story. I lost them, but seeing the place puts an indelible mark on you.
Interesting site. Enjoyed viewing the historical aspects of this site. The gardens are lovely, a nice place to relax on a warm day.

More Valuable Foundation. Qorikancha is found inside a colonial church in Cuzco. The Spaniards had torn down much of the Incan temple and used the stone in their own building projects. The Incan remains have been discovered in stages after earthquakes have caused parts of the colonial structure to collapse over the course of several hundred years. You'll see some classic trapezoidal stonework, niches, an example of the Lego-style process for fitting stones, and a portal used for astronomical observations, among other things. It's a good place to start building your understanding of Inca architecture, mathematics, and astronomy.

Sacred place of the Incas. We were very happy to have seen the most important temple of the Inca's empire! The temple boasts the finest stone masonry, a special technique of the Incas. But the most important is that it last in spite of a big effort of the Spaniards to destroy it and built Santo Domingo Church on top of it. However, their church got destroyed during devastating earthquake in 1953 while some impressive base parts of the Golden Temple of Qorikancha appeared again as Phoenix! We were quite impressed by it trying to go back in time imagining its atmosphere during the Incas!

Lots of paintings and Spanish architecture. You have to be really into Spanish colonial culture to appreciate the Convento de Santo Domingo as it's really built over an Inka site that offers more interest.

Not enough remains to make it really interesting. The original Incan site was destroyed by the Spanish, in particular the Santo Domingo Brothers. What a travesty! But it has not left enough of the Inca ruins to really make it so dramatic. It's great for seeing how the Incans built the walls, how they cut and moved the stone, how they planned their buildings but it's not so interesting as some of the other sites or even the Cusco Inka Museum.

This is the place to learn about the Incas. There is so much here of interest; not least the clash of cultures to create such a unique mishmash of religious worship. It's well set out and interesting for a wander; there are lots of nooks and crannies. Choose a side route to walk to it. It's also worth taking your camera if you only sometimes take one out.

Popular sunspot. A popular little place with a lot of history. Sadly this was built over the old Inca ruins but you can still see some of the original structure. You can sit in the garden area and vendors sell ice creams and drinks. It's just a 5/10 minute walk from the main square.

Beautiful Site. Qurikancha is one of those places that you have to know the history behind in order to appreciate it. (Simply reading about it online is sufficient) I've never done the tour, but I always enjoy walking by this ancient sun temple and reflecting on the Inca past & history. So fascinating and recommended for tourists to Cusco!

A Must See. No matter what your interest...incredible Inca buildings, Spanish colonial churches, colonial artwork, or the classic story of what happens when a thriving civilization is defeated by another...this site has it all. Definitely add it to your "must see" list when in Cusco!!

The history of this Church/Incan Temple is wonderful. You need a good guide to really enjoy the exhibits of this Church built on the foundation of an Incan Temple. The court yard provides good views for photo's and preserves numerous Incan stonework. This place was crowded (even during the off season), so I would recommend visiting in the morning if you can.
See it to feel it. A special place in the world, you have to feel it. The old walls. The views and sounds mixed with the altitude make you wander between South America and the Mustang Pass.

Come in the morning as the afternoon tour groups crowds are oppressive. Located within Cusco city itself Qurikancha is a archeological site hybrid containing the Spanish Cathedral of Iglesia de Santa Dominico which was built onto of the inca ruins of Qorikancha after the Spanish looted it's gold and pilfered it's stone for building materials.Note there is an entrance fee of 10Sol and this isn't included as part of the Boleto Turistico. This was an unexpected addition to our city tour and we visited in the afternoon. Unfortunately our tour seemed to run in parallel with several others and the crowd numbers within this site were oppressive. I couldn't see the limited Incan ruins that remained through the the hoards of elderly asian tour groups playing with their selfie sticks. It felt claustrophobic and was not enjoyable. In addition the ruins offered were very minimal and not that impressive.Overall I would only recommend this site to independent travellers very keen on archeological sites. If you choose to come definitely come in the morning to avoid the tour groups. You would benefit from some historical context so that you feel you aren't just viewing piles of rocks.

Both an Inca Temple & Spanish Cathedral. This place has such rich history and is unique in its Inca and Spanish cultural heritage. However, it gets overly crowded with other tourists and not as impressive as it would've been back when it was in it's golden glory. It is still worth a visit and has a nice view of the city from upstairs.Note: Entrance fee.

Beautiful courtyard. Some nice examples of Incan architecture. I especially liked the courtyard. A shame that the Spaniard colonists destroyed much of the original structures. Amazing that earthquakes destroyed much of the church that the Spaniards built over the original grounds, but the remaining Incan walls survived the quakes because they were so well-constructed by the Incans.

Ancient inca temple with Spanish cathedral. One of the most famous atractions in Cusco. It is worth the trip but if you can manage better go when there are not a lot of groups. You can go on your own or book a guided tour. There is an entering fee in the temple(jan2016) that is not included if you bought the boleto turistico (you pay only one fee to enter several sites) There is a museum below it that you can also visit that is included in the boleto.

think about this place of gold. i am very sorry the spanish took away all the golden ornaments that this place was covered with, imagine now how could it be if they still would be stuck on the walls, how it would shine out with the cusco sun. anyways, i enjoyed this visit here.

Don't pay to go in. Discussing evidence of Spanish attempt to obliterate a indigenous culture.Paid to go in due to Inka wall only to discover you don't need to in order to see the wall which predates yet another Church.You can see the stones and wall from outside. Save your money, buy some food and water.

The Incan Temple inside is the very best of Incan stone work and a must see!. If you think the blocks are impressive on the outside then you need to go and have a look inside. Its 10 soles which is about $3.50. It was the main temple for the Inca empire and was built to show that. The stone work is far greater than any other example in existance. I regularly go there just to have a stroll. Cant recommend it enough.

Amazing architecture of 2 cultures. Our guide did a fantastic job explaining what is known about the Inka temple and the Spanish Church built using pieces of the Inka temple. Such an amazing example of 2 cultures.Convenient central location and a must see in Cusco.

I would like to be here again. When I touch these walls it make me feel as if I would be touching the gold covering it was covered and I think about the spaniards who took it...all was a eight of greed and misery, but the actual hereditaries didnt get anything.

they built over the inkas.... its disgusting for me to accept that the spanish invaders built their awful constructions over the magnificent inka bases & foundations...and using their stones as bricks, so the spanish didnt really worked, only recycled and after destroying the original buildings rebuilt as they pleased.

Amazing sight right in the middle of town. Don’t miss this exquisite church built atop Inca ruins, right in the middle of Cusco! It helps to have a guide to understand what you’re looking at and explain the historical context.

An amazing combination. Qurikancha is a fantastic combination of European and Inca Architecture. I had had no idea how such things could look like, before I visited it. I strongly recommend it to any history-lover or architecture-lover!
I visited this place. it was a nice visit to know something of the Peruvian culture, I was delighted with the history of this building

this was at the very center of the city. I realized that all of this palace was covered in gold & silver...I cant imagine how the inkas let the invaders go away carrying their gold and sacred treasures...Im really sad for that

Cheap access to remaining ruins of Cusco. The Inka ruins here are of high quality. Easy to walk-through with information in English throughout the site. Didn't feel the need for a guide. Estimated time to see everything around half an hour to an hour.

A site to behold !. Beautiful ! Astounding! You can use many words to describe the place, good for picture and great architecture. If you are lucky, once a month they do a special ceremony at the place. Go check it out and have a nap

I wanted to see the gold. It was very sad to know that all the gold I wanted to see and photograph was taken or better SACKED by the spanish 500 years ago, well thats history...the precincts were fabulous and the explanation were so good, I like the general info about this place, the price was acceptable.

Beautiful site with so much history. We were part of a guided tour so we got the benefit of a lot of the history of the site. I think it is really worth getting a guide to fully appreciate it, but even if you don't, this is so beautiful - the building, the grounds, the atrium - that it's still a great visit.

Great!. this is such an amazing place to visit. However, if you dont know the specifics about this place you will NEED a tour guide to explain you about the place and its history. They usually charge an additional 10 soles per person and the guides are usually outside gathering a group of people. Give yourself time to visit this place. also, try to go early in the morning as it gets full later on during the day.
magnificent Inca astronomy. u can walk from the main plaza, and we paid 30 sole to the agent at the museum entrance and he is very passionate about the Inca astronomy advancement.

Important site, sad to see the destruction. Although it might not to be much to look at, this is one of the most important sites in Cusco. We learned on the Inca Trail that the Inca did not damage anything. If there were pre-Incan ruins, they stayed. If there was a boulder in the middle of the path, the trail went around it. So to see the Qurikancha, the Inca temple of the Sun, reduced to rubble with a convent on top of it made me feel absolutely ill. When the Spanish arrived, the plaza was covered in gold to honour the sun but this was all stripped away and melted, then the stones themselves were taken away.

The most depressing of the Incan sites. A must see by any visitor to Peru. This was the site of the great Incan Sun temple which had been adorned with 1 meter deep gold. The Spanish built a fine Cathedral over it. But in the 1950 Peruvian earthquake, part of the Incan walls were uncovered, standing stronger than the Spanish structures, and we all learned where the famous Sun temple at the exact center of the Incan empire was located.

Shame the Spanish looted it. . Located in the center of Cusco's historical district, this must have been an awesome site when it was covered in gold. Would have loved to take pictures inside but not allowed. Another example of incredible Inka architecture. Although the Spanish melted down the gold and carted it away they did build a magnificent Cathedral.

Easy access and super interesting . Easy to get to, one block from the main plaza. Super interesting history and nice architecture. Entry not included in the boleta turistico, but not at all expensive to enter. Included in the city day tour of cusco, which you should do if you've got time. If not, I've heard very good if the guides available at the church itself, especially Diana.

Must visit place- if only place to visit in Cusco. This is the only church/temple / paid attraction to visit in Cusco. The admission fees are decent unlike the cathedral at the Plaza with its ridiculous rates. Admission fees are 10 sols and you get a perspective of the size of the Incan main temple from the size of the church as well as the scale model of the Incan temple. Kiddos for the monks in preserving the ancient Incan temple rather than destroying it and keeping mum about it after independence from the Spanish. The paintings, rooms, decorations found on the church are certainly astounding and mouth dropping. Certainly worth 1-2 hours of your time . The paintings are very Peruvian and its perspective on religion very interesting based on local perception. Certainly the best attraction in Cusco region other than Machu Picchu.Walking distance from the Plaza and a pleasant area to hang around.

Depressing. Once again, this monument is mostly a Catholic church having been built on top of a beautiful Incan temple. All of the still existing Inca structures were at one point plastered over and still show small flakes of the white plaster in the pores of the stone. It is quite distressing. I also almost wish they would put a new replica sun disc where it used to be, because currently there is an out of use well with flowers around it. The highlight was the Rainbow temple, with the smallest rock ever used by the Incas.

Interesting, mostly the church, though.. The history was very interesting, but there were so many people and such a small space, that I didn't feel like I got to get into the story so much. A good start to the City Tour, though.

Another example of Inca and pre-Inca history and culture brutalized by Spanish at Qurikancha-Cusco. Unbelieveable scale of destruction of native history and culture by relatively ignorant but powerful conquistadors. My heart bled to see the destruction of history and culture by Eurpopean colonialists at Qurikancha. Once you stabilize your emotion, enjoy the historic facts, engineering marvel, and architectural wonders. Comes as a default with any Cusco tour.

Amazing ancient architecture . This is a must see in Cusco. The ancient Incan architecture and engineering is absolutely amazing. The Spaniards used the existing temple foundation and walls and built their cathedral on top. The stone work is elaborate and hard to believe what they could accomplish with limited tools. The grounds were also beautiful. It's on one of the main streets in Cusco so it's very easy to get to. We passed by it almost every day as we walked around town.

Beautiful indoors and out. I may have combined this review with the one of the convent which surrounds Qurikancha. Please put this place on your list when you are in Cuzco, as it is so important historically, both for the Incas, and the Spanish, who came later. There is an area with a stunning painting of the Milky Way, and our guide explained the significance of the galaxy to the Incans. In addition, there is a copy of an interpretive table, the original of which was purportedly made of gold. The table is full of symbols, an explanation of which is nearby. It is a sheltered place to wander around, and thus a good choice for the rainy season.

An unusual juxtaposition of Incan and "modern" architecture and life. Koricancha was an important Inca site long before the Spanish descended on Peru and built the Convent around it. In South America, Convent can be used as a term to house either priests or nuns. In this case, priests live there, and their area is understandably off-limits to tourists. However, I did get to see a group of them in their traditional Dominican vestments and it was impressive. You get the best of both worlds here, first with the Incan architecture and its unbelievable joining of perfectly-chiseled blocks, to the breathtaking, huge oil paintings which adorn the walls of the lovely courtyard. The Incan portion is actually built to withstand seismic activity, and there is a very interesting alignment of windows allowing you to see through several of the rooms if you are standing on a small stepping-stone to raise your eyes to the proper level to observe this part of the structure. Again, a guide is essential here if you want the full experience. An alternative is to purchase a guide book, or research on Wikipedia prior to your visit. There are lovely gardens arranged on terraces, and the view from the hillside is spectacular.

Don´t leave Cusco without paying a visit!. This is a pretty special piece of architecture in the history of Cusco. You can see literally how the changes happened from the era of the Incas to when the Spanish came. It is beautiful and not expensive so be sure to visit!
On the tour but not worth side trip. Incan ruins in a Dominican church. I am having trouble remembering it - it was not spectacular. Not worth a special visit unless you are a real aficionado.

Sun the god for me as well. I couldn't understand how the Incas did so perfect job, well polished walls with a careful design; I got in the morning the best time I think, 'cause the mega groups got in the afternoon and it's very crowded, this is located to three blocks from the main square.

Good place to visit. Especially as it's close to the city centre. . This proved to be quite an interesting museum. The day we visited many of the rooms were closed for some reason but we still got a feel for the place. I would suggest reading something about the place before going, especially if you dont speak Spanish as there isn't much in the way of descriptions in the museum . It took us about 1 and a half hours to explore everything.

Amazing paintings inside. Very cool site in the center of the city, 10 minute walk from Plaza de Armas. The cost to enter is 40 sols and you will need about 45 minutes to walk through the grounds and enjoy the site. There are amazing Peruvian religious paintings inside. Ensure this place in on your list to see.

Lots of Things to See. I visited here with my wife. The name of Qorikancha came from Qori (Gold) and Kancha (place). This means that there were lots of gold in this church at Incan Empire Aera, but the Spanish took away all the gold here in the 16th century.This church had lots of thngs to see such as beautiful patio, corridor, garden, trapezoid window frames and paintings representing ancient Incan Empire. I could not see three consecutive trapezoid window frames because many tourists were queuing to see them. This church is must-visit place in Cusco.
Interesting. Worth seeing if you have the time but not as impressive as some of the other ruins. You do get to see the huge stones that the incas moved to the site and made part of the building.
Very Intesting Site. This is another Inca site that is worth the visit. Very interesting structures and lots of history here.

Temple of the Sun!. Beautiful building from the outside but do have to pay an admission fee to get in. Check out the church right next door, beautiful place, nice art on the walls, with a lifesize replia of Jesus Christ after his crucifixation, eerily life like, and moving!
its worth seeing it!!. amazing combination of history, culture und the glory of architecture. the technic of this building same like other Inka"s creatures attract by its mystery!

Contrasting Architecture. This is part of the city tour.Some of the walls are from the original Incan structure.Most of the Incan building has been converted to colonial structure so it provides a contrasting perspective of the conquerors and the conquered.Lots of history so make sure to listen to the guides.It can get crowded.
Start here in Cusco. The history of the region is fascinating - take a guided tour here, and you won't regret it. The place is beautiful and the guides are all knowledgeable.
Good place to visit. Nice place to visit Ten Soles to get in, so not expensive and well woth the look around, we were taken her as part of the city tour.

Good place to visit. This was one of the places we stoped on our city tour, I really liked it, it has an early Incan look and again the stonework is fabulous. Make sure you walk down the hill and look back to the building from the Avenida El Sol (street) it is very impressive.

Good background history. This is an interesting place to visit for an hour or two. Inca base with a Spanish finish. Gives some sense of what happened to the Inca structures when the Spanish arrived. Still some base Inca stones. Interesting Art, both old and new in two galleries. The grounds were well kept and pleasant. Cost only 10 soles to enter. Guides available. Could have been a bit more description in some of the exhibits and rooms. I overheard some guides giving more background and I had a written guide from a book so that helped.

Okay 👌!. This museum is okay, not much to see. The room with the paintings of Saint's was the most beautiful. This museum gives an impression on how the temple's were made. Also, the bathrooms were very clean and modern.
Insight. Gives a lot of insight into Inca architectural styes and building techniques. Doesn't require a long visit but worth doing early. Close to the cntre.

Beautiful site along Avenida del Sol. As you walk down Avenida del Sol, the main street in Cusco, you can't help but see this beautiful fortress. In a city full of cars and modern hotels, it's nice to see something from the past still reserved. You can walk through it day or night. It doesn't close.
good start for city tour. very interesting place, covers 3 stages of architecture. pay attention to your guide and do not wander off
Very interesting. Again we were very lucky to have the services of our excellent guide Manny so we did not miss out on any of the history of this monument
