Inca walls. the precision cuts made on the stone and stone wall makes you wonder what kind of technology was envolved in the building process
A must see in Cusco. Amazing architecture. Inca architecture at it's best. Out tour guide did a great job explaining the entire complex. Another MUST see in Cusco

V nice!. This place was supposed to be the most important landscape be of the incans. Now it just has some remains and a beautiful courtyard with flowers.
Definitely worth seeing though, especially since it's walking distance from the centre!

Fascinating early Inca masonry in convent. Went here as part of a half day tour with local guide around Cusco. Guide was very knowledgeable, showing us how the original Inca walls were incorporated into the church and convent. Views outside of Cusco also valuable. Worth the visit.

Temple of the Sun. Qurikancha is a lovely temple with exquisite grounds. Our tour guide brought us here and really helped me to understand the history behind this beautiful temple so I would recommend you go on a guided tour. You are only allowed to take photos in specific areas.

Part of our City Tour of Cusco. Koricancha convent was one of the stops on our city tour of historic spots. It is a cool old colonial style piece of architecture that is built on traditional stepped ground and decorated inside much like every catholic church you visit in south america. The building is fairly well preserved and there are a few really cool old paintings there that they request you do not photograph, but some people still try.

Very pretty. Usually this is part of the city tour, but I visited it on my own which allowed me to walk around and take pictures at my own pace. Got lost a couple of times, but in a place like that, getting lost is kind of great. There are so many groups visiting at the same time that I could also overhear the historical information when I was interested without a problem.
Super interesting. The best place to admire the amazing Inka masonry. The convent still has some of the initial walls. It has been - like the Blue Mosque in Istanbul - many things before.
Not to be Missed. A very impt place for Incan history; must have an excellent guide, knowledgeable about Incan engineering to appreciate this place.
Well worth a visit. Great place to visit. Beautiful inside and out. Easily accessible as it is a short walk from the historical centre of town.

Catholisation of the Incas. This fascinating building/museum is blatant evidence of how a nation, its culture and religion is overthrown by conquerors. Some lovely remains of original Aztec buildings have been built over and incorporated into this lovely colonial building. There is also a lovely painting gallery in the cloister. Well worth a visit

Good if you have some spare-time in Cuzco. This was apparently once the most important Inka-Palace in Cuzco. Now it's rather a church/colonial house with some remains of it. Walking through is nevertheless fun and some little explanation is provided (Spanish and English). If you have some spare-time in Cuzco a visit to this place isn't wrong.

Do not worth the price. Sadly, it is not included in the full city ticket (130pen) and I understand why. The ruins, even if authentic, are lame and the expositions do not worth it. Worst, you can even visit a big part of the covent, only the garden is interesting. Would not recommend to pay for it, prefer other activities
Get a guide. Added to our macchu picchu experience without doubling up on info. Nice to learn a bit about the engineering and beliefs.

Learn the history of the Inkas and take in the beauty of Cusco. We spent a few hours checking out Qurikancha and we thoroughly enjoyed learning about the Inkas, the history of the area surrounding Cusco, and the arrival of the Spanish. The grounds are beautifully maintained and are centrally located in Cusco. Visiting Qurikancha helped us to have a good understanding of the Inkas and their culture before we headed out to see the many historical sites surrounding Cusco.
Amazing!. Make sure you get a guided tour or you will miss out on so much history.Another unbelievable piece of history in Peru and one you really should see.
Beautifull ruins and church. What a beautiful mix of inca construction and colonial church. the paintings inside are amazing, the inca temples are so well done and beautifully carved.
Inca creme dela creme. No visit to Cusco should miss a visit here - the cradle of Inca history, religion & cultural importance. Awesome with an excellent guide Danny (Yoni Daniel Aguirre Gomez).

fascinating. We hired a guide at the door and were thoroughly glad we did, as there wasn't much in the way of signage (especially english-language signage). I believe her name was Lady, and she was a wealth of information. I think this was perhaps the single most informative thing we did while in Cusco. In part because of our guide, but also because of the broad amount of information ... she better explained Inca construction, the history of the city, etc. Took about 60-90 minutes. The gardens out side were beautiful, as well.

Quick and cheap. Its 10 soles to enter. I'm not sure if its year-round, but when I went there was an incredible art gallery inside. Paintings, movies, modern sculptures- cool stuff. The garden over look was amazing too!

Incan ruins are interesting. Worthwhile visiting for the Incan ruins, less so for the Spanish church itself. The precision with which they carved the huge building blocks is impressive. Such a pity that the conquistadors destroyed so much of Incan construction

Magnificent architectural and historical visit. Mandatory visit if you're in Cusco. Mandatory visit. Astonishing place of the highest importance to the Incan empire which the tour guides will make sure to emphasize. Incredible architecture that will let you appreciate the inca's prowess as builders and designers.This being a temple of sun worship also includes some religious pieces and stories behind it, and you'll find some unexpected beautiful view and green zones.Must visit.

Beautiful history. Our taxi driver pointed out Qurikancha on the way into town from the airport, he said "that is the most important place in all of Cusco!" We went to visit on the second day and I can say that he was absolutely right. The architecture and the museum are really worth a trip to learn about the history of this Inca temple and the Empire. I was blown away by the art work that was inside of the museum that explained the four corners of the Inca world. The grounds are also really beautiful and the sunlight is amazing here, I can see why this was the Temple of the Sun.

Magnificent architectural and historical visit. Mandatory visit if you're in Cusco. Sacred place of which importance you'll probably only realize once you take a guided tour, this place, of the highest Inca importance and order still manages to preserve some of the pillars of a fantastic Inca temple dedicated to the sun.You'll come upon some wonderfull walls and learn about their prowess as builders and religious beliefs. Mandatory stop.
Beautiful architecture. Set in lovely grounds this temple is both interesting and beautiful. There is interesting art on show. Well worth the 10 soles entry fee. A real highlight in Cusco.

A historical mystery. This place is really a special place. The Inca temples and constructions are truly special. They are a lot different from other old buildings and they have constructed some wonderful buildings. The most remarkable thing about these buildings is, that they had no special equipment, they just picked up the rocks from somewhere in the mountains and then used these huge rocks to build incredible things.
Temple of the Sun. Qorikancha is t he most important Temple of the Sun in the Tawantinsuyo Empire. Qorikancha means gold and kancha means place. This museum has a great exhibit with great history.

Amazing and Sad. This is a small museum which sheds great insight into the Incan culture. Seeing the layers of history on the exterior with Incan stonework topped by Spanish masonry, expresses the history of this place very visibly. The exhibits are especially interesting and despite our prior visit to the Inca Museum shed additional and important insights into Incan history. One comment, the exit is confusing and bizarre. Guards yelled us yet we had crossed no ropes.

So Beautiful!. This is one of the most beautiful buildings in all of Cusco. The architectural design is flawless and is so beautiful standing tall in all its splendor. I very much enjoyed the views it offered 360 and is definitely worth the stop.

Excellent tour guide. Incredibly sad for me, this is the Joy of history.
We, Inkari SA group found it very informative and meaningful

a must see in cusco. Here you can see the absolute pinnacle of Inca period architecture. At this site you will not see the random angles where walls were formed. You will see perfectly straight lines recessed entry ways which in my opinion is extremely impressive.

A MUST before Macchu Picchu. We almost missed this site... don't miss it. We had no idea of the staggering work that was uncovered after the 1950 earthquake. This was the site of temples that marked the center of the center of Inca worship. Hire one of the guides at the door. You will see absolute perfection in Inca sacred construction. Although Macchu is staggering for its setting, this is utterly amazing for its attention to detail and perfection in alignment and technique.

An interesting place to visit. Visited late afternoon on our first day in Cusco. I think it is worth seeing. The structure really highlights the history of Peru- a Catholic convent plopped in the middle of an Incan structure. We initially were going to do a self guided tour and just read the plaques but we ended up hiring a guide. There was a guide standing near the entrance who gave us a tour for a small fee and we didn't have one booked in advance. I think she charged us 30 soles. It was worth it. The grounds are lovely and the history is pretty interesting.

Take a guided tour . I went there by myself and it was beautiful and speciel. I though had to sneak around to try to catch some of what the guides was telling. There is not a lot of information on the signs. So take a guided tour.
ecletic mix of exhibits. This is a somewhat weird church/cultural complex, but the grounds are beautiful. Skip the tour--it's fun to just walk around and take in the sights.

Great History Lesson. This used to be the main temple of the Incas. Beautifully maintained and cheap admission. You can also pay for a guide, but we opted out as everything was written in Spanish and English.

Don't Miss. Come here and take it all in. It's an interesting blend of colonial church and original Inca temple, with some very pretty parts of both. It's worth either reading up on the place or coming with a guide to get the most out of the experience.

Seems like Spain. interesting tour, amazing history- had some very cool artwork, and just walking around gave some marvelous perspective. Would recommend getting a guide or bringing wikipedia research or a relevant app along with you- some of the cooler things don't have labels or descriptions

Great View over Cusco. Great View over Cusco from the site of the Castle. The corridors have heavy carved wooden ceilings.Interesting to wander along the corridors and the astrological room is stunning. Best done with a guide to explain the exhibits.

Beautiful grounds and an impressive piece of history.. There are so many impressive sites around Cusco. This is one worth a visit. I enjoyed the dichotomy of the original Incan walls and structures juxtaposed within the architecture of the convent. The grounds are beautiful as well, with lovely flowering plants all along the side outside wall.

Amazing inside!. The building is beautiful from the outside, but I was shocked and excited to find Incan temples inside - temple of the rainbow, stars and sun (I think). The rocks are similar to what you see in Machu Picchu - very nicely carved huge stones.... WOW.

One of the best historical sites in Cuzco. The Qoricancha is one of the most interesting and important historical sites in the Cuzco region, and is highly worth a visit. It is a Spanish cathedral that is built on top of an Incan temple. There is an interesting tour of the premises, and I marvel at the incan stonework outside of the complex. In the Cuzco area I also recommend visiting Sachsayhuaman, the Plaza de Armas (the main plaza in Cuzco), the Mercado San Pedro, and La Merced church. The main cathedral in Cuzco is nice, but way too expensive! I recommend visiting it when mass is in session, then it is free to go inside!!

Most emblematic Inka building in Cusco. Qurikancha or Coricancha was the one of the most important buildings during the Inka Empire. It was dedicated to study Gods and the nature. During the conquest was converted into a monastery, so today is possible to observe the mix of the two constructions types, one over the other. Quality of the construction is impressive which made it an iconic building in the city. It is a must to see in Cusco. Most of the city tours include Qurikancha visit, however you can buy tickets by yourself and go there, taking all the time you want to visit it.

Important Cusco site. Definitely worth visiting and paying for a guided tour. A lot can be learned about the history of the area, Incan building techniques, and colonization by the Spaniards. I would highly recommend trying to go at an off time of day. We were there at what appeared to be peak time and the crowded conditions made the experience less than ideal.
Pretty Interesting. A lot of interesting history inside. I enjoyed walking through and marveling at Incan ruins so nearby.

Start Here Before Touring Cusco. I checked this out during the Inti Raymi festival and thought it was a cool place. Cusco's got a lot of history and this is a good place to start to give you context before checking out the rest of the city.
Largest ever cathedral. Good if you like cathedrals and bling, otherwise exhausting!Huge.Interetsing Last Supper with guides pig.
Walking through History. We toured this site as part of our walking tour of Cusco. It was impressive to see first hand how things were done, and the impact that the Spanish had on the Incan cities.

Great view of the city. The site is elevated and offers a great view of the city. I recommend a visit to the Qorikancha. If possible, get a guide or read up on the history before the visit to learn more about the place.

A must see in Cuzco. This used to be the Qurikancha temple or Temple of the Inca Sun. However, with the arrival & subsequent colonization of Cuzco city the edifice standing now is the Sto Domingo church. One should go here with a guide who knows the history of the place to understand it better. This is a place you would want to go back again.

Sun Temple revealed after Spanish intrusion. Spaniards piggy backing the Sun Temple of Qurikancha by building their monastery next to and over an existing temple. Luckily for us visitors there was so much effort in excavating some areas to reveal the original Incan monument. The renovation was very good and we see now how the Imperial style of construction is used in the original temple walls, another marvel of their artistry and advancement. Would have loved to spend more time there except it was part of a day tour in Cusco. Well worth the visit!

if you want to understand Inca architecture. you should have a guide for Qurikancha, one does not realise how amazing the place is until it is explained. The Inca building is only visible since recently, when there was an earthquake and part of the Spanish church above collapsed, uncovering the Inca site underneath (very well preserved actually)

Go!! Visit!!. It's a saddening reminder of the destruction the Spaniards brought onto the Inca, but it is so beautiful, it's a perfect mixture of Inca and Spaniard architecture. Not pictures are allowed in some areas, and it's covered by the Tourist Pass.
I recommend. It is worth it with a guide. The building is beautiful by itself, but the history is something else!
Loved it!. I really enjoyed seeing this sight. However, I would really recommend paying for a guide. I would not have made much sense of it if I had not. But well worth the visit.

Beautiful stonework . This is definitely one of my favorite stops in Cuzco. I was wowed by the beautiful stonework on my first visit ten years ago and just as blown away on my second visit last month. It's probably best to opt for a guided tour to get the full history. It's a unique opportunity to see how Incan stonework was transformed into a new religious use by the spaniards. The gardens outside are also lovely.

Stunning clash of two cultures. We could not see the inside of the church, even though my companion had wished to attend the Mass, the brother was not letting her in! The outer areas show the remains of the Inka temple and explain what decorations and festivities were held here. The amount of gold that once decorated the temple must have been overwhelming to the Spanish. We had a guide for the day, who explained what we were seeing, as well described the paintings lining the courtyard. He really wasn't necessary.

Another must see in Cusco. This is the center if the Inca world. Unfourtnately little remains to see beyond some walls. The rest is colonial built over the ruins. Make sure you go to the muesuem under the site.
Don't miss it!!!. it was the core of the Inca Empire, besides the place was partially destroyed by the conquistadors, You still can see the best stone work of the Incas. So prefect!!!
Beautiful architecture and history.... It is worth the admission of 10 soles to go inside and enjoy the beautiful architecture and history. It is conveniently located in the historic city center.
Inca history. More amazing Inca history and information about Cusco. A lot of people so had to wait a bit but overall very informative.
Another great temple. I went there with a group and it was very interesting. Quite crouded, but we could still enjoy it. Very Interesting place where Inca and colonial cultures meet

A Church standing strong on ancient foundation.. The Iglesia is especially interesting to see as it's built on the foundations that were built by the original Peruvians. They stood firm while most of the Spanish built structures collapsed during the earthquakes that are fairly frequent in this area. It's a must do when in Cusco.

THE INCA ASPECTS I FOUND INTERESTING RATHER THAN THE CATHOLIC. This is the Catholic Santo Domingo Monastery built on the foundations of the Inca Koricancha Temple of the Sun. I found the Inca aspects of this place more interesting than the Catholic. Parts of the original building are still visible and a tour guide is invaluable to explain the various facets. Well worth a visit; even more so if you are interested in Catholic religious buildings.

Not as good as I was expecting. From the outside this looks very impressive but I was a bit disappointed when I went inside. I thought the place would be packed full of artifacts and history but there wasn't really, there was an art display but it wasn't my cup of tea.There are some parts of an original Inca structure inside the building which is nice to see. The outside space is very nice.
Nice place!!. I saw this place and I can recomment it, is in the center of Cusco you can just walk fro your hotel and see how nice is that place!!

Great architecture. The original Inca sun temple was stripped of all its gold and silver by the conquistadors before suffering the indignity of having a Catholic Church built on top of it. However an earthquake in 1950 destroyed much of the church, leaving the Inca building largely intact.A trip around the interior is fascinating, as is the nearby underground museum

No Need To Go Inside and No Need For Tur Guide. When visiting this church, I would recommend that there is not need to actually go inside. All of the interest is actually at the exterior of the church. You will see a number of crucifixes and there are also tombs evident. From what I gather the interior isn't that spectacular. If you really want to spend money I would advise just making a small donation to one of the local registered charities.

Beautiful Inca walls visible inside old Jesuit church. Beautiful and well-maintained church and ancient Inca walls. Lovely gardens below, good quality museum - religious paintings in several rooms on the ground floor as well as an interesting contemporary art on the second level.

Crowded but don't miss it!. This was super crowded, but due to its history well worth the visit. Try to get there early to avoid crowds. Recommend getting a guide to get more information - we missed out doing so.
Fair. This place was SO busy when we visited. Some great views of Cusco on the terraces..but the sheer busyness of the place made it less than enjoyable.

MUST SEE attraction at Cusco. Fascinating history, exceptional art, and wonderful mix of religion and culture. Day or night (I would recommend both for the great pictures), the story of the Incan foundation and church that sits on top of it is an interesting one.

Favorite Site. This was quite possibly my favorite site in Cuzco. There is so much history vividly portrayed (the Spanish/Incan collision) and the old Inca architecture is incredible. We hired a guide right outside the site. It was nice to have her explain some of the Inca architecture so we could really appreciate their knowledge of mathematics and architecture. The gardens outside are also lovely.
Another must-see. Another must-see; so interesting to see the combination of Spanish and Incan influences together. Easy to walk to.

A little gem in Cusco - worth a visit!. The photos you can take here of the Inca stonework is great. If you are on a tour, you will be told about the different rooms in which the gods were worshipped i.e. the Rainbow, the Sun. There is so much to take in, and obviously see past the Spanish influence which is more dominant on arrival.

Local history, architecture, and art. Interesting juxtaposition of Spanish and Incan cultures/architecture. The Convent of Santo Domingo sits on top of the Qorikancha‘s Inca foundation. (Fun fact: the original Inca stonework survived an earthquake in 1650, but the Spanish cathedral on top needed to be rebuilt.) Amazing demonstration of the mortarless Incan stonework, a huge amount of Spanish religious artwork, and beautiful grounds and views with flowers everywhere. They also have modern artwork from local artists on display.

Intriguing historical site. My friend and I walked here from the PLaza Des ARmas, and it didn't take us long at all. The site is built on old Inca ruins and the architecture is old, interesting and beautiful to look at. It's a great mix of old and new.

Must do!. This is a must- see location in Cusco. But you must also do it with a guide. There is so much history and information you wouldn't pick up on otherwise. We went with a smaller group/ private guide and found it wonderful. I noticed there were some much larger groups on public tours that didn't look like such a great experience.
Inca and Spanish history met. Fantastic place to learn about the history of the area, but very crowded when visited on the city tour circuit.

Not as awesome as they make it out to be. Maybe Im not a history buff so didnt appreciate this place and didn't think it was as wonderful as the guide books make it out to be. There are some nice views looking out from the top though. Its a bit frustrating that this is not included in the boleto touristic though (though lets all just admit that the boleto is one huge tourist rip off...thanks Peru)

A great compliment to your complete Cusco things to do. Exploring Cusco can wear you out because there is lots to see and do, but we loved this stop because you could see a lot in a short amount of time. You have the Incan sun/moon temple combined with the rich Colonial architecture and history. Not to be missed is the small art museum of wonderful 16th century Spanish art (largley, there's more than just that. A great place for photo ops and for relaxing. Cool enough and small enough to keep the kids from going bonkers too.

Do not go with a tour guide. First, when paying for the entrance, be sure to check your tickets. We were given one valid ticket, and one ticket that was already ripped and dated for the previous day. Clearly the guys selling and collecting the tickets have a nice business going on, pocketing S.10 for every couple of tourists that enter! Second, if you come across a tour guide outside who is very pushy, don't go with her. We thought it would be interesting to go with a guide, but kept refusing her offers as it was really expensive. She kept lowering the price and hassling us and other tourists until she got a group together of mildly interested people, but then spent the first 5 minutes of the tour still hassling tourists to join the group. She had told us the tour would last 45 minutes but answered her phone at the beginning of the tour and we overheard her tell her friend she would meet them outside in 25 minutes, not realising we understood Spanish. When I asked her if the tour was really going to be only 25 minutes she looked pretty embarrassed. The tour she gave was terrible. She spoke really fast in English and had a strong accent so the group could barely understand her and when we asked her to repeat she was cold and looked annoyed that we hadn't understood the first time. She gave very little information and whisked us around, making us want to revisit the site without her at the end as we felt like we'd missed out on a lot. I don't know if all tour guides are as bad as her, but I would recommend just going by yourselves.
Cool Incan structure now managed by Catholic Church... More Catholic than Incan treasures here, but worth the hour and $3.50 fee to enter. Lovely courtyard and small gift shop.

Quirikancha (Sun Temple) and Santa Domingo Church melded together. Not unlike other places in the world (for example, Turkey, Morocco with churches and mosques) where existing buildings were taken over and modified per shifts in power, this attraction provides good insight into the engineering and astronomy feats of the Incas and the corresponding appropriation by the Spanish. The craftsmanship is amazing.
Amazing!. Visited as part of a Cusco tour. The beautiful church has a museum that charges 10 soles to visit. Well worth it .
Best cedar "retablo" I have ever seen.. Incredible piece of local art. The "retablo" (altar background) is carved in cedar by local artists.

Visit the museum, but do not miss the church of Santo Domingo. Very well laid out museum, with Inca temple walls displayed in a unique way. Please do not miss the church (open for mass at 6:30pm). The "retablo" (background of the altar) is an incredibly beautiful piece of art (cedar wood).
ancient machinery. Take time to visit this other amazing sight if you want to see proofs of the ancient machinery like all over in Peru.

I must - I would say!. Okey, this church isn't like all the others - when I went we walked around for a while, took pictures and imagine how it was back then. The next day we went back with a guide. I really liked that order of doing it (even though it wasn't planned or anything). Interesting and beautiful
A Most in Cusco. The Santo Domingo Church is a most in your visit to Cusco Peru, especially after Machu Picchu ......

Interesting place to learn about the Incas. There are a lot of educational aspects to Qorikancha, definitely worth it to visit. You will see how the Incas built, and carved their stones to fit into one another. It's also so interesting to see the fusion of architectures in this structure - Inca and Spanish colonial.

Amazing example of Inca building. Qoricancha is in fact a ruin of what is left of a major temple and ceremonial centre built by the Incas. The Spanish conquistadores destroyed most of it, and built the Santo Domingo Church on top of the remains. What is left is still an amazing example of the ability for building stone structure that the Incas had. Very much worth visiting. While visiting, be patient since it is always very much busy with tourists.

Not my favourite 'attraction'. The entry to this attraction is 10 soles, but personally I didn't think it is one of the must-do sights of the city. I visited it alone, without a guide. They have a series of panels with the history of the place right after the ticket counter, but what you actually see is just a few remains, and some reconstructions of the original temple. There's a lot of religious art and artefacts on display that wasn't very interesting to me.
visit and enjoy the gardens. beautiful place to visit or just to take a break since they have gardens with beautiful flowers and hummingbirds.
Beautiful old church. An amazing experience visiting this beautiful old church. The whole experience was amazing to visit this place was an awesome experience.
Exploring Cuzco by foot. Nice place I went to qorocancha and I founded many Inca temples near Cuzco centre, it is amazing the union of stones in every corner.
a must see to understand what the Spanish did to Inca Culture: destroy it. This is a sad place, ruined by the Spanish to build theur Churches. They really destroyed everything from stones to gold

Another fine example of a Colonial Church but completely dwarfed by the importance of the Incan Temple it replaced.. Another fine example of a Colonial Church but one completely dwarfed by the importance of the Incan Temple that it was built upon.

Horrible and wonderful all at the same time.. This was the true center of the Incan Empire. It is the site of most important Incan temple and was the hub from which the terrific Incan road system fanned out. It's very impressive and one can just imagine what it must have been like with the inner temples walled with gold and silver. The Spanish built a church on and around the Incan temple in a designed plan of cultural assassination.

Worth a stop, if you have a guide.... super busy later in day...sacred site of the Inca. Spaniards built a church on it. Was discovered in the 1950s after an earthquake.
Worth the price of admission

This is Qorikancha! Still great :-). Beautiful monument and well maintained but actually this should be one entry on TripAdvisor and call it Qorikancha: the Sun Temple of the Incas. Santo Domingo is just the church the Spaniards decided to build on top.... ;-)

Impressive. The Inca walls and the whole inner courtyard are special, the gardens and park outside beautifully maintained: a great monument that give many visitors the first impression of what they can expect of this city.

Beautiful, and worth an hour of your time in Cusco. This is a lovely place to tour while in Cusco. My wife and I went with a local guide (check out toursbylocals.com), who explained the architecture and the impressive stone walls that remained from the time of the Incas. The inner courtyard is beautiful. Pictures of the inside were not permitted, however.

My favorite site in Cuzco. The Qurikancha offers insight into how the Incans developed their building techniques over time. There are many places to take wonderful pictures inside and outside of the building. There are beatuiful flowers and green grass to rest and enjoy yourself in front of the building.

Get a tour guide to enjoy all of it!. It is a very beautiful temple and a very interesting mix between Spanish and Inca architecture.This place is so full of history and interesting facts that I highly recommend getting a guided tour to learn and enjoy most of it. We didn't have one and were offered a tour at the front door. It costed 40 soles for 2 people and was really worth it!

Beautiful Unexpected Stop. The gardens are beautiful and the views from the church are gorgeous. The church has nice exhibits but my favorite part was the structure itself. The indoor patios and Spanish style columns were the highlight of the church.
Research before visiting. The stone work here is amazing and must have been incredible when covered with gold. A little research beforehand helps with the enjoyment of this place.

a good combination between the inca and spanish architecture. You need to spend one or 2 hours to visit this magnificent monument. The incas started the construction of their temple on this place and the conquistadors built the catholic church on it. Interesting to discover the cloister and the pinacotheque

A tick-in-the-box visit worth 60 minutes of your time.. Nice building with some very nice examples of the Inca stonework. Unfortunately, so much Inca culture was destroyed by the Spanish conquistadores that it is quite difficult to rebuild what could give the visitor a real sense for the way the Inca culture existed and thrived. But there are some good attempts in this building and, if I understood correctly, there are plans to develop it a lot further with things they've excavated. A bit too "touristy" to my liking but well worth 45-60 minutes of your time.

Diana Tour Guide tops all others.. We picked up our local guide, Diana, at the door and she gave us a great tour which included much of the Inca and Spaniard history while walking through this place. She was also very familiar with the Inca wall construction methods that have withstood earthquakes.

Wonderful technique. I'd strongly urge you to use the services of a guide when you visit this ancient temple as there is a lot to learn and you'd be lost without their knowledge. Most of what was apparently constructed by the incas was lost when the Spanish arrived. They had in fact even covered the stone walls by plaster which only gave way during one of the earthquakes and it was only then when Qorikancha was 'discovered'. What we found the most interesting is the angles of the walls, their ability to withstand earthquakes and the technique with which these walls were built, one stone after another without using any mortar.
Worth visiting. This cathedral also is a historical museum with ruins that show how both the Incas and Spaniards lived. Very well done.
Beautiful... rich history. Make sure you hire a local guide when you go through, really helps understand the history this place truly holds. Awesome piece of history!

Best way to understand inca's astronomy. There will be a full explanation about inca's astronomy and also you'll find some Spanish art and religion. Just an amazing place to visit and is only 3 blocks from main square
Impresive fussion. It was very impressive to see an Inka temple and a Spanish cathedral fused in one structure. Definitely , a place that you must to visit.

Nice one! . Pretty good place it is good to remind that the entrance is right beside the church and not at the sun avenue,which is another Museum that only accepts entrance if you buy a entire ticket for a lots of other museums. This one is just 10 soles which is totally worth it. You can see the original old constructions from the Inca period.

Imagine the walls of stone covered in sheets of solid gold. This site gives you a clear idea of how huge was the Inca Empire. Imagine the walls of stone all covered in sheets of solid gold, sophistication and art. All that is gone now.After the conquer of Peru, some lazy spanish engineers built the Church of Santo Domingo over the Inca temple, destroying part of this Temple and using its foundations for the Cathedral. Funny thing is that every time an earthquake occurs, only the spanish construction is torn down, by the contrary the Inca construction has resisted all these earthquakes and the parts that look deteriorated is due to the robbers that took away the gold leaving just the naked stones. Obviously destroying the possibility of knowing more about the House of the Sun.

Worth the trip to see the Incan Foundations. Fascinating to see the Incan ruins under the Catholic cathedral. Check out the building blocks -- like ancient legos -- and be fascinated at what the Incans were capable of. See the artwork and how the two cultures came together.

Vacations at Cusco. Excellent and beautiful place to learn about the history of the Inca and the Spaniards interaction since the early dates. The collection of old books is impressive as well as the Saints reliques.
Neat. this was part of a city tour, I probably would have missed out on this gem otherwise. you should plan on stopping by.

A great place to get an understanding of the history and culture of Peru. A good place to really understand the overlapping of the Inca culture and the Spanish occupation. Try to go at a time that is not too busy as it is on everybody's tour list

Temple of the Sun. What was one the central temple in Cusco, a city of temples, was, like so many others, converted and subverted soon after the conquest. Here you can clearly see the Incan stone foundations outside that support the modern cathedral. Inside you can get a closer look at the stonework, the techniques used and even a scale model of the original Koricancha. A guide is recommended to explain what you're seeing, how the building and its features were used prior to their conversion and the importance of this particular location. The inside is nearly as spacious as the exterior gardens. You can easily spend over an hour to take it all in.

Qurikancha-layers of civilization. This is an amazing spot and your visit will last long after you leave the building. It's instructive on the whole of Spanish Colonization and the "fine art" of degrading a native culture. I was swept up into holy thursday services later in the week of my visit (the Cathedral) and I recommend that people try to observe a service in these amazing facilities, when they spring to life.

Do not miss Qorikancha when you visit Cusco!. This was one of the best parts of our Cusco tour. It was impressive not just for the architecture itself and the history (make sure you book a good guide who knows their stuff—we had Virgilio from South Adventure Peru Tours, and he was fantastic) but also for the art contained inside and the gardens. The collection of stonework from Incan times, particularly the stones that had previously had gold in-lay and their golden "staples" to hold the stones in place were really cool, as were the examples of their stone pipe-work and their ability to align their structures so that windows and things would line up—truly mind boggling how they did it all.To me it's a real shame that the Spaniards felt compelled to erect a huge church on top, because it would have been awesome to see it in it's full glory as what it was originally, instead of the European-style architecture work put on top. I also really enjoyed the Cusco-school paintings, with all of the tongue-in-cheek references and comedy the indigenous artists would sneak in.
Good. There are a lot of history in the place. Pretty crowded. It includes in the Day Tour. Wish to have more time to stay there to digest the info.
Over the top opulence. Love history and liked the stories of how it was built and how the Spaniards forced the Incas to "believe" in a Catholic God

Tourist Information Deficits. This is a very interesting cathedral built atop Incan temple ruins. There is some wonderful examples of Incan stonework here. But, my favorite area was the Spanish artwork in which there were several paintings which were quite different and beautiful.. Since photos were not allowed, I was hoping for a gift shop in which I could buy some reproductions in postcards or some such media. However, there is no gift shop and I never found a book in Peru that featured Qurikancha. I was hoping for one at an airport, but, alas, no luck. I think that my visit would have been enhanced by hiring a tour guide but was not aware of this need until after I had the spent a Sunday afternoon here and was tired. Friends were misled by someone in Cusco who told them this museum was not open on Sunday and, then, when they spotted lines to get in, they realized they had been given wrong information. So, my biggest criticism is that there is not good information available to the tourist about this museum and, therefore, one can miss much about this attraction.

Le Temple du Soleil. If you read the famous belgian comics, this place has the same name as the one Tintin goes to. It is impressive and you can see that the Spanish people tried to force the Inca to their religion by building their new churches on top of the existing temples.

Good. The comparison between the Incan and Spanish past are excellent and clear here. Worth the time. I went with a guide -- and I think that's a must at this place -- otherwise, it's just a lot of rocks.

Museum to the Sun God. This property preserves Incan architecture and allows for a closer inspection. We hired a local to be our guide. His English was good and he was very well versed in the history of the property as well as the Peruvian/Incan culture. From the road I didn't realize the topiaries were shaped as a puma. Beautiful gardens and artwork as well. We toured late in the day and felt a little hurried. However, it was nice to be in downtown Cusco and able to meander around.
Lovely building and huge doors. I couldn't get enough of all of the large old doors all over the Church and other buildings. They have pride and keep everything neat and clean. Good people.
Interesting!. We enjoyed our architectural tour. We were impressed with the extremely precise and detailed construction. Mindboggling. If we could recapture the skills of those engineering feats...

Worth a visit. There is a museum on Avenida El Sol that is worth a visit too. Qurikancha seems historical from outside but loses that as you enter. Lots of glass and cordoned off sections. Both the museum and the Qurikancha are interesting. However, it can't compare to the ruins that you can visit at Sacsayhuaman or Ollantaytambo which are similar in construction.
Don't miss the art exhibits upstairs. On the second floor there are art exhibits, that are also really interesting. Don't forget to climb the stairs and check them out, too.

A memorable attraction in Cusco. A wonder architechture dedicated to Sun God by Inka King - in Cusco. What an amazing set of buildings - unknown in the 12-15 centuries. The techniques applied to build this wonder temple is unimaginable. The structure is preserved very well in spite of the damages done by Spanish invaders- thanks to the Peruvian Government and UNESCO!
Must see. Amazing building that was built on the Inca foundations when the Spanish conquered the city and tore everything that was Incan down. Amazing joining of two cultures.
A little disappointing. Of the many sights we saw on our trip I feel like this one was a little disappointing. Seemed a bit plain compared to many of the other incan sites.
Interesting historical church. This church has an interesting history and an extensive art collection. The church was built on an Incan site, and some of the Incan structure can still be seen.
Online photos just as good. Interesting to see but I would not put high on you must visit list unless you are into mystics. think of it as a funeral parlors prep room
Must see!. The best place to see the architectural combination between the remnants of The Temple of the Sun (inca period) with the built-on-top Church of Santo Domingo.
just look from the outside. overdone ruin in town. repeating the same info you hear everywhere else. at least its cheap and something to do in town. better to head out to Sacred Valley
Amazing. A must-see when in Cusco. The way the Church and Inca ruins blend in together is fascinating. Well worth the admission fee. The Church next door is lovely too

Nice church and great remnants of original Inca buildings. The museum is very interesting with some original walls and rooms from the Inca period. We didn't have a chance to visit the Cathedral but looked in and it was quite impressive.

Huge attraction. The outside of the sun temple is huge and invites travelers to come check out what is inside. Make sure you book some type of tour so you know what you're viewing. I was really impressed with the amount of artwork that is in the center square. This is a beautiful temple and stunning grounds.

The Introduction . Qurikancha, in Cusco, is an ideal introduction to the ancient Incan civilization. Spending time in this area provides a primer of many examples of the Incan civilization. The exactness of the stonework, the engineering evidenced by the structures combined with the realization of the era creates nothing short of amazement. This is a tour that is best completed with a guide as there is much to learn.
Frescos also amazing. Very interesting as the lower part of the building is still Inca walls and then modern building over it .
Highy hyped. The same can be skipped if you are on a short duration since if you see any of the central down town area they all look the same

A Convent Atop the Sun Temple. This is the former Temple of the Sun which was purportedly the most beautiful and sacred temple in the Incan empire. It contained many gold objects and was covered in gold plates . The Spaniards destroyed the temple, stripped its gold and constructed the Convent of Santo Domingo on its foundation. One can see and appreciate the beautifully fitted Inca stones at the base of the Convent (best done from the Av. el Sol). One can only marvel at their workmanship and engineering. In the Convent, you can see several of the original temple rooms -- they are so precise and beautifully crafted that one might think they were modern. It is a shame that only a few pieces of this temple remain. Admission fee of S/. 10 --- the Boleto is not valid.

nice to see from outside. We had the chance to see Qurikancha as the first impression of Cusco when we arrived from the airport. It's really a nice view from outside and you see always a lot of tourist around this area. as you have to pay an entrance and we had less time, I'm not able to comment it from inside.

History alive!. This really is an amazing site, as is just about everything in Incan Peru. We had Fred from Condor Travel as our guide and he was an overflowing font of information about all of the sites. As an archaeology student, he really made everything come alive for us! I highly recommend hiring a guide, and get Fred if you can!
Too busy. I would have liked this better had it not been so over crowded. It was hard to see or get to anything.

Nice Site. This was a nice site to see and had some really interesting elements that showcased the Inca civilization as well as the Spanish history that influenced so much of what you see in present day Peru. I would give yourself about an hour to see Qurikancha and would recommend touring with a guide. Edwin showed us around Cusco during a walking tour and provided quite a bit of great detail on the site and the city itself. I think we definitely got a lot out of having a guide that showed us around. My recommendation would be to go mid-morning or early-morning. It seemed like many schools were visiting the sites of Cusco frequently in the morning, so try and get there either before a lot of the school children do or slightly after. While the afternoon would be great, things tend to clear up in the afternoon and you can get some beautiful photos of the outdoor sites, so spend your morning inside here when the skies are still a little grey.

Amazing Building of the Inkas. Its not possible to see the whole construction anyomore cause over the sun temple was built st. Dominic church but you get an excellent idea about how Inkas could achieve such a great buildings
Great introduction. A great introduction to Inca architecture and ritual sites. And easy to get to and not a hard walk while you get used to the Cusco elevation.
Worth the Visit. This place has beautiful scenery, lots to see, and you can interact with locals to shop and hear their stories.

Beautiful Church and Inca Remnants. It is a beautify church and a beautiful courtyard. However the most impressive is the Inca stone foundation and the original Inca buildings inside the church. Beautiful stone masonary showoff the Inca art to perfection. Wish could spend more time there.

Another Cusco history treasure. I really enjoyed a guided tour of this church to learn about the stonework and history. I was particularly fascinated by some of the beautiful doors, architecture and art. We had a tour guide arranged through Go To Peru travel agency in Cusco. They are very helpful!

A lot to see and learn!. There's a lot to see and learn about the Spanish and the incas meeting each other and how they dealt with one another if you really want to learn more in detail I would recommend a guide!

A Franciscan monastery built around later discovered Inca walls. A Franciscan monastery built around later discovered Inca walls so there are a few sections of walls within an otherwise standard looking monastery. Impressive walls perhaps but not so much in this setting. Interesting in that its a good example of how one culture or religion uses and converts their predecessors buildings. 10 soles pp entry made more worthwhile by some decent Spanish colonial art in gallery.
A visit to Santo Domingo Church - Cusco. The Catholic Church was built on top an ancient Inca temple. The Inca ruins can be seen beneath the newer Catholic Church. A beautiful site and church.

Nice mix of church, art, and history. Costs 5 soles for students, 10 soles for others. There is lots of information about the history of Cusco inside, which was cool! There is also beautiful art on the walls inside, and the center of the church makes for a great picture. There are guides standing outside for you to hire, but they are not necessary as everything is clearly explained in the church itself. Good place to spend an hour if you are looking for somewhere to go.

Exquisite stonework. This was probably the highest quality stonework of all the Inca and pre-Inca sites we visited, with the possible exception of Sacsyhuaman. It is well worth visiting in order to understand Inca construction techniques. The site is a fusion of Inca and Spanish colonial culture. I would definitely recommend hiring a guide--you can tell the guide how much time you want to spend and negotiate a price--you will gain a much better understanding if you do this.
Go with a quide. I'm not that interested in churches in general, but a good quide will have many good stories to tell about this church and its paintings.

Worth visit, if you have time. We visited this during a city tour. It was a good experience, but less impressive thatn Inka ruins that we saw later. Nice place to visit if you have some extra time in Cusco city.

Mind Boggling. What the Spanish missed! Our tour guide, none other than Romulo Lizarraga Valencia, coauthor of Joirney to Machu Picchu, gave us phenomenal insight to the lives of the Quechuan and Incan people and the detrimental influence of the Spanish conquistadors and church. I found it fascinating and mind boggling and well worth the time and money!

Amazing Temple. Truly an amazing tour. It's a bit sad to see amazing ancient structures the Inca had just to be modified and taken over conquistadors from across the world. A worshiping building for the Inca turned into a Catholic Church.

Interesting To Visit. We meant to go here first but ended up at an underground museum on the Av El Sol. After our detour museum we popped into the Temple of the Sun. It's only 10 sole for adults and 5 for students, so very cheap. We did not get a guide since we only wanted to look around (but having one would be a good idea - not a lot of signage) The museum is a combination of Inka ruins and European paintings (including pictures from the Cusco school) and European religious clothing. Great views and benches to sit on and people watch.
Thankfully some of it is still standing. The highest standard of masonry imaginable. The perfection of the stonework is unbelievable. Truly worth the visit to the Convent of Santo Domingo.

Get the Guide!. We visited this site and opted for a self guided tour.. what a mistake! Although still a beautiful site to walk around, there were countless groups taking in so much information from their guides, and we were walking around aimlessly. Definitely worth a visit in Cusco before seeing the other ruins in the Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu

Hillside Splendor!. Sitting on a hill overlooking the central part of the city, this majestic church provides a glimpse of the incredible Inca stonework. A tour through the building is best done with a guide since there are many facets of the history and construction that are easily missed without one. Plan to spend about an hour to take in the wonder of this facility.

An open Time Capsule. On the outside, you can see how the different civilizations who ruled the area build on the the previous civilizations. Each with distinctive material, design and skills. It's one wall but you know the same people didn't build the whole thing. Once inside, you continue to see how the Spanish incorporated what the Incas had previously built. Plaster covers some ancient rock but also new architectural feathers like arches and domes cover the old Inca ruins.All very interesting.

Interesting . This is a good place to learn about the Inca empire and their culture. Especially about their advanced building methods which are incredible given what tools they could possibly have had at that time. We went as part of a city tour but sometimes it was difficult to hear our guide due to so many other tours there at the same time. I would recommend a private tour if you really want to learn and hear everything about this awesome temple.

Right in the middle of town. This is a beautiful combination of inca ruins and Colonial Church architecture. it really shows how the Catholic church would build churches over Incan sites, even using some of the Incan stones for the church buildings. The Incan ruins are not that comprehensive but it is interesting to see how they blend with the church. it really is a beautiful place.
Pity the Spanish put a church on top of Temple. Coricancha should have been what it say's a Temple still what was put on top of the Temple is also impressive to watch.

The Sun and the Earth. For the Incas and mortals alike, one feels the connection of the Sun and the Earth, the main source of life itself. Nothing much has changed the spiritual side of things there. The descendants of the llamas still roam free.

Beautiful Temple. A must see when in Cusco...We had a private guide Hubert with Adios Adventure Travel.Highly recommend having a guide bring your through the Temples and ruins - they have so much priceless knowledge of the history of the area.

Architecture at it's Finest. Just like the Santo Domingo church you will be amazed at the stone work outside and inside the Temple of the Sun. Inside they offer a smaller scale schematic of what the area and buildings used to look like and how they were set up. Once again, a can't miss Incan site.

Incredible Architecture. As you approach the massive stone work you will be awed at the Incan ability to construct and build these structures with no bonding agent. Having a guide to truly explain things is certainly worth it. Really nice garden area as well.

I'd been to Cusco many times, but never into Qoricancha. My loss! Once you get past the desecration of a phenomenal Inca religious site (and the reported stripping of incalculable amounts of gold) and ignore the christian edifice built up and over the Inca temple, the masonry of the surviving Inca architecture is quite simply the most beautiful and precise I've seen anywhere. Little wonder: This was the central temple of the Inca empire, and they appear to have spared no expense or technical expertise in its execution.This site is included in the full-coverage Boleto Turistico. Try to ignore the mess the Dominicans made of the place when they built a two-story chapter house on the west side of the north court-yard (the only one currently open to the public). And be prepared to be blown away by the beauty of the stone-work in the surviving Inca structures. Largely beyond description (for me, at least).

Worth the visit for knowledge on the Inca architecture. Enjoyed hearing about how the Inca and Spanish architecture and it is very important to have a tour guide explain the difference. It was impressive how they built for earthquakes. Good place to visit....

Lovely gardens and lots of history. We began our trip with a tour of Coricancha and what we loved is how beautifully the site reflects the clashes of the Inca and Spanish cultures. We especially loved the calendar room, the beautiful gardens and the carved stone walls of the Incans with the Spanish stone walls above. This is a wonderful way to begin an understanding of the history of Cusco.

Finest Inca or pre-Inca megalithic architecture (who really knows?). A must-see in the city centre a short walk downhill from the main plaza. Shows how the Spanish physically imposed thier architecture on top of the existing constructions. The centre of the Incan universe so to speak.
Finest Inca or pre-Inca (who really knows?) megalithic architecture.. A must see in the city centre a short walk downhill from the main plaza. Entry currently 10 soles per person.
Actually Qurikanacha. Beautiful temple with a great story - a must see. Kind of sad, just more examples of the painful arrogance of Spanish colonialism.

Rich With History. Loved the idea of being in the Incan culture. I believe there needs to be more explanations and not have to rely on a guide to explain everything to you. It's important to allow a tourist to feel empowered.

Fascinating insight into the Inca world. This place really emphasises how much was lost when the Inca people were invaded all those years ago. Walking around you can see how Spanish Colonial buildings were put up in place of Inca Temples and the difference in architecture and building techniques, the Inca's superior, earthquake proof, stonework, which needed no mortar, is real artwork when compared to the more traditional stone and mortar of the Spanish style. Good presentation of what it used to look like.

Don't miss this.. This is an imposing site.It's easy to reach, one of the "must-visits" in the area.Much history offered, both from the Inca and conquistador side.Certainly should be on every list when visiting Cusco.

Past and present collides well. Have a guide along with you to explain how this once an Inca temple has now encompassed so much history in it and how the Spanish colonization got it converted to the modern church that stands above it. The place has lots of background stories to it and requires a learned assistance to help you enjoy. It is not that you can’t visit the place without a guide. You certainly can but you will miss out on the history and relevance of the place. Maybe a little bit of reading beforehand will solve the problem too.

Definitely worth a visit. The main interest for me in touring the Santo Domingo Church is to view the comparison between Spanish and Incan stonework. (Hint: The Incan stonework is much better.) I often shy away from tours, but here it is good to have a tour guide knowledgeable about architectural history.

Good. If one is in Cusco, they should visit Coricancha. It was 10 soles or $3.5 USD per person. It's an interesting site/museum. I think to get a better experience I'd recommend hiring a guide. There was no audio-guides available like some of the other sites in the city. My wife and I didn't hire a guide and kind of wish we did, after the fact.

Ah, Folks, We Missed It by 475 Years. I'm intrigued by the gist of almost all reviewers comments( some had "guides"--Lord knows what their training and qualifications were--some did, but I'm left with very strong suspicion that the majority of visitors left not knowing what they missed. A few things I noted: (A) "guides" pointed to and talked about what was there almost exclusively, NOT what was missing; (B) whether with your groups or not, visitors almost all circled around the periphery of the courtyard without taking much or even ANY time to view; (C) the large placards providing information are remarkably coy about what used to be there, and suggest that the stories were probably exaggerated, and even mention mythic legends about long-lost buried Inca treasure. There really isn't must serious historic controversy about what was in Coricancha or about what happened to it. I'm not a tour guide, but I would like to lay out a few things about that central courtyard, for the benefit of future TripAdvisor readers headed that way Here goes:Coricancha is Quechua for Golden Enclosure. Six buildings enclosed the Inti Pampa (Quechua: Field of Gold). They were temples to the Sun, Moon, Stars, Lightning, and the Rainbow, plus ceremonial quarters for the priests of the Sun. The current surviving ruins do surround the courtyard, which does have a fountain in its center, making it a likely candidate to have been the Inki Pampa. The Dominican monastery was built on top of the Sun Temple, but various archaeologists may have competing theories. The buildings surrounding the Inki Pampa were gold- plated--not gold leaf, but gold plate, each sheet weighing several pounds (I.e. that now-naked stone wall your tour guide is pointing out).But the really mind-boggling thing was the Inka Pampa itself, the "Field of Gold." Here's what the conquistadores found there when they took the city: a field of grass surrounding the fountain, which was broken up here and there where holes in the earth were poked to permit planting of rows of maize, which were now ripe for the harvest. Llamas were grazing on the grass, under the watchful eyes of Inca shepherds. EXCEPT all of this was beautifully crafted out of gold.. The dirt was gold; the grass and corn silk was finely spun gold wire. Everything was so masterfully done that it looked real. The centerpiece of the fountain was a golden figure of the sun, given by Pizarro to one of his captains as his share of the loot. However the nouveau riche conquistador got drunk and lost it gambling that very night, resulting in an old Spanish expression for a spendthrift, "to lose the sun before the dawn." Pedro de Cieza de Leon, who 12 years later spoke to many Spaniards who had seen the Inka Pampa, wrote of "the garden where clods were pieces of fine gold" as well as the "cornfields ... The stems of the leaves and the cobs. Beside this they had more than twenty llamas of gold with their young, with the shepherds life-sized with their slings and crooks to watch them ... all made of gold." Nor are these tall tales, because accompanying the expedition at the time was the King's fiscal representative, who kept careful records of the valuables that Pizarro and his men seized (to ensure Carlos V got his Royal Fifth.) This inspector, Miguel de Estete, recorded officially that he saw "straws made of solid gold, with their spikes just as they grow in the field, and if I was to record all the different varieties in the shape of gold my story would never end." Elsewhere Estete records of one haul, "Four llamas in fine gold and very large, ten or twelve figures of women, natural size, all of fine gold and so beautiful and well made it seemed as if they were alive."For the most part, as per royal orders, these extraordinary masterpieces of the goldsmith's are were melted down into ingots, as were the silver masterpieces. However, some of the works were so extraordinary beautiful that even the crude conquistadores (most of them, like Pizarro, could neither read nor write) couldn't bring themselves to destroy them, and shipped those supreme examples of Inca art to the Spanish court as they were. Needless to say, Carlos V was livid on hearing of this, and issued an edict (13 Feb 1535) that if any such cargo was received "all gold and silver from Peru shall be melted in the royal mints at Seville, Toledo and Segovia." Not a single piece shipped to Spain survives. I'm submitting a photo of the courtyard to TA. It's not a BAD courtyard surrounded by bare stone Inca rooms, But compared to what the Inki Pampa WAS, it's rather like going to some some dusty anthropology museum and seeing a 500-year-old female human skeleton that used to belong to Amerigo Vespucci's sister-in-law Simonetta. Not a BAD skeleton, but about the same time Spanish functionaries were melting the Field of Gold into ingots, leaving what you see in the Coricancha courtyard now, (and Amerigo was making a name for himself in the --er-- Americas),Simonetta was posing for Sandro Botticelli's Birth of Venus. The loss of her beauty was naturally inevitable; the loss of The Golden Enclosure, however, was not. But standing in that courtyard now can be a richer, if sadder, experience if you try to visualize the way it looked the day before the Spaniards arrived.
Temple of the Sun. Great museum and a must for visitors we had a guide from Lima Tours who was fab?If you are an inca fan then the history here is key
Very good. It´s a very good place to visit. The bad thing is that you must pay another ticket to visit it. It´s not included with the ticket that you buy to visit every attraction in Cusco.

Beautiful. It´s a very go od place to visit. The bad thing is that the ticket you pay it´s only for a half of it. If you want to see everything you must pay another ticket to get into the Santo Domingo Seminar.
Great site. Needed more time. The tour was too fast. The visuals were great but I needed more time to take it all in and I would have loved more history from my guide.
Must have seen. The rests of the different temples inside the monastery that was built over it are really impressive. Also you learn about the Inka world what they thought and so on

Inca History. This is the perfect place to see the amazing craftsmanship of the Incas. There are beautiful examples of their stone carving skills. Add to this beautiful colonial artwork and you have a special day going back in time.

Glimpse back in time. Lots of tourists and tour groups since it's right in the center of town, but it provides a good intro and overview into Inca heritage and stone work. Be sure to go outside to check out the views.
Interesting. Worth stopping by if you have time in Cusco. It's an interesting place to wander through, which we did without a guide, and managed to get the gist.

Beautiful...with a little sadness. We went with a tour guide who is very knowledgeable about the history of Incans vs. Spaniards and how the churches came to be be built on top of Incan sun temples. The church itself is magnificent and beautiful indeed but can't help but feel sad for the Incans whose civilization was ruthlessly decimated. Some parts of the original sun temple remain and you can see how the lego-like blocks and construction were perfectly cut and aligned using only stone tools. Had I not known better I would've thought these Incan temple walls are new construction built in modern age. For those interested in history and architecture this is a must-do.
Interesting. It was amazing to see the Incan structure with the Spanish colonial built on top of it. The painting were amazing and the courtyard was beautiful.

Part of the Inca City Tour. As titled, we visited this attraction as part of our city tour. This was the Temple of the Sun converted during the Spanish Colonization into a Church. Our guide focused on the Inca remains inside the attraction so we saw the engineering the Incas used to construct their temples and their houses. And I realized that the Incas knew lego blocks before we all even played with one. Very fascinating as to how something so simple a concept in masonry could build strong building that still continues to exist (partly or fully) thousands of years later.
Stunning. The church features more gold than most jewelry stores with altars everywhere and figures clad in finery to dazzle the senses.

Beautiful example of old Spanish church build on old Inca temple. beautiful, the best views are from the outside! there you can really appreciate the Inca and Spanish culture together. Inside is nothing to write home about, so you loose the real mystic There is a school playground or park at the base that offers an interesting view of Cuzco life.

Quick tour inside the main courtyard to see Inca architecture. A quick tour inside the courtyard will provide a upclose impressive view of the Inca architecture/stone work. The high-precision Lego-like construction was reserved for temples and the work here is impressive (and unexplained by scientists). Most other Incan architecture (e.g. most of Machu Picchu) is not constructed with this level of mortar-less precision.

Amazing remnants of a great Temple.. The site was across the street from my hotel, it is very centrally located, and is amazing the masonry of the place. Inside the location, it is possible to see what was the temple and what the Monastery and Church, is today on top of it. Must be seen, with a guide.
Very instructive in early Inca culture. Great grounds and tour guides available within walking distance in center of Cusco. Mixture of current Catholic use and life of the Incas.
beautiful. beautiful, but the best views are from the outside!, there you can really appreciate the inca and spanish culture bend together. The inside is "touristic", so you loose the real mystic

Picturesque. This Temple is beautiful. There are so many beautiful places that you could spend hours here taking photos and admiring the interior. The outside is also attractive and if you're lucky you'll get to listen to the humming bird while you're leaning on the wall overlooking the grassed area.

Tougher than I thought. My partner and I decided to visit Machu Picchu this year. At mid 60's we did not want to leave it too long. So with Tauck tours we climbed Temple of the Sun. Shortness of breath is an interesting sensation when you think you are fit. Both of us exercise regularly, despite it we both noted the lower oxygen concentration. We loved the amazing stone crafting of the Incas. The Inca was the ruling class so we will never know who the artisans were. I offer credit to these forgotten workers. It is dramatic and exciting despite the shortness of breath and the other specific and non-specific symptoms of Acute Mountain Sickness.

Fascinating to see while in Cusco. Visited here as part of a private tour with 5 other friends. Our guide's great explanation of the Inca building methods and the purposes of each of the Inca rooms brought the place to life. Without a guide of some kind I don't think you would get much out walking through without explanation.
Huffing & Puffing.. 250 steps at a 3800 meters altitude.View is spectacular.Made a few stops before reaching the top. Coming down is a little easier. Not much to see at the Temple of the Water.

A lovely church built on an ancient temple. The Spaniards used the superb Inca foundations to build their own structures. Here one sees the 17th century Santo Domingo Monastery built on one of the most important Inca temples.

This site was not of great interest to me! Tired and needing some oxygen.. When we got to the Temple of the Sun I was not really ready to take on any more input about the Incas and their history. I was tired and needed to take a break so I did just that. I sat down in the hallway and just took it all in. What a relief that was. This is the kind of place that should be looked at with a lot of energy and enthusiasm. I didn't have that feeling and I was glad when we left and went on to our next stop. Take a look at this place and make up your own mind about it. Altitude and a lack of appetite might explain my indifference.

Breathtaking. This church holds so much history and culture. It's a must to visit.I would suggest visiting this church with a tour guide that knows what they are talking about. I recommend FRED with Condor Travel

Lovely but busy. I can't say our tour gave justice to this Temple as the crowds visiting the day we were there made it a very rushed tour. The artwork is lovely and a longer tour I am sure would have revealed much more of what we only glimpsed.
Santa Domingo. Gorgeous inside and out. Take this tour! It will be a very enlightening and spiritual journey. And if not, well it's full of fantastic views and history to boot!

Beautiful Temple. This temple exemplifies some of the best architecture of the Incans. People who say this is nothing special simply do not understand it's significance to the city of Cusco. There is a lot of history here and the beautiful Temple is open and airy. Surrounded by a lovely Garden. If this is a trip that looks to be boring to you, I would suggest taking a guide of sorts to help you understand the meaning behind all of it.I would tag this place as a place of high spirituality, history, architecture and theology.
Do not miss - take the tour. The tour inside this church will give you a good idea of what the spanish did with the inca culture when they arrived. Great mix of old & new.

Fascinating mix of cultures. An imposing and iconic building that houses a colonial church, perched atop some original Incan ruins.It was fascinating to learn about the skill and techniques of the Incan craftsmen, ahead of our trip to Machu Picchu.It was also very interesting to hear about the history and to see first hand how ahead of their time the Incan craftsmen were (the original colonial buildings were destroyed in an earthquake whilst the Incan foundations remained).
Nothing special. well, I do not think it is a must in Cuzco if you have been to sacred valley or Satchuymann. It is in the city centre and easy to access though.

A beautiful, and spiritual experience.. If you are in Cusco, make sure this is part of your itinerary. Take the tour and take an experience guide with you (Trust Cusco-Native Travel Agency). This church was built by the Spaniards on top of the Inca's building. You can see and feel the influence from both cultures. Classic and beautiful. An ancient cathedral with lots of history. Take the time!
Well worth touring. Very enjoyable place to visit, the inside is amazing. Make a point to go inside and take the tour, not just enjoy the facade outside.

Beautiful & Plenty to learn/look at. It was a pleasure to walk the grounds, learn of the history and appreciate the architecture. The tours are great if you get one but simply walking around is also stunning.

Temple of the Sun trip. We love all the ruins and our guide gave us great history about the Temple of the Sun. I had read about it but nothing compare with seeing it in person. I like you can get right in the middle and see everything.

Amazing view of the three valleys. The temple sight is very impressive. They built the temple into a valley for strategic purposes. The views from the top are amazing. Give yourself two hours to fully appreciate the sight.
A must see. A very important site for any visitor to understand the blending of the cultures. More is being discovered all the time and there are excellent guides to show it.

Fascinating site. This stupendous site is fascinating and sad all at once. The imagination can just fly trying to imagine what it was like in the time of the Inca. The precision of construction and beauty of the stones is something that has to be seen to even start to appreciate it.

Iconic building that reflects the superimposition of one culture upon another. Qorikancha (the official name as reflected on the entry ticket) which means "courtyard of gold" in Quechua, was the site of a series of Inca temples with the primary one being the Temple of the Sun, at one time its walls were covered with gold sheets. It was also the site of the main astronomical observatory of the Incas as well as being the centre of the Cusco Seque System that defined the social organisation of the Inca empire. Following the Spanish colonization, the Inca temples were destroyed and upon its foundation a baroque Dominican Convent of Santo Domingo was built. On-site, the main attraction is the fine masonry of the Inca seen from the outside as a 6m high curved stone wall that formed the western foundation of the convent. Inside, four original chambers of the Inca temples have been uncovered, showing the perfectly fitted stone masonry and the niches typical of Inca buildings. Information on the Cusco Seque System and the Milky Way in Inca Atronomy is also provided. The courtyard, cloisters and the bell tower of the Santo Domingo Convent also contribute to a picturesque scenery, as one takes in at this one site the superimposition of one culture upon another.

WOW. Here you will see how the Spanish could take over and build their churches over exsisting sacred places. You can also see how the Incas had earthquack proofed their buildings long before we even thought of it. Thousands of years and because of their construction they still stand ! Great displays and history leason.

Beautiful gardens and views. I found this place to be beautiful on the "outside". I enjoyed the gardens and the views of Cusco from the gardens. Which you can see from the outside without needing to go in. The inside is "okay". The courtyard was beautiful. The walls were pretty cool because the stones fitted together perfectly, however, you see this everywhere in Cusco, Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu,I only went here because it was provided in my Cusco City Tour. I wouldn't pay extra to go.

Bored. I thought find something more spectacular but it was bored. It does not mean this place is bad, but I would not have paid for a bad museum like this one. The best part is the large court located at El Sol avenue which is for free.

Inspiring - rich in history. Really enjoyed visiting Qorikancha. There were excellent descriptions of Inca history and the Spanish conquest, and vivid exhibits of Inca art and stonework. Plus the gardens are gorgeous too.It's maybe a little dry for some, but I thought it was great for a couple of hours. I went away a lot more knowledgeable and excited for my Inca Trail trek.You can read more Cuzco travel tips on our blog, here: https://ednaventures.wordpress.com/2014/12/09/cuzco-a-beautiful-countdown/
incredible stonework. worth a visit to see the amazing wall-building of the Incas; also to stand at the "centre of the earth" - ask about it!

If Cusco was the center then Coricancha is the epicenter. Impressive site that clearly shows how the Spanish grafted their settlement onto the Incan ruins. Don't miss the famous Peruvian "Last Supper" painting in the art gallery, with the cuy as the centerpiece. We spent about 90 minutes here but that felt a little drawn out; an hour is sufficient to have a good look around and learn about Incan building techniques as well as the history of Cusco.

beautiful, worth a short visit. The qoricancha is a unique structure - a spanish baroque styled church built on the site of an ancient inca structure. a giant lawn on the front aspect, with a winding road by the side that leads to the convent and church. the interiors are decked up with impressive artwork. the structure is beautifully illuminated at night. worth a visit.

Great visit. We still talk about the IncaMural we saw here, and the idea that incas looked not at the stars, but at the black space between them. This amongst fascinating ruins and wonderful artefacts- a trip here is well worth while.
