A nice place to visit.. Good history, good architecture displays and Dali´s works on Dante´s Inferno are currently on display until some time in May. Make sure you walk outside and visit the gardens and other nooks and crannies.

Interesting ruins worth a short vist. Typical tour stop when seeing Cusco. Worth a stop and a listen to what the tour leader says. More interesting from a distance. Part of an overall monuments ticket so give it a few minutes

Inca Stone Work. Compact and well explained. You can see the fact of irony that the church building Spaniards built on top the Inca Temple were totally destroyed by the big earthquake, but the Inca foundation withstood the earthquake. There was an art exhibition on the 2nd floor (separate admission).

My Favorite Church on the City Tour. I really enjoyed walking around this church. Much of the Inca influence was destroyed when the conquistadors conquered the land, but you can see a bit of the history along with where the Catholic influence was introduced.

Impressive and Beautiful. beautiful! The ruins are kept nicely both inside and outside. The inside posses very detailed carvings and art work. Outside to one side is a park and to the other side is a lovely walkway with a stone design. The walkway leads to the convent behind the church. a tour Guide is suggested to get details of its significance and location. loved going underground, too. The museum if also beneficial!

Worth Going to the Top. Had to take all the steps to the top to reach the Temple of the Sun, but the view was great. The Stones in the Temple of the Sun were different from the others, it's worth going up to take a look!

Don't miss this "Palace- Cathedral". This impresses me as a symbol the Inca culture rising to reclaim its place by engulfing a Spanish cathedral. They rebuilt some of a massive Inka Palace within and outside of an equally amazing cathedral and museum. I hope they will complete the reconstruction connecting the temple with Pachachutec's residence.

Don't miss it!. Amazing Cathedral with the ruins of the previous Inca palace of Pachacutec rebuilt inside and outside. The model of the previous palace was meager and needs improvement and proper orientation.

Symbolic of the Spanish Impact. This site is typical of the Spanish impact where they destroyed much of the Incan society and forced their own. What is really cool is to see the merging of those two societies in modern day Peru. This site can be very crowded so pick a time when there is less visitation to truly enjoy this.

Go when it's raining. Coricancha features interesting examples of Inca stonework. Certainly it's impressive but you can see similar examples in Cuzco for free just by walking around San Blas and other places. Because Coricancha is under protective roofing it's a nice place to go if the weather turns ugly, which it often does. I'm glad we saw this before we went to Machu Picchu and some of the other bigger sites because Coricancha is smaller and suffers a bit in comparison. Nothing wrong with it - it just doesn't have the grandeur of some of the other, larger Inca sites.

Go with a tour. Avoid the museum at all costs.. By going with a tour (FWT or any other), you'll take advantage of this nice historical spot. The museum is an embarrassment - can't believe they charge you the same as any other Cusco highlight. If you don't have the full ticket, skip it.

Cuzco's best site. It's definitely the best site within Cuzco centre. Entrance fee is 10 soles and not included in the 10 day tourist pass. It is a temple complex dedicated to the sun god, Inti.... The history and charm of the temple make it a MUST SEE in Cuzco.

Cool. This place was beautiful! I walked past it on my way to the post office one day and I didn't have my guidebooks so I sat on a bench to appreciate it for a while and then kept walking. Then the next day, my "City Tour" included a stop here. The ruins are kept nicely and the inside is just gorgeous. Check it out!

Qoricancha is beautiful. Santo Domingo is Qoricancha. I'm not sure why TripAdvisor has them listed separately. Please check out my other review for Qoricancha. Or better yet, just go in person to see this amazing place for yourself. :)

Beautiful. Qoricancaha or Coricancha is beautiful - inside and out. The inside has very detailed carvings and art work. Outside to one side is a park (Piedra 12 Angulos) and to the other side is a lovely walkway with a stone design. The walkway leads to the convent behind the church. We were lucky enough to be at Qoricancha on a Sunday and attended a good portion of their Sunday service.

Explored the Coricancha Temple. This beautiful Cathedral was worth visiting with a Tour Guide as she explained so much about the details of its significance and location. The outside and inside are magnificent! We loved going underground, too. The museum if also beneficial!
Really like it. This was the best sight according to me. Really nice history. We took a guide which I can recommend (about 30 soles) who told us a lot about the sight.

Great construction. It's amazing how the incas made this place to withstand seismic movement. Even though after the conquistadors built a church over the Coricancha after the earthquake in the 17 or 18 century I don't really remember the church fell apart and was rebuilt completely as for the inca ruin nothing happened to them. For about 20 soles you can get a guide to explain the way the incas knew about the sun orientation and the equinox and solstice. The rocks are marked with this information it's truly amazing.

A worthy place to explore. The cost of admission was reasonable. We explored upstairs and downstairs on our own. It was very interesting. There are restrictions on camera use in some areas. A temporary display of Salvador Dali Dante paintings were there which proved quite interetes and typical Dali.

Well worth a visit - and get a guide. Coricancha is yet another example of how the small city of Cusco is filled to the brim with unique experiences. As we approached the temple, we were accosted by many potential guides. I was skeptical at first, but we ended up hiring the one who seemed the least shady. His name was Adolfo and he ended up being the best part of the visit. I would recommend hiring a guide if you can find one you feel comfortable with.Adolfo did a terrific job of explaining the history and development of the site (and even brought his own book with diagrams and examples), but the star of Coricancha is the architecture itself. The Incan construction methods have stood the test of time. It's hard to imagine how anyone could hand-cut rocks to fit so perfectly together at any time, let alone at the time of the temple's construction. All of the colonial work built on top crumbled in subsequent earthquakes...so I guess there's a metaphor in there somewhere.Scattered throughout the complex are various calendars and celestial markings, in which shadows perfectly align to mark the solstices and other important dates.While Coricancha is no longer bathed in gold as in the time of the conquistadors, the design, history and wonder of this site made it one of the best places to visit in Cusco.

History everywhere. This temple its amazing, no picture or good story can describe all the history between their walls, the Inca perfection i like to called, every wall, stone, paint, contains lots of history, the view and the amazing structure made this a mandatory stop if you are in Cuzco.Schedule:Monday to Saturday: 08:30 a 17:30 hrs - |Sunday: 14:00 a 17:00 hrs.
Have seen pictures in National Geographic but was blown away by it's beauty.. Photo will never give this site justice. You have to see it to believe how perfect the construction was. Simply amazing.
amazing. Thank goodness that not everything Inca, was destroyed. Although little is left, what has been preserved is amazing.
you must see it. on the inca ruins.. ruins to see kept and shown in excellent conditions..unlucky it is not included in the "boleto turistico".

So Sacred. There are so many historic places here in Cusco. Some outstanding archialogical sights here. Huge Basalt rocks in this region,amazing sights looking down to Cusco township. Well worth a visit
Interesting!. I enjoyed this spot. I learned a lot of the history of Cusco and it was an interesting place to explore. Definitely worthwhile.

The tour guide makes the site a worthwhile visit.. I actually visited this after seeing Machu Picchu and still found it to be quite interesting. I went alone and paid for a guided tour (only 20 soles for a private tour). I feel that without the tour it wouldn't make much sense. There are some blocks on the ground which gives you an appreciation and understanding of the intelligence that the Inca's had when building their empires. It's impressive that they built a foundation that did and still can sustain earthquakes. The 14 point block is also neat. All in all it is definitely a worthwhile site to visit.

Beautiful, Interesting, and Thought Provoking. The Inca Temple of the Sun was the most sacred and important temple in the Inca world. To subdue the population, the Spanish conquistadors build the church of Santa Domingo on the site, tearing down the temple and using the materials to build the church and other structures. Some of the original temple walls were too well built to be easily dismantled and are still in place and can be viewed from inside and outside the church. However, the Dominicans still occupy a large part of the site and have not permitted archaeologists access depriving the people of Peru of cultural and historical information about their past. You should not miss seeing the Temple of the Sun and as you do so, look beyond just what you are seeing with your eyes and also engage your brain as a thoughtful tourist.

Do not miss this place. You get a great impression of the difference between the solid simple lines of the Inca structures that have withstood the impact of earthquakes without issue and the grandeur of colonial Spain that is damaged with each quake. Then ask the question who knew how to build better?.The history of this center of the Inca society is simply told with a couple of magnificent modern paintings that must not be missed.

rivals Machu Picchu for significance. this is in Ollyatatambo and is in the Sacred Valley. The site has great significance in Incan history and shouldn't be missed. Evidence of how the temple was built using ramps and stone rollers to move stones from a quary that was 5 miles away is something you don't see every day

Another amazing feat. if you get the multi city attraction pass, this is really worth seeing. I still marvel at how the Incas could build such amazing architectural structures and this is no exception. There is one small section in a room where you can see exactly how the walls were when they excavated the site. The vestments are exhibited in one room and coves a span of time giving you some great examples of style and adornment.

Incan Architecture. Worth a stop (I think it's included on the multi location pass we got). Off the courtyard are some walls from the original temple. May need some interpretation - we had a guide already with us, and am not sure it's really we labeled.

interesting. The Cathedral Basilica of the Assumption of the Virgin, also known as Cusco Cathedral, is the mother church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cusco. The cathedral is located on the Plaza de Armas. Building was completed in 1654,[1] almost a hundred years after construction began.
interesting. located in cuzco, this old inka temple has been one of the most important of that era. it was dedicated to the God Sun

Go, but there will be mass tourism. I have been to Coricancha twice, and both times I enjoyed the history and culture of the place, but was taken aback at how overrun it was with tourism. Do not expect to dedicate more than an hour to this museum, but don't miss it if you enjoy the other Inca ruins. It is one of the finer examples of their building technique.

One of the jewels of Cuzco - don't miss it. It's a 'must-see' and you are strongly recommended to take a guide to ensure that you get the oh-so-valuable insights you will need to fully appreciate the site, and to avoid missing crucial details. You cannot but be awed at the quality of the stonework, the patience needed to create it, and the conflict and accommodation between Inca beliefs and subsequently imposed Christian beliefs brought by the Spanish Conquistadors (Who obviously knew better and saw it as their duty to convert the ignorant. Please note the tongue firmly in my cheek and the parallels with the fanatical religious ideologies we hear about daily in the news).

Good - but hire a guide. This is obviously a "can't miss" on any tour of Cusco, given its importance to Incan history. The museum part does just an ok job explaining what you're seeing, but as we walked through and listened to other groups learn a whole lot more, I wished I had hired one of the guides standing outside selling their services. I think I would have gotten a lot more out of it. That said, even without a guide, you get a good understanding of Incan architecture and cosmology.

Amazing Incan stonework. We went to Coricancha as part of the CIty Tour first, this was very interesting with a guide as he brought the story of the building to life and explained how the Incans built the foundations. The tour was a bit short so as we had some time on our final day we went back again and this time spent more time exploring the gardens as well. It's a fascinating place and well worth the 10 soles per person entry fee, even twice! While we were in the gardens we also saw a hummingbird up close. Don't miss the paintings of the Llama constellation and the four quarters of the Incan empire, they are just amazing.
Very Interesting. This area was fascinating and our guide did a wonderful job of explaining everything we were seeing.

See Culture and Inka architecture. It is a nice place to see the Inka architecture and belief inside. A great learning place. The building itself is combinaton of Inka and Spanish construction. Outside there is a beautiful square. It is a must see place if you are interested in Inka culture.

over the road from the hotel Liberatore very historic and interesting. Whilst staying at the hotel Liberatore Our tour guide at Condor had arranged a trip to the church which is in stepping distance.Glad we went very interesting and historic.fantastic architecture.Well worth a visit.We spent and hour there but could have stayed at least 2hrs

Worth to see!. I read some reviews here and I agree it really depends on a guide what your experience will be like. We had a guide just for us (my fiancee and I) and our lovely Yrma from View Peru really took her time to explain everything and some more. I would recomend to go with a guide, because alone you will not grasp the history and the meaning of this place. It is a beautiful landmark, especially the Inka remains. If you realize that Cusco was the navel of their world, you must see this temple. It will take your imagination back, before the Spaniards, when Coricancha's walls were covered with sheets of gold, golden statues were on display in the courtyard and king Pachacutec was on the throne.

tell your guide to spend more time. we were rushed but wish we could spend more time and see all the spots. very interesting. make sure you have your camera charged and enough memory on the card. best to get few linse - close up and long shoot.
Beautiful. We spent an hour enjoying the art, history and architecture. You could spend more or less but should go!

Worth Seeing. From the outside, the grounds and view are spectacular. The Inca engineering and construction are quite impressive at this site, inside and out. The stones were laid with such an exact fit. It's so good that the Spanish built their structure right on top. It's confusing to look at -- two very different civilizations at one glance. The inside is a very different view, almost bare and compact. The courtyard/gardens are beautiful and we were told it's still an active church. Visit the individual rooms for each one has a different story. You can even see a small repair to a stone -- quite ingenious. Take a walk through the entire inside and make sure you go inside the museum. There are exhibits with historic explanations, even in English.We visited this Convent twice. The first time was with a guide but he rushed us through so fast that we only were shown the items he thought were interesting. We visited this again a couple days later by ourselves and had a more enjoyable time. We could spend as much time at exhibits and rooms as we wanted.I would visit this exhibit early for it was starting to get very crowded as we were starting to leave. II would visit again. It's very clean and safe.

Striking architechural contrast. The Church and Convent of Santo Domingo is built on the foundations of the Inca Coricancha temple. The contrast in both architectures is very striking. Even if you don't go inside just walk by to admire the external construction and gardens in front of the structure. Located just between Ave El Sol and Ahuacpinta and an easy walk from Plaza de Armas.

Must Do in Cusco!. We learned about this site briefly during a free walking tour and decided to check it out ourselves for a bit after...totally worth it! Would suggest getting a guide so you actually know what you're looking at. There's usually a few standing outside the building and we were able to hire one for two of us for 30 soles ($10 or so) in addition to the 10 soles entrance fee each. For less than $20 for the two of us, this was an excellent place to spend a couple of hours and learn about the melding of the Inca and Spanish empires. Came to find out that a certain point in the temple was literally the exact center of the Inca empire throughout SA....so cool! Definitely check this out!

Inca and Spanish. Temple of Sun is in the middle of a complex of a Spanish church,,,,,stones were taken from part of the temple to build the church. Very interesting art from native peoples after their conversion to Christianity by the Spanish. Very typical religious scenes but with a native touch to many of the themes.

History in the middle of the city. Right in the centre is this lovely old building with interesting history. Went in a tour which has its good points but would have liked more time to roam around on our own, but you could do that later if you wished. Well preserved and clean, a delight
Go to the museum. We came to see the museum and it was well worth it. You'll learn about the Spanish occupation of cusco and how cusco was before that. Very educational and interesting.
Worth it. This place is a peak into the inca empire. You'll see their construction style and learn about their culture and religion since this was their main temple.
Okay. We had the guided tour, some bits interesting others a little bit boring but everyone is interested in different things, we were glad we went around this place but have seen better.

History and domination in the heart of Cusco. Qoricancha is a very rich experience if you are interested in Inca architecture and their rituals. Make sure to have a guide or to read about the history of the place before going, as the context of the monastery over the Inca temple and the circumstances in which it was unearthed are very interesting!
Amazing. The Incan construction first and then the Spanish on top was very interesting. We hired an English speaking guide at the door for a reasonable price and learned a lot.
master work. this place was so nice , because the most important temple for the incas was, the finest polished stones, temples, absolutly recomended.

Very interesting place. Amazing to see the old Inca walls and the massive stones. So interesting to read about the history of Cusco and Incas. Some lovely modern artwork in the building, as well as a lovely Spanish courtyard and a lovely view over part of Cusco city. It's definitely worth the small entrance fee, you can also buy a combined ticket to see the convent, which works out a few peso cheaper if you do want to see both places.

Incan and spanish historical place. In Cusco city where both Incan and spanish catholic history harmoniously co-exist, great paintings inside but no photgraphy of paintings. Overall nothing wow-ed me though, if you dont like history then skip this place.

Wonderful old cloister with great views. This is the legendary cloister of Santo Domingo that was built in the 17th century from the stones of the Temple of the Sun. There are some beautiful views here of the area.

all these skills of the Inca. impressive. Not so much the Spanish construction as well as the old Inca walls and constructions that withstood all the earthquakes (while the Spanish buildings collapsed said the guide with a smile). Use your imagination and see how it was in the Inca times!

Qorikancha & The Convent of Santo Domingo. As happened so often, the conquerors built a church and convent on the ruins of this famous temple, the Temple of the Sun. The Temple of Qorikancha was one of the most sacred Inca buildings and one of the most important temples of the Inca Empire. According to archelogists,it housed over 1,000 priests and attendants. The convent has many beautiful murals and paintings. There are many artifacts in their museums and the priests's vestments were covered in glorious embroidery in gold and silver threads.
very interesting. the profile of the stones and how they fix one to the other is really amazing, very interesting and well explained

Church built on an Inca Temple site. When the Spaniards came to Peru and in particular to the city Cusco, they demolished temples of the Inca Empire. One such temple foundation was used to build the Church of Santo Domingo (Iglesia de Santo Domingo). And, glimpses of Inca architecture can be seen as part of the structure.
Beautiful and unique. Classic and beautiful.. a must see if you enjoy ancient churches with wonderful décor and historical pieces and art.

Fascinating. We got a guide for this site and were not disappointed. Even without a guide, there was enough written on the walls to decipher what you're looking at. The price is great as well, just a few USD for entry. The site itself is a mix of Incan and Spanish and is really cool. Would recommend a visit, especially as it's right in the heart of the tourist area of Cuzco.

Extrodinary engineers. You have to see the building technique of the Incas to appreciate the sheer genius. We had a local tour guide walk us through the ruins and point out and explain the engineering techniques. It was simply amazing.
Very Interesting but COLD!!. It's crazy how much wind us up there - so make sure to dress warm! Otherwise, it is pretty awesome to see the alter where the moon comes in.

Well worth a look.. Another ancient Inca relic. One of the main temple around the area. But somehow I felt this temple a little bit underwhelming. But either way, it was one of the famous spots in the Sacred Valley and it was also a popular stop of the tourist bus, so still worth visiting.

Interesting. The ingenuity in building this structure is amazing. The whole structure and all the angles inside each room are a trapezoid to keep the structure intact in case of an earthquake. It is stone on stone precision construction with nothing else holding it together. This was built by the Incas and is definitely worth seeing.
Worth a visit. This was a stop on the tourist bus. Worth a visit, especially if you read about the significance of the site before you visit.
Underwhelming. There is much more to see in the Sacred Valley. Can you say Olleyantaytambo? This tour was too long for what we got out of it.

knowing what you are seeing adds to the experience. We get to see Incan ingenuity and colonial conquest here... When they conquered the Cusco valley, the founders of the Inca dynasty, Manko Qhapaq and his family, settled on the site now occupied by the Qorikancha. Later the main temple of the Inca Empire was constructed here.Inca Pachakuti (or Pachakuteq), rebuilt the shrine and endowed it with fabulous riches, and for this reason its name was changed to Qorikancha, which in Quechua means “golden enclosure”. Situated at an elevation of 11,150 feet, Cuzco was laid out on a grid plan in the shape of a puma, a sacred mountain lion. The pre-Inca site of Sacsayhuaman, on a plateau near the northern edge of the city, forms the head of the puma and the Coricancha temple forms the center of the grid..After the Spanish conquest in 1532, the Qorikancha fell to Juan Pizarro, one of Francisco Pizarro's brothers. Before his death, Juan Pizarro donated the Qorikancha to the Dominican Order. Founded in 1534, Cusco’s Saint Dominic Priory (Convento de Santo Domingo) was the first Dominican convent in Peru...enjoy the cloister with the Incan ceremonial fountain and the garden with the Incan terraces...

A beautiful place, inside and out! - July 2013. We had a guided tour, courtesy of Julio, of the famed Santo Domingo Church. Inside are the Inca ruins over which the church was built. Sad how Catholicism tried to stamp out any opposing faiths by almost literally sweeping them over the rug. Several paintings adorn the hallways, and the Andes Mountains surround you on all sides during your visit. Take your time here, there's plenty to see!

How did they learn how to do this?. I was intrigued by the way the builders were able to bring the large stones to this distant location. They had to use a ramp to get to higher and higher levels. Determining the exact placing for the temple required scientific measurement of the sun angles. We fail to give early civilizations the credit they deserve
A day in the Sunlight. Loved exploring this temple, learning it's history , taking in the sunshine from various windows and portals within it's amazing walls.

Great warm up for Macchu Picchu. We had a tour guide take us around and she really brought this place to life. She also told us that it was a "warm up" to get us ready for the real hiking the next day at Macchu Picchu. This site really helped us understand the history. Hiking/running shoes are a must and you'll want sunscreen and bug spray as well. It's also a great way to make the most of your "travel day" from Cusco to Macchu Picchu, as its on the way from Cusco to the train station.

Worth the low entrance fee. Basically, this is an Incan temple that was converted by the Spanish into a convent and Catholic church. The blend of history is great, and make sure to get a map (and paper tour) from the ticket area to guide yourself through the complex. Definitely worth going!
Not enough descriptions. The temple itself is nice, but the descriptions there are not enough. It may be better to hire a tour guide or visit the nearby museum to have a better understanding.

Inca's Golden Temple. we had a really good guide and she told stories that made the place come alive. I could imagine all the beatiful differnt parts of the temple and especially the garden with it's golden statues.

Worth the extra S/10 soles. A bit taken aback that this wasn't on the Tourist Boleta ticket (Church grabbing money again?). The Inca ruins are not huge, as they have been suppressed by the church, but there is a great collection of 'Cusco School' religious art, and also a modern exhibition in the upstairs galleries. Outside you can appreciate the dominant position of Coricancha and some of the staggering complex Inca stone-work.
Can't miss. If you come to Cusco you cannot miss the ancient Sun Temple. If you go deep down into the history of this sacred place, you will discover the most interesting place you've ever visited.

The Energy Intersection. Here in Coricancha there are 43 ley lines intersecting in the temple. This is why the energy in the temple is through the roof so to speak. Koricancha (means "courtyard of gold" in Quechua) was an Incan temple before the Spanish made it into a Church. They built right over the existing structure. Outside you can still see the original Incan walls. The structure was also used as an observatory.What is most interesting are the mortarless, trapezoidal doorways, and exterior curved retaining walls, which to this day have survived earthquakes in the area.There is a museum nearby off of Avenida El Sol where historical documents of the site are stored.

Worth the trip. Illuminating view of the Spanish attempt to wipe out the native religion. It was interesting that once they had removed the gold they decided to renovate the temple as they could not recreate a more stable structure. Effectively they saved some of the best ideas.
Wear comfortable shoes and take a hat.. A really terrific experience, if not a little crowded. A bit out of Cusco, but some interesting things on the way

The Only Place You Will See 100 Ton Rocks Cut to Precission. Temple of the sun is an amazing Inka legend. Despite the attempts by the Spanish Catholic Church to deface it, it remains with walls that boggles the mind in regards to the precision with which the tons heavy rocks were cut to fit precisely fit with each other using tools and methods that to this days are baffling. The alignment of the windows through the temple is awe-inspiring, the magnitude of the precisely cut rocks fitting like hand in glove.This site is like the holy grail of Inka precision engineering. A must see! - (and try to ignore all the Spanish religious attempts to denigrate this pearl of ancient civilization).

beautiful, but not enough time on the city tour. beautifully preserved remnant of the Incans Temple of the Sun... however, we visited this site as part of the city tour, and while that gave us information that we would not have had otherwise, it did not give us enough viewing/wandering time.

Fascinating experience. This was just around the corner from our hotel in Cusco (Casa Adina Private Collection) and the story and history behind it was brought to life by our guide from Condor Travel, Alex Medina. Fascinating to see the church within a church theme used by the Spanish to subjugate the Incas. The skill of Incas in building the temple and protecting it from earthquakes along with their interpretation of the milky way and the stars was brilliant from start to finish. Highly recommended, especially with a knowledgable guide.

beautiful church. Our hotel was literally across the street from this gem. It is fascinating to see churches that the Spanish insisted on building to convert Indians to their religion - and to see touches of native culture in carvings or paintings - an ear of corn here, a jaguar there....
Just amazing. A place you must experience at least once in your life. Amazing views and you can breathe the history around it.

amazing stonework. We went to the site in the afternoon around 3 pm and it was a bit crowded. Better to go early in the morning.The stonework is just amazing. You can see how the stones fit together and it looks incredible. The gardens are beautiful and well maintained. You can take photos mainly in the section outside. I recommend to be with a guide, as there are many interesting stories around the place...

Amazing stone work and very nice grounds. We were impressed with the Inca construction and it was interesting to e the Conquistadors attemps. Would love to have had a plaque with information regarding this attraction. Museum associated with it is a hard to find. It is expensive and located under ground.

Excellent examples of stonework and value for money. We went to the site around 10am and it wasn't very crowded. The stonework is exceptional and inside there are excellent examples showing how the stones fit together. There are descritptions in Spanish and English making it easy to walk around without a real need for a guide for this particular Information. There are incredible works of art in one section, and although photography of this is not allowed, there are other areas where there are plenty of photo opportunities. The gardens are particularly pretty and well maintained. Care should be taken on the stone paths after rain as it is a little slippery. This is highly recommended. The cost of entry is 10 sols, but if you have time and the funds spend another 5 sols to include the Santa Catalonia monastery nearby. The walk to coricancha is realtively easy and is about 10 minute stroll from plaza de Armas.

Bell Tower Closed, But Still Nice to See. We came to this spot specifically to climb the Bell Tower, which unfortunately after we paid the 10 soles each we found out it is closed and wouldn't reopen until later in 2015. If you are interested in the history of how the temple was built on Inca Ruins it's great to see. There's also several pieces of art too.

The temple of one culture sits atop and encloses the other.. It's hard to believe that this complex built by Pachacutec once had hundreds of gold panels lining its walls, life-size gold figures, and gold altars. Of course, the gold was removed to pay ransom for the captive Inca Atahualpa--all done in vain. So now we have the Convent of Saint Domingo that was erected upon the site. Note the semicircular wall forming the exterior wall on the western side of Coricancha--such excellent stonework that has survived earthquakes.And as you visit the churches in Cuzco and surrounding area, reflect on the sources for the gold in the interiors of the churches.

Inka Stonework. You will find an interesting "restoration" of the Inka temple which was covered/destroyed by the Spanish but revealed after an earthquake. Make sure to go to the small underground museum in the front yard/near the street.

Inca walls and spanish church. I went there with my girlfriend. The Inca part with the walls, some stones and a small reconstruction model of how this place was supposed to be is nice. But those christian paintings and everything that was brought by the spaniards does not at all go along well with the original Inca style of that area. Just the Inca walls are amazing. Still worth having a look.

Very interesting and there are so many details about the stones. I came here as part of the City Tour. The entrance is 10 Sol. There are no photos allowed in the temple of the sun. Our guide walked us through the different rooms and explained in detail about the history and the formation of the rocks placed by the Inca people. I felt like the stories were more interesting than the Cathedral in the Plaza de Armas.

Hard Hike. We were able to climb to the Sun Gate earlier in the day when it wasn't too crowded. It is a strenuous climb which can be slippery in places. The view from the top is amazing. On our way down, things had gotten pretty crowded and it looked like a long line of people trudging up the steps. If you can avoid a crowd like that, then definitely go for it - it took us about 40 minutes to go up to the Sun Gate.

Any visit to Cusco must start here..... The Coricancha summarises the history of this city and why not the whole Inca complex society. Ancient walls show how the Incas had adapted to their environment thst included powerful earthquakes. There are also represetation of their deities including all their major gods and an interesting representation of the Milkyway showing Inca's constellations including local fauna like llamas.Spanish influence is also present in the church built on top of the Inca temple and also on canvases.TIP: The place does get really crowded in the afternoon when most of organized tours arrive with hordes of tourist so I recommend a visit in the morning, the place opens at 8:30 am (excluding Sunday when it is closed in the morning)

Our Tour Guide David Ramos opened our eyes. This temple of the sun must be visited with a very knowledgeable tour guide. We were fortunate to have David Ramos who knew the history of the Temple and of the Spanish destruction. He nearly had a story and insight about each stone, crevice, carving, and ruin in the building. I would not visit this temple without a guide. It would be boring and mundane. Davis enlightened us and made this sight quite exciting. Being Incan, David was biased against the Spanish. We loved that passion and "true" history of the Spanish Conquest.

Impressive inca architecture. Most interesting thing here is to watch the ancient inca temple (once covered in gold) above the "new" church. The church is OK, but the inca remaining are impressive. Skip the church and focus on the massive stone structure beneath. There are two different sites here. The Santo Domingo temple (buy the ticket there) and a archeological museum (no single entry ticket option, you have to buy the Cusco tourist ticket..a really really stupid policy).
wonderful. It was awesome everything we see during our stay in the city of Cuzco, Qoricancha is one of the wonderful places, the Andean syncretism, paintings, architecture, nice everything.
Most important temple of the Inca empire. You can see how the Spaniards built their church in top of what the Inca's temple was. But the Inca's architecture remains. Temople to the god Sun.

Should have done more research.... Former palace of the Inca, stripped of that glory by the conquistadors, still an active Catholic Church. For 10 soles you can wander through the courtyard & garden, admire the walls & engineering, view a model of what once was & wonder... Not much signage so a guide or book would be very helpful.Nice display about astronomy & a replica of a gold disc with special symbols...just wish I had done more research before visiting.Btw, this was the only place in Cusco where I encountered photographers who were busy waiting to sell me the pics they had taken as I walked into the Qorikancha

Architectural Buildings, Religious Sites, Historic Sites, Art Museums. I am interested in Architectural design and culture. I thoroughly enjoyed the tour and the history.This was a bitter sweet experience for me. The destroyed Inca Temple with the Catholic Church built upon it, left me with a sense of sadness.

Great Pre/Post Columbian Comparison. This place is awesome for the fact that you have such a juxtaposition of pre and post Columbian stone work. Much of Cusco is built on Inca foundations, including the church of Santo Domingo, which is on top of Coricancha. It was amazing to see that the post Columbian stone work fell during earthquakes while the Inca foundations stayed firm. The Inca stone work here is amazing and you can really tell the care and work that it took to make this Temple of the Sun. Too bad all the gold is gone!

In a knew what they were doing, Conquistadors did not. All over Peru Spanish buildings (especially churches) were constructed on Inca stone foundations. Earthquakes of layer centuries took their toll on the newer buildings but left the Inca stones intact. No where is this more evident than here at the Temple of the Sun/Santo Domingo. Informative and artistic displays. Hard to feel any sympathy for stupidity and greed of the conquistadors!

Easy and beautiful tour. We toured this with our guide - the paintings are amazing! You can't beat the price and location for an easy afternoon outing. THe monastery as a whole was beautiful and we enjoyed looking at the architecture. The gardens were stunning.

As close to El Dorado as the Spanish got. Known also as the "Court of Gold" we can now only imagine how glorious this Temple of the Sun must have looked at the peak of the Inca Empire. It was devastated by the need to pay ransom to the Spanish for a captive Inca ruler, and later ransacking by the Conquistadors. It requires a skilfull guide to make you appreciate not only the architectural and engineering skills (some of which are obvious) but also the surprising sophistication of Inca astronomy and medical knowledge.

Check out the Museum. Make sure you go inside the museum. There are some better preserved walls and ruins inside. You can see just how great the architects of old were at making perfectly flush connections in the stone

shouldve bought the book before we went. if you self-tour this one, you'll miss 90% of what's important. pre-read, and get a guide, we wish we did. nonetheless, the importance of this site to incan religion/culture cannot be overstated.
Stunning. We loved learning about the old and new parts of the sun temple. The views from the balconies are stunning

Interesting mix of Inca and Catholic. A Dominican Monastery built on top of a destroyed Inca Temple. Very interesting museum with some English signage that explained the history and then the different areas of the museums. See Inca and Spanish walls side by side and decide which was more primitive. (Hint: it isn't the Spanish!) A great introduction to the Inca culture, the Catholic/Spanish conquest, and the Cusco School of art which was Catholic yet blended a bit of Inca in after a while.
It's worth a visit. This place tells a story about history. Hispanic building on top of Inca building. I learned a lot there. A place worth a visit.

Must see!!!. Increadible inca art and history is very interesting . I wish I could see all these walls covered with gold 2 finger thick gold and jewels ... you can see three different settlement in history .. just go !!!!

Art and architecture. Also known as the Incan Golden temple, this is now a Dominican monastery. The architecture that has stood since the 1500's in a seismic region is remarkable. Our private GotoPeru.com guide, Fernando, answered our question about why so many trapezoid shapes with a wonderful explanation of how it was built (including tilted walls) and these trapezoids which provide extra support to the structure.
Don't miss it!. This tour was worth every moment! We viewed it as a pretest for Machu Picchu. It was beautiful to see the work of the Incas in the backdrop of the most beautiful Andes mountains!

Interesting!. I loved visiting this Church. It was such a good example of how the Catholic Church had tried to rub out the previous religious culture of the Inca people. I am a Catholic myself but found that I was appalled at the infliction of such a different way of life on the Inca people. The Church was built on top of the Inca Temple! We went to Mass at the Church after our visit and guided tour but I found it a very dark and creepy Church. There was nothing warm about it, I felt. For me the main interest was in seeing the remains of the Inca temple that was originally there.

Impressive Inca Architecture. We visited the Temple of the Sun archaeological site. Note that it is not included in the tourist ticket but it only costs 10 soles to enter. On the inside you see the Spanish architecture on top of the Inca architecture which is pretty cool. It was very impressive to see the intricacies of the Inca architecture. Unfortunately all of the Inca artifacts were taken away by the Spanish but the building itself is pretty cool. In addition, you get some good view of the surrouding area from some of the outdoor points within the complex. I would recommend checking it out.

Underwhelming. It cost 10 soles to get in but there was just several empty rooms. It was quite busy (popular) but I couldn't see why. The Inca stone masonry was great but to see several empty rooms was not really worth it. Perhaps a good guide could bring the visit to life.

This gave us the appreciation of the architecture so many years ago.. We walked around and marveled at the building knowledge which has lasted through earthquakes and time. The stone walls are in beautiful condition.
a good museum. it's interesting to see the temple of the sun, the architecture and the things exhibit inside. It's a must-come if you're in Cusco.

Well Preserved Archaeological Site. This church was located literally right across the street from the hotel we stayed at Inka Palace, so obviously we could not resist going inside. Once inside I was amazed to see all of the grand artwork. All paintings appeared to be held within gold cased frames. There were too many urns and vases to count, and the paint on them seemed brand new (it was so bright and clear).The center of the church actually holds some incredible ruins. This church was built in/around an exisitng structure. During the visit, you walk through exisiting "Inka-style" structures. The walls/stonework here is not ealborate but is certainly of a high "caliber" of artistry. Stonework is very smooth/polished, windows are squared, walls are straight (even today). and rooms are linear; you can look through one set of windows, and line up to a wall three levels back. All rooms seemed level.What was most interesting to me was to see the devastation left from the many earthquakes which have hit Cuzco in the past. In particular, there are paintings/pictures from a major earthquake, which toppled a good portion of the church and the city itself. The remaining structure was used as a foundation for this "new" church.Almost every night of our stay, there were dozens of weddings - complete with fireworks on the plaza - at this church. There were also many communions, and funerals, so obviously this is not only a histrical site, but also a functioning house of worship.

Get a Tour Guide!. This is an amazing historical artifact, with so many interesting facts. I strongly recommend you pay for one of the many private tour guides standing outside waiting to show you around – they are well worth the money. Looking at it alone, it looks like a lot of stones, but the tour guide pointed out all kinds of interesting things about how the Incas made their structures earthquake resistant, how they got the rocks to fit together in an age where they didn't use mortar, and about the various ceremonies that took place in these temples. This is definitely worth your time to visit!

Very informative. We spent about an hour walking around the temple. Note that many of the museums and temples prohibit photography but there were places in this temple that allowed photographs. It's great to hear the history of the locations and how the Incas lived.

Well worth the visit. We visited this site in Cusco during our exploration of the city. Note that they don't really allow pictures in most of the areas in the temple (very common in Cusco) but there is quite a bit to see and the history if well worth the visit.

Interesting!. An interesting inca temple of the sun with its typical megalithic stones mixed with the colonial architecture of the Saint Dominicus building. A very nice fusion,even if having the whole original inca temple would be better..

Interesting church. Great to see inside.It is free in the mornings, with a charge in the afternoon.All the churches in Cusco are spectacular for their own reasons. This one is on the main square. The town has a parade everyday and the parade is around 9am. The parades, are in memory of an Incan or Catholic religious icon. They usually start from this church.

Interesting inca ruin within the Catherdral. Many of the Inca ruins were built on by the Spanish. These are one of them. Very central to Inca culture and Cusco. The ruins have been preserved as much as possible. A guide adds value to all of the site. It is a small cost. Open most days during business hours. The art, architecture and renovations were well done. The church is intricate and not as we know them in Australia. The wood carving and gilding is amazing.The ruins under the bank in Cusco cost nothing and are the best preserved I have seen. The bank is one block closer to the main square from these ruins.

Paying site. Did not went in because it was a paying site and we had visited the museo de sitio del Qoricancha, and we were soooo disapointed about this museum.Could be so much more. Still remember the smell of the toilets close to the exhibition rooms.

beautiful relic of history. The history and architecture of this temple/church is fascinating. Some of the artwork hanging around is also incredibly interesting. This is a must see for anyone who wants to see what the Spaniards did when they conquered the people here.

overwhelming, but be prepared for large crowds. The temple, in the middle of the city, carries pre-Columbian and newer history - a lot; if you are lucky enough to have some space to breath and time to feel, it is overwhelming. Try to avoid big crowds and explore at your pace.

A guide would have been useful. Although you can get a sense of the place from reading a guide book I think it would have come alive if we had had an English speaking guide.The scale of the stones and the architecture was very impressive as were the cloisters.

Best ruins within Cusco. Easy to get to. Easy to find. Really annoying that it doesn't come with the very expensive Boleto Turistico; but it was still a nice intro to Incan culture and history. The setting is really well-maintained, and nice. Don't bother with the museum located nearby...really.
Just ok. It wasn't nearly as nice as the Inka ruins attached to it; but some of the more modern paintings were nice to look at. Centrally located, so it's easy to get to.
Amazing. The big boulders used to build the place still amazes me. There is so much to see in Cusco...and the ethnicity enchants you wherever you go.
Very beautiful. This is a very beautiful building with a ton of history. Well worth the visit and there are tour guides to let you know what you are looking at.

A bit disappointing. This temple would have been wonderful to see 500 years ago but since the Spanish destroyed it and built a church on top, there's nothing much left. The best views are from the rear but there's a nice park there where you can sit and watch the locals at play.

Neat inca site. This is probably the best inca site inside the city of Cusco. That been said, most better preserved Inca sites are outside of Cusco. The remained of the temples are neat, part of it is now a Dominican Convene. The garden is pretty. Its sad the original temple of the sun is destroy and is now the cathedral portion of the convene. It's still worth the tour to see the delicate incan architecture. The only complaint I have is there's no caption or self guild brochure anywhere, so you need to hire an expensive guid (more so than the ticket) to know what you are looking at. That seems to be the case with all historical site in Cusco.

Last Day Decision. One more place to tie all the history together. Very worthwhile. We read most of the plaques but I feel it would have been even better if we had hired a guide at the door. Seems to give a better understanding where everything fits in. Read a few bits of history before your trip to Peru and then reread them after and it will all make so much sense.

It goes on and on. No where for contemplation, it seems entirely taken over for tourism now, although photos are strictly forbidden. It is quite a stunning place though, and seems to be 4 cathedrals linked into 1. Well worth a wander around.

Interesting juxtaposition of two cultures. This site is well worth seeing. There is a lot of information throughout the building so you don't really need a guide, especially if you have a decent guidebook or two. The church is built directly on top of an ancient Inca site so both are merged into one. It's a great example of how the Spanish used their religion to dominate the older Inca culture by literally placing their structures directly on top of the formerly sacred sites. Disturbing yet beautiful. There is also a very inconspicuous contemporary art gallery on the second floor which has some wonderful graphite drawings and a beautiful display of photographs of antique toys. Not at all what I expected but a nice use of the space.

I must-see. I'm so glad I had a guide take me through here. There is so much history about both the Inca and Spanish conquistadors tied to this Dominican church and the main Incan temple it was build on top of. To see the original Incan foundation and base used for this church, and the original walls that were exposed after the 1950 earthquake, shows the incredible ingenuity and mastery of construction this ancient culture had over the Spanish. Almost all the original walls were covered in gold and silver, which was given the Spanish. One can only imagine the splendor of this place.

You DO NOT have to buy the ten site ticket. I am still not sure how much this "all-access multi-site" ticket was supposed to cost. I think it was s/170 each! Well, we were not about to do that. After a long conversation with an employee, he "allowed" us to enter for s/10 each. The employee was insistent that this was an exception and not a normal occurrence. At this point he was whispering to us. That is because if the rest of the gringos heard, mass hysteria would ensue. This entrance price is not advertised on any of the signs at the entrance, so you must pitch a fit to even find out about it.
Spectacular views. Nice walk to visit the Temple of the Sun. A book of TinTin (belgian author: Hergé) was based on this site.
Rigorous and beautiful hike. Impressive, relatively short, intense trail hike through very interesting ruins. Highly recommend this as part of the Sacred Valley experience.
interesting!!. the story behind the Inca-Spanish temple- church is thought provoking ...appreciate how the Peruvians have combined Catholicism with the ancient worship

Interesting. The stone work was interesting and the courtyard was very pretty. The paintings are fantastic - we arrived shortly before closing and would have liked more time to ponder The Milky Way. Not sure why there is a toy museum on the second floor; it seemed a bit out of place.

I don't want to spoil the surprise!. This is what I would term a very boroque church. It had a lot of silver around the altar etc. It was a good example of how the Spanish attempted to incorporate the Incan religion into Catholicism, most likely as a selling point. There was a surprise at the end of the tour and I don't want to spoil it for anyone taking the tour!

Inspiration for Lego!. This was an fascinating explanation of how the temple was built to withstand earthquakes. The way the blocks fit together is exactly the same way legos fit together so that they would provide some flexibility during an earthquake. The little bit of gold at the end of the tour depicting the Sun God lets you imagine how magnificent it must have been before the Spanish took the gold from it! They have some very nice landscaping around it, as well, which frames a view of the city.

Great!. Was great to see history right in the middle of town. Grab a guide for extra at the door (you pay them at the end) for added information as there isn't much information inside. I thought it was worth seeing!

The best part is the Inca foundation. This place is very interesting. You get 16th century church built on the foundation of an Inca or earlier temple. The temple foundation is the best part. I could not help wondering why the Spanish did not get the Inca stone masons to work on their churches. The tight fitting blocks of the temple are earthquake resistant. The Spanish church, not so much. But well worth a visit. Unfortunately, everyone in town is inside at the same time.

Awesome Church. Beautiful location. Beautiful architecture. Beautiful scenery. I especially loved the open areas that are great for taking pictures. The artwork around the church was amazing. Loved the mini trek to the bathroom because you get to see the entire city of Cusco, and the mountains. I would highly recommend this place if you are in Cusco.

Finale of our Cusco tour. Under saving the best for last, this was our final stop with our Kuoda guide. The "Navel of the World" was best understood in the context of all the other Inca and colonial sites we had visited and was a wonderful culmination of our trip.

Pretty good learning about Inca's past. This temple is a church, museum and ruins visit all in one. The temple houses the ruins of the Inca temple long destroyed and the new church built on it's foundation. There is art and a ton of history on the Inca empire inside the walls of this attraction.

Must do while in Cusco. While I personally wouldn't say you have to take a City Tour (the half day guided tour of the Coricancha, Cathedral and four main ruins outside of the city), you should make sure to visit the Coricancha and Cathedral with a tour guide. The guided tour is a MUST or you'll miss all the important information.

Nice place for a quick visit.... I saw Corincancha on my last day in Cusco, so I only had a bit of time. I enjoyed strolling through it pretty quickly (without a guide). Though I think many city tours typically include this (it was closed for national elections). The courtyard and gardens were really pretty. As was the view of the city.

More than expected. We almost missed out on this,by now 'Churched out' it was not untill around two pm on the Sunday that we saw the crowds leaving after a service that we wandered in. What a splendid section of the old temple remains within.
Take some time out to go visit this place,you will not regrette at all.

TEMPLE OF THE SUN (CORICANCHA) WORTH SEEING!. Hire a guide through your hotel to get the most out of your visit. Our guide was Marco and he did a terrific job of explaining everything to us. Definitely worth seeing this historical site if you are in Cuzco.
Disappointingly fragmentary. Efforts are being made to refocus on the Inca core, but a guide is still necessary to sort out the surviving pre-contact parts and their no longer obvious functions.
Amazing. Is amazing how incas built this macfinicent place, temple of the sun is a place that you must visit.

Very informative. As budget travelers, we did not buy the boleto turistico, so this was something we could do without the tourist ticket and is only 10 soles. It's very informative, with exhibits in English and Spanish. The excavation of the Inca temple alongside the preservation of the monastery is quite impressive as well. There are also good views of the city. We did not go with a group or guide, but I don't think you need one. It's worth 10 soles!

Qoricancha. All that remains of Qoricancha is the foundation on which the Spanish built the temple of Santo Domingo. But the stonework of the foundation is amazing as it was the most important temple of the Inca empire, the Temple of the Sun. The rounded oval shape of it is quite unusual for Inca structures, I guess, it was reserved for important religious cult buildings. You can see it from the street or go thru the church (admission S/. 10)

Not a must see. If you have an hour in cusco, go there but it's not a must. The other inca sites are much more impressive. The entrance is not included in the boleto touristico, so you have to pay 10 soles to get it.
Another Incan Treasure. Another site where having a guide to tell the story made a huge difference in appreciating it's significance.
A must see. Hire a guide and hear all about this fascinating place. The history is very interesting as are the Inca building techniques. It gets pretty busy, so best in the morning.
Enjoyable. Easily fitted in with other Incan remains, this one is well worthwhile visiting. Dawn or dusk will provide further interest with nice interplay of colour and shadows.

Cusco Tour. The tour consists of visits to the Santo Domingo Monastery with its gold leaf , the ruins of Sacsayhuaman the Ampitheatre of Kenko and Puca Pucara. Tour guide was very informative and easy to understand. Three exceptional sites in Cusco.

Huge wow factor!. This church has the most beautiful architecture, gold and silver works of art I have ever come across through my travels. I was a little depressed that I could not take pictures inside, even without flash. Well worth the visit. It also has some amazing paintings.
Anniversary Trip. This was our first tour upon arrival in Cusco before going to our hotel. The Inca temple and Spanish monastery are very interesting. You can imagine when it was covered in gold

Qorikancha. This is one of the most impressive buildings to see in Cusco, one can appreciate the mix of colonial and prehispanic heritages coming together. Most people go on a tour that clearly provides the background to better appreciate the building but it results on overcrowding and very limited space to take pictures plus very little time to enjoy the place. Recommend to go back on your own very early or before closing time so have more time to enjoy it.
Beautiful Church. A beautiful Church much rebuilt but showing the vibrancy of the church, love the cherubs. It's on top of Inca Temples, and well worth a look.
A must see!. Very interesting and very sad to see that what the Incas built was completely covered and not appreciated. A nice stop and doesn't take too much time to see.

Christian Church built on top of Inca ruins. Very interesting site. Examples of well built earthquake-proof Inca walls and architecture. The Spaniards came and plundered all the gold inside. Only replicas of the golden artwork remain. They built the Christian Church right on top of the Inca ruins. It is a good example of the melding of the 2 cultures. Lovely courtyard with historic paintings and nice gardens.

Impressive site - conveniently located. We went through Quoricancha twice, once on our own, and once with a guide (wasn't intentionally planned however). Have to say that there's benefit in doing it either way. Best would probably be having a guide for part of the time and then spend some free time to just wander around the complex inside and out, taking in the surrounding views of the city, or soaking up the sun on the grassy lawns. As historic sights go, the entrance fee is one of the more reasonable at 10 soles (about $4). Definitely worth a visit with or without a guide. If you are still around in late afternoon or evening, could also check out the attached church of Santo Domingo which seems to be only open for evening services from 5:30-7:30.

Instilling a new way of life. In the days of old conquest of neighboring (or faraway lands) was a means of increasing the power and wealth of a nation--just steal their wealth and destroy anyone that got in your way. For the ones who were not killed during the conquest, the conquerors forced their beliefs and way of life onto the conquered.One of the most common practices of this was to destroy existing religious sites and to construct your church or temple over the ruins. Think Jerusalem’s Temple Mount and then compare it to Cusco’s Incan Temple of the Sun. At Santo Domingo, you can clearly see the remaining Incan stone walls and the transition of the Spanish stone wall constructed over them.The architecture is typical of churches constructed in Europe at the time history, with the addition for the Spanish colonnaded courtyard.

Catholic construction over Huge Inca temples.. The history of the construction, how the church moulded the original structure into a Catholic edifice, and what the underlying Incan buildings were used for. The size and grandeur of this place as it remains is awesome.

Shame to have lost the Temple of the Sun. Destroyed by during the Spanish conquest and a new church constructed over the siteMuch of the original Incan stone foundation remains, which exhibits some of the finest examples of fitting of blocks of stone. With Cusco being the capital of the Incan Empire, you would expect nothing less in the skill level of construction workers.Stones had keyways cut into them in which molten metal was poured to harden and serve as anchors to hold stone in place during seismic activity (earthquakes). That molten metal consisted of a mixture of copper, silver and gold. Had the Spanish known of this practice, they would have undoubtedly destroyed every Incan structure in search of these anchors of precious metals.

Well worth the climb. Make day 2 of your visit to Machu Picchu dedicated to this climb. While not included in a guided tour of this amazing historical site, the climb is not particularly challenging if taken slowly. The view of Machu Picchu from the Sun Gate is truly magnificent and the overwhelming sense of being a part of the past is ever present.

Interesting historical site. We went here as part of a tour which was really great to hear about the history and really understand how amazing the temple is. Only downside is that it is really packed with tourists!
Inca's architecture.. Excellent examples of Incan architecture. Don't miss the museum underneath with elongated skulls and mummies.

Inca - Spanish mash up. Those Inca sure built some amazing things. And also really interesting to see the colonial Spanish stuff plopped right on top of it! The site is interesting, but there's almost no explanatory plaques. Hire one of the numerous guides at the front to give you a tour. We paid 50 Soles for 2 people.

Impressive art collection. There are so many churches one can see during their visit, however they don't always have such an impressive art collection. This church is really an art museum to all atheists. There is also a rock in the front left corner (inside) that Incan's still go to for prayer. It was part of the original Incan temple because the Spaniards burnt it down and built the current church. Recommend going while trying to acclimate to the altitude...not much walking and located right in the plaza.
How sad that conquistadores had to build on it. Great example of Inca architecture and their knowledge to avoid earthquakes, of astronomy, of seasons, and of mathematics
Architectural splendor. A real marvelous piece of colonial architecture filled with paintings, murals, and a gold decorated altar, worth seeing it.
Surprising History. It’s an amazing witness of the greatness of the Inca Empire. The visit is absolutely worth going considering all the history you can find and learn here.

So you can see the colonial and the inca!. Worth at least pass by on the outside, it really show how things were built in Cusco: above inca temples and buildings! We didn't go inside the museum, but it seems to be interesting. Buy the touristic ticket that gives right to see a lot of places so it can get cheaper!

One of the most important historical sites. I attended this site on a Cusco City Tour and really wish I hadn't done the City Tour as we didn't have enough time here. It's worth going with a guide to get all the fascinating historical facts, including how the stonemasons created the incredible buildings which withstand earthquakes.
Peru. Great experience and a must see. Cusco takes some time to adjust but this location helps with the adjustment of altitude.
Super History Lesson. We did the tour without a guide and found the descriptions in English to be satisfactory for a good understanding. A must-see to begin understanding Cusco pre and post-Conquest.

The gardens!. The temple contains a lot of history and a lot of interesting facts. I really liked that our tour ended with the gardens view. P.s If you don't know where is the panoramic view, ask where is the bathroom.

On our tour. This is a beautiful building with a courtyard and several Inca building remains. The Franciscans did destroy many things when they brought Christianity to the area, but it is a good representation of the history of Cusco.

Amazing architecture. The story-teller guide was passionate and caring. Very well done! He started with the architecture and the wisdom of the Incas. They were certainly not unskilled savages! but brilliant strategists.
Very crowded. Although we went over Peruvian Independence Day so it was very crowded, this was a fascinating tour. Loved the explanation of Incan architecture.

A Church on the Sun Temple. This Church was practically built within or on top of the Sun Temple. Part of its walls were the walls of the Inka Temple. The interior houses what was left of the temple. An architectural marvel!
amazing. It was amazing seeing ancient architecture up close. Gardens were beautiful, also enjoyed the contemporary art on display.

Atmospheric. So many of the Temples and places of Religion, Spirituality and Sacrifice exist in the Andes and in Peru. The tendency of the Spanish conquistadores and leaders of the Catholic Church to assume the right to build on previously hallowed ground is still amazing to me. Our guide stressed the significance of pre-Inkan civilisation at this point. The artwork was beautiful and it was an atmospheric and enjoyable visit..
Just off Plaza las Armas. A little taste of the entire Peruvian Culture in one sitting. Lots of history has taken place here. Its like a puzzle of life.
Worth it. This was built on/around the Temple of the Sun. It was a beautiful building and kept in very good condition.

Very Cool!. This was pretty cool, it was originally an Incan Temple that shows their ingenuity in building perfection but the Christians built a church on top of it. On the lawn outside they often have traditional Incan rituals, while I was there I managed to get in the middle of one which was beyond cool!
Lots of History. This is the temple built on the Temple of the Sun site and is worth a look around - so much history here.

Wow!. This site was very interesting to see - the history is fascinating and my cousin and I killed the better part of an entire afternoon looking around the attached church, the grounds and the museum.

Great History Lesson. Our guide was perfection in bringing this beautiful location to life. The Catholic Church is not too keen to allow correct historical information to be known, and so they change their story over the years. You can see the ancient Incan walls that were beautifully and perfectly constructed only to have been covered in plaster by the church in an effort to hide the true construction of the site. The church's involvement in Peru is a terribly interesting history beginning with the Spanish invasion to current time. The Temple of the Sun brings much information and discovery to center stage and at the forefront of thoughtful reflection.
Beautiful site. The site is very well-organised and the 3 inca temples are very interesting. The cristian building is very modern.

A glimpse of the past. A Dominican church was built on the Koricancha, but enough of the original building remains to give an idea of the splendor of this building in the past. I was fascinated with the blending of cultures and structures. A must see.

An interesting site. Coriconcha is a site not to be missed in downtown Cusco. I think what I find most fascinating is that the monastery was build right on top of an Inka temple, leaving much of the temple intact. There is actually a diorama showing the old Inka temple, and I've wished that they had the monastery as a removable part, so you could super impose the one over the other to see how they meet.There are some wonderful and interesting paintings in the Coriconcha as well.. both with an interpretation of Inka beliefs as well as a bunch of truly enormous Christian and Catholic "churchly" paintings. There is also a room full of new to ancient Priestly robes and garments. The gardens are beautiful as well. Get a tour guide to explain things and allow a couple hours to see the whole site. There are wheelchairs available at the entrance to the site, and most of the areas are wheelchair accessible.

Don't Miss This Fascinating Site. The sacred Inca temple of Cusco is tucked inside Convento de Santa Domingo, which is interesting in and of itself. The architecture is super unique--Spanish style convent with wallls of the old temple inside. Beautiful religious art on the walls.

Worth a visit !. We visited it with a tour which was bad, not enough time to see a lot of interesting things. Do not visit it with a tour, go by yourself and take the time to enjoy the place. An old Inca Temple transformed in church by the Spanish. At least, they kept the walls an the foundation of the Inca Temple...I recommend to visit this place !

Absolute delight to visit. Love Incan history. A great learning experience. I would say this is a must on a trip to Cusco. It must have been an awesome sight before the Spaniards too all of the gold from the walls.
Coricancha. Well worth it! Spent hours exploring the buildings and courtyard. Amazing history of the Inca ruins where the Spanish conquerors built on top of.
coolest day spot to check out. so pretty and since the weather was nice, the photos we took we were amazing. really cool and informative even if you're not super into museums.

A Great Place to Start Studying the Historic Center of Cusco. This is the Navel of the Earth, the Golden Palace, Sun Palace, and most important historical point of interest in the city of Cusco. Begin here and you will not be disappointed. Once reportedly filled with gold lined rooms and statuary, this is the central point from which the four quadrants of the city spiral out. I also learned about how the Incas viewed the night skies. Amazing!

Go with a tour guide. Would recommend going with a tour guide unless you have studied the place prior. We opted to go without and found it difficult to stop and read the history signs among the crowds so didn't learn the significance of each of the rooms/paintings. Nevertheless the art was still amazing and the ancient parts of the building was beautiful. Some pretty good views of Cusco from the deck area too.

beautiful. This place is really beautiful! They shouldn't let so many tourists get inside at once, though, I could hardly listen to what my guide was saying since it was so full of people. But the architecture is incredible.
Oh, do go to the bathroom, the view is amazing from there! Haha, really!
So so. The place is mostly cultural and has a lot of history.It is pretty and quite but I personally found it boring and probably the tour guide didn't help...
Another old church. Nothing special. All the churches from this period look alike. If you've already seen one, don't bother. If not, this is as good as the others.

Very intersting place. Visited this place it's on the Main Street not far from our hotel but it was really interesting loads to see and photograph lots wonderful paintings so yes very interesting well worth a look

An important part of Cusco history. Just walking past is of interest until you then realise the significance of the "Temple of the sun", such an important part of Incan culture. As others say, get a guide as you will miss so much of significance.
A beautiful church. Situated right near our hotel, we see this regularly through the day and it is a wonderful sight at any time, day or night, absolutely imposing, a beautiful church.
very interesting. spanish church built over Inka temple... very interesting. Get a guide or you´ll miss most of the contents in there.

Must see with a guide. We stopped in here on advise of trip advisor, and we are glad we did. We got a guide for the first time and we are glad we did, they were able to explain the difference between what the Spanish did and what was original Inca's.
Go see it, cheap to get in, pay for the guide.
Cusco and the Sacred Valley. This is a very interesting site that was hidden away until the earthquake in the 1950's. Be sure to look through the perfectly aligned window openings.

Beautiful place. There's so much to see inside, recommend spending a few hours here and try to avoid the tours that only spend 30 mins here as you'll miss out on too much. It's beautiful from the outside too.
Beautiful church. So much to see inside the church, recommend taking a few hours rather than going with a tour or you'll find it too rushed.
Surprisingly impressive. I wasn't expecting to be very impressed but I was. The town and the ruins were amazing. It's not to be missed.

A don't miss in Puno. Unbelievable fine stone work, much of it still intact. Huge blocks of stone, perfectly smoothed, squared and fitted (often with interlocking corners and other complexities). Try an imagine doing this with nothing but hand tools; it's mind-boggling. It's a tragedy that the Conquistadors knocked much of it down, but there's still quite a bit to see in good condition.The guide's explanation of the religious and astronomical signficance is also quite interesting (and worth getting).

Fascinating blend of indigenous and Spanish cultures. Coricancha was an Inca temple and palace at the height of the Inca empire. The temple was literally paved and plated with gold. When the Spanish invaded Peru, naturally they stripped all the gold and converted the temple into a Catholic church. What survives today is a blended Inca temple-Catholic church, with evidence of both cultures. There's also a fabulous museum of Peruvian Christian art, as well as a modern Peruvian art exhibit. Sadly, your tourist pass won't work here -- you need to buy the ticket separately.

Must see in Cusco. One of the most (if not the most) mythical place in the Inca world: the Temple of the Sun. Unfortunately, most of the original setting has been destroyed by the Spanish but the place still offers remarkable insights in Inca history. Do some reading before or take a guide to optimize the experience. The Temple is within walking distance of the Plaza de Armas.

More history. I hired a guide just outside the Temple, and I'm glad I did. So little is known for sure about the Incas that stories and exhibits were augmented by an explanation. There are small signs, but not much text. You either need a good guidebook (my friends and I used Lonely Planet) or a guide. Takes about an hour and well worth it for the history and the art museum.

mildly interesting for half an hour. The spanish balcony area is quite pleasant but behind this but if you get excited about looking at walls most of which have been reconstructed then this is the place for youFar too packed with tourists wondering what it is they have come to see?

Don't miss. A wonderful contrast of Inca and Incapas construction. But very sad. One of the many examples of "my myth is better than your myth" religious thinking that has been responsible for so much suffering through the centuries.
Get a guide at the entrance. You can walk through on your own, but the guide prices are reasonable and they bring the temple to life. The temple has some of the best workmanship in Peru.

Iglesia del Carmen. Iglesia del Carmen is Located in front of the Alameda Apodaca, this white church might remind any of the South American colonial churches. I used to assist to masses here when I was a little kid, after playing soccer in the marvellous gardens by the seaside...
HIGH VIBRATION. GREAT place for a meditation...I was there on the Summer Solstice. AMAZING! I would spend some extra quiet time here

Once covered in gold, great intro to Inca Architecture. Great guide also selling her own very informative guide to Macchu Pichu outside the gates. Go slow and look around so you can imagine how it may have looked before the Spaniards melted it down.

Amazing historic site. The Inkas were prescient, and their architecture and historic remnants show it all. It helps to have a guide and/or interpreter of the many signs which are in place, because there are mysteries of design which would otherwise be missed.
Overpriced. If you really LOVE lengthy explanations or Catholic art you will love this and it is very worth your $15 US. But if you want the Incan stuff take your photos from the outside.

Ok - Inca site hidden underneath "newer" structures. Sadly enough the Spanish church and the newer church totally mask the Inca site. A few nice things to see but feels like really like a museum - even difficult to dream and imagine how it could have been. Since it is downtown - all tourists in Cuzco are there around 8am-9am.
