Magical. Visited the Temple of the Sun and the surrounding caves. I went with a group of 5-6 as part of a tour. We stayed 2 hours which was plenty if you're trying to just see the area. Could spend all day on the surrounding trails if you're more into hiking. Something magical about this place.
Gorgeous. The cathedral is gorgeous and definitely worth the time. It is sad to see how the beautiful a architecture had been built over by the Spaniards. Definitely worth the time and entrance fee.

Spectacular Construction. To imagine this temple, Qorikancha, was built over 500 years ago and is still standing despite the multiple earthquakes throughout the decades. This truly demonstrates the "to the victor goes the spoils". The removal of any gold or valuables to be shipped back to the Spanish monarchy. The repurposing of the building to meet its conquerors' designs - the second floor, the murals painted on the walls. Yet, we can see the intricate shaping, tongue and groove, and mortar and tendon techniques the Inka society employed in creating this temple. Not to be forgotten, the garden is a vision of beauty. All of this - and only in daylight.Return at night -- and enjoy seeing the building lit up (bundle up first - it's cold)

Fascinating building in the heart of Cusco. Old Incan temple with a church built on top of it. Interesting cutaway exhibits where you can see how the Incans shaped the stones that fit together to support the buildings. Make sure to go outside and see the gardens planted on the steppes.
lovely little church. don´t miss this when visiting Koricancha. It gives a real sense of who lived here and who built the church on the ruins. Lovely altars.

Awesome constructions. Get a guide because there is so much more to learn that what is written on the signs. So much history here between the Inca time and the Spanish colonists. Precise stone work and sadly a reminder of the pillage by the conquerors.

Temple of the Sun...interesting and Beautiful. The history of the Temple reveals that it was the most important temple in the Inca Empire, dedicated primarily to Inti, the Sun God. It was one of the most revered temples of the capital city of Cusco. The building was stripped of its magnificent gold walls and floors, that were described by the Spaniards (who took them) as opulent beyond belief.

Very Interesting. At S/10 per person admission plus S/30 for our group of five to hire a guide I thought this was a bit expensive, but we definitely found the guide helpful for being able to fully understand the historical significance of this site. Qorikancha is an Incan site that was stripped of its gold decoration and built over by the Spanish. The modern roof covering the remains of the Incan temple detracts a little from the atmosphere and you have to work quite a bit to visualise the way it would have been (made easier by the scale model of the site), but the history is definitely still there. There is an art gallery of sorts on the upper level.

Shame it was destroyed but good some remains. Worth seeing this - short walk from Plaza de Armas and shows the detail also of the Inca building quality. It was part of a tour for us that included Saqsaywaman and our guide was able to explain all the details to us very well. Make sure to stand on the stool so you can see the 3 windows lined up.

A clash of cultures. It is worth seeing this display of dissonance where Spanish architecture meets Inka walls. Amazing pre-hispanic architecture and history. Worth a brief visit, but definitely not the most stunning place in Cusco.

Great display of Inca building. As I mentioned in another review, I think it is a little sad how so much of the displays provided in these sites are so biased toward the Spanish colonialism and totally ignores the harm done to the Quechua culture in the process. That being said, this museum does a very good job showing the technique that is unique to the Inca (Quechua) sites -- the interlocking, smoothed stone blocks. Very interesting and informative. Also of interest is the collection of art created by local Quechua artists who were not allowed to sign their work (they weren't Spanish, after all!) but who were able to put their cultural stamp on so many of the paintings -- people of color, coca leaves in the paintings hidden in plain sight, Quechua symbols of the sun and moon. Beautiful.

Nice architectural interpretive displays. The paintings were nice but not memorable; not a disappointment that no photos of the painted artwork were allowed. We enjoyed the architecture and I especially liked the display of "building blocks" used by the Incas. You don't need to plan to spend a lot of time here, but it's definitely worth a visit.

A must in Cusco. This is a great visit in Cusco. Grab a tour guide and learn about the most important place in Cusco. Try to imagine all the idols and ornate gold and silver that there used to be. The coolest thing I thought was "the smallest stone in the Inca empire."

Interesting place. You need some imagination to picture the Inca ceremonies which have taken place there, but still, the remains of the temples are superb, and it's the most impressive Inca masonry in the Historic city centre. We didn't hire a guide, there are explanations along the visit, and if you have a Lonely Planet or a guide book, you can really male it on your own.

great place to start. Great place to start your cusco adventure. It has a lot of great art work, and will make you start to appractie the Inca construction work. Also great old architecture work, there are always alot of people but it flows nicely.
Lovely church. Built by the Spanish on the site of an Incan temple, this building has some fantastic art and artefacts.
Incredible!. Wow is theonly thing I could say when entering the church. Modestly adorned outside but the equivilent of the best European cathederals inside
A great site. Amazing what the a Incas built. Allow an hour to take in the scenery & architecture. Wear you walking shoes. Be prepared to be hassled at the end to buy souvenirs.

Unique feature of Macchu Picchu. The curved rock face with the three level alter underneath wa an amazement of the Inca culture. the placement of the stones showed it was a very holy place as they were perfectly matched.

Catch your breath and see history on your first day in Cusco. It is a good starting point to learn about the history of the Spanish invasion of this area. It's a nice quick breather on your first day at high altitude however it is not as moving as other sites are, including just sitting and people watching in the plaza. I would recommend that when you do go you hire your own tour guide. Many people do this as part of a bigger tour, which I would not recommend as you can never really hear or understand what the guide is trying to communicate when there are too many people. Although this site is lovely, I would not say it's a must do especially if you have other tiring activities on your itinerary.

Some remains within the Spanish church. The Spaniards built around this site, but there are still Inca walls which they used, covered in frescos (which are removed after damage from an earthquake) and did not tear down. Worth seeing.

A good guide helps. We were shown around by a guide obviously proud of her native Peruvian past and indignant (putting it mildly) about the Spanish invasion. But she did it with an ironic sense of humour.See a famous stone (there are several all over Cusco) with twelve corners, it is incredible. Visit the museum, it will probably be on the same ticket, but it is nowhere as good as the site itself.

Two attractions in one: Inca Temple and Spanish Monastery. This is probably one of the strangest combinations of two so much different cultures in one place. What is even more strange both are beautiful. Taking photos is not allowed but nobody, including guards, cares. Do not miss the gardens - this may be also opportunity to find toilets. Ticket for an adult us 10 soles.

get a guide. Ignatio, an english speaking guide stopped us at the door, and offered to take the 4 of us around on a tour for $30 including entrance fees. Money well spent as he was able to explain things and get us in and out in around 45 minutes. Amazing culture, architecture, and history.

Once a great building. Unfortunately not much remains of Qoricancha. It is hard to believe that this was once the most important building in the entire Incan Empire. The best views is from outside, where the beautiful curve of superior Incan stonework sticks out under the Spanish church above. You need a ticket to fully explore Qoricancha. A large cloister conceals a few more Incan walls. Upper levels have been turned into an art gallery. There is not much explanation in English and the importance of the site isn't explained well. There is a beautiful painting of the Milky Way and how the Inca's interpreted the stars.

Interesting mix of Spanish and Inca. Santo Domingo Church sits on top of Qoricancha (The Incan Temple of the Sun). This baroque church was incorporated into it's predecessor in the 17th C. It is a bit dark inside. Cloisters extend into the Qoricancha area, some were removed to reveal more of the ancient Incan remains. The two sites blend into one but the church is free but a ticket barrier stops you from wandering into the Qoricancha part.

Luckily the Spanish left SOMETHING... ( hint- not much! ). The Temple of the Sun was the most sacred of all religious compound of the Incans. At the time of the Spanish conquest, it consisted on numerous one story temples who's interior walls were lined with entire sheets of gold and housed many gold idols and religious symbols. The Spanish immediately pried the gold from the walls and, together with the idols, melted them to pour into gold bars. Needless to say, this was desecration of the highest order to the Incan population, who were aghast with shock.Then the Spanish leveled all but a scant few temples and constructed an enormous church on the site. For some reason, they left a few of the temples, which were used as domestic chambers for the clergy until earlier this century. They also built another floor and story over one set, until thankfully an earthquake significantly damaged the colonial structure which then allowed for the Incan temples to be made available for public viewing ( of course, the Incan stonework held perfectly! ).A must see for all who visit Cusco and have an interest in Incan history. However, either read the historical accounts, or hire a guide or else you will not understand what is to be seen.

Awed by the skill of the Incas. Start with the Incas' wall in the narrow lane and compare their workmanship with that of the Spanish at the higher level: "Inca versus Incapable" about sums it up!Then have a guide show you what to look at, otherwise you miss quite a lot. My bonus was watching from above school students practising for their June festival on the grass plot on the town side. The church was secondary for me.

Great to see from the outside, the inside is less interesting. Honestly, I got a bit bored here. It's beautiful from the outside but the inside is a sparse museum with little detail. It's interesting to see the Spanish buildings on top of the Incan ruins but there is not a lot of information. There's some beautiful religious art, if that's your thing. My husband enjoyed it, but I would skip it.

The heart of the Incan empire. The temple of the sun - variously spelled with a C, Q or K - was the most important temple within the entire Incan empire, so naturally the conquistadores stripped it of gold and silver, and built a Dominican church on top, as part of their programme to destroy the indigenous culture and impose a Spanish Christian one. Originally the walls and floors were entirely covered in precious metals, but that was all removed and melted down 500 years ago. Since the Incans were not ones for decorative carvings, you have to use your imagination quite a bit here, as sadly all that remains are part of the outer wall and some internal structures, with a colonial-era cloister and church planted on top. The Incan stonework in the Qoricancha is of amazing quality and it's almost embarrassing to see the relatively poor quality of the church construction, heavily reliant on thick layers of mortar to hold it together. To get the most out of this its best to hire one of the freelance guides loitering outside for around S/20 (£5) - this is on top of the entrance fee of about the same - although take some of what they say with a pinch of salt. The "altar for sacrificing llamas" is clearly far too small to do any such thing, for example. The Dominican church itself is also worth a look although it pales in comparison with the cathedral and the Jesuit church on the Plaza de Armas, and it does of course contain the usual gory, blood-soaked Andean Catholic iconography. As with all Andean church sites, no photography is allowed inside, either with or without flash.
Very cool how they protected both. Nice to see they've rebuilt part of the Incan stuff and kept the Spanish portions as well. Definitely a good site to see the bridging of the two cultures.

Awesome - and probably worth getting a guide/tour. Whilst the structure and the combination of Inca masonry and colonial architecture is in itself unlike anything else I have seen, to get the most out of your visit I would suggest a guided tour to appreciate and understand the significance of the site. I didn't, and wandered around just lost in trying to absorb the stories and history from the stones. Like most places in Peru, there is limited signage to inform you of your surroundings.Dirt cheap for what it is though
Another special Inca site. We found every single Inca site we visited with our 70% Inka heritage guide to be fascinating and enlightening. One of our best trips ever.

Need to use your imagination. This is an original Inca site that was built over by the Spaniards, and they also removed the gold from the walls, so you need to exercise your imagination to see how the inner temple might have looked originally.There are some useful insights into Inca architecture and building techniques, and interestingly the Inca parts were the only ones to survive the Cusco earthquake in the 1950s.N.B. We visited as part of a pre-paid tour group with guide. I don't know how interesting it would be for independent travellers with no guide as there are no info. boards to tell you what you are looking at.

Melding of two cultures. It was a really cool structure that melded the Incan culture with the Spanish culture. It was amazing that the Spanish portion was destroyed in the earthquakes and the Incan parts remained. Some beautiful artwork as well. Cool views of Cusco. Our guide spent forever here explaining every different stone, which got really boring really quickly. I would not recommend a guide.
Good tour. Our guide give us a good knowledge of the 'Inca' history as he knows it,and had plenty of time to take it all in.

Spanish monastery meets Incan temple. Easily identifiable on the outside, the Incan stonework of their temple and what remains beneath the Spanish "domination" is well worth the visit. Be sure to get up close to the Incan walls so you really can see/feel how great their work was.

not that interesting. Made the mistake of getting a guide here and not the Cusco Cathedral. Don't need a guide here because the signage is in English. Not much to see, especially if you've come from other ruins.

A monument to the Spanish conquest of the Incas.. This was a major Incan temple on top of which the Spanish conquistadors built a church. Beside the church is a museum of sorts that show the significance of the Incan architecture that is prevalent in all of the ruins you'll see in/around Cusco.
amazing temple of the sun... Great incas architecture and excellent local guide, we meet Amadeo and he is just a fantastic guide he took us back in history with all his valuable information.

Temple encased in a church. I had seen several churches by the time we visited the Temple of the Sun so I was a little disappointed when I entered this building. There was people offering to guide you around, for a price of course, but it was quite easy to read the displays for yourself. Most had English translation as well.

Old and new. An amazing place to visit, you can see original incan architecture, we did this as a tour which is recommended so you know what you're looking at. This amazing Temple is now a church, it's a must see whilst in Cusco.

Great way to see how the Spanish added to existing Incan structure. did a private tour with our guide. Great to get up-close to the original Incan ruins that the Spanish then built around. Nice view of the city from the terraces. Worth the time to spend there.

Interesting to behold. This was probably our favorite site to visit in Cusco. We had a guide with us on our tour of the site and I think this certainly added to our appreciation of what we were seeing. The preservation of the site is impressive as is the history behind it. It truly is a wonderfully interesting place to visit and I would highly recommend seeing it. I would also recommend a guide as the cost is well worth what you get in return.

Very interesting - go with a guide!. This was a fascinating tour - I highly recommend you to visit the Temple of the Sun in Cusco. You can see the different architecture (Incan and Colonial,) and how the Incan architecture has withstood earthquakes and the test of time. Get a guide though, it's much more interesting if you know what you're looking at. It's worth the small fee.

Hire a Tour Guide at the front door!. We showed up for a quick tour of the Temple (now church). There were a couple of independent tour guides at the tour. We found someone who spoke wonderful English and she gave us a private tour for 30 soles ($11). Great deal. She made the building come to life. Wouldn't have understood what we were looking at without her. The Inca Stone Work inside is the best in Peru! This what the heart of the Incan Empire. You must check this one off the list. Cheers!

Well worth visiting. The Inca ruins form the base of the church & convent of Santo Domingo. The walls that the Incas built were perfectly straight – no cement was used - you couldn't even insert a dollar bill between the stones.

A real eye opener. This was one of the first Inca sites we visited in Cusco and described how those amazing walls were constructed. Two more modern paintings illustrated the temple sites along lines emanating from Cusco, the centre, and the importance to the Incas of the 5 animals to be seen in the Milky Way.
Very cool! Most important: get a guide. . It's incredible the incan architecture. But, pay for a guide at the entrance. Believe me, it's worth it.

You have to see it. Corincancha is full of energy. The greatest confirmations came from visiting this site. Walking is easy. You can arrange for several locations for one day and Corincancha can be one.
Interesting. Good for a short visit. Get a guide if available, otherwise just ask the guards in every room, they usually know a lot and don't expect any tips.

Beautiful Church in the heart of Cusco. Baroque is the name of the style for the churches in Cusco and the Sacred Valley. The workmanship is amazing and the completeness of the designs with amaze you.

A Close-up View of Amazing Inca Architecture. From the outside you would not know what remains of the Inca temple, with the only clue being the massive foundation of grey stone blocks now surmounted by the Spanish monastery. But after passing through the entrance in the monastery you quickly arrive at a grassed courtyard surrounded by the foundations and lower-level rooms of the temple. What immediately impresses you is the precision with which the builders placed the blocks forming the walls of the rooms. In one of the rooms several shaped blocks are placed on the floor for easy viewing. In another there is an intricate model of what the whole building looked like in Inca times. Rooms on the other side of the courtyard displayed Inca artifacts in gold, copper and stone. This is a site not to be missed in a visit to Cusco!

So much history! and an amazing building. After learnign about the history of this amazing place, I felt sad learning how beautiful it must have been with all the gold ornate sculptures and furnishings before the Spanish came and took them all - sad but its a place not to be missed
Interseting place. Interesting place to walk around in the centre of Cusco. Yet another example of the precision building of the Incas

Fascinating. Loved this place. The basement museum (part of the boleto touristico) is small but interesting and the part in the Dominican monastery is brilliant. I didn't have a guide but I got plenty out of it as there are many explanations in Spanish and English. The restored Inca ruins are certainly impressive and the religious art provides a nice contrast. Well worth the price of admission.
Good start to Inka history. Another must see area prior to Machu Picchu. The ruins provide insight to the Inka way of life. A guide or self guide book/app is must.

An interesting mix of architectures. Lima Tours took us to this location as part of a Cuzco tour. The tourist part is on land owned by a functioning monastery, so you visit less of the buildings than you see from the outside. We had a knowledgeable tour guide from Lima Tours take us through. I recommend either a tour guide or a book to help you understand what you are seeing.

In disguise!. During the Spanish conquest the Conquestadores and the Catholic Church did everything to thoroughly destroy the Inka culture. They built a convent around the remains of the Sun Temple. The area was closed off for public access until around 1980 (!!!) gives an insight into contemporary Catholic Church attitudes. The remains of the temple give proof of the high level of Inka culture.

Holy Moly - So similar to Sakkara. Anyone who has visited Imhotep's temple at Sakkara, Egypt, will be BLOWN AWAY by how similar the architecture of the Temple of the Sun is. Can this possibly be coincidence?!? And even if you haven't, marveling at the skill of these bronze age builders is worth the time. Nice to go with a guide who can describe what's what, otherwise you are just looking at very well made bricks.

Must-see in Cusco. This is a great place to spend your afternoon in Cusco. You can see the Incan, Spanish, and Arabic influences all in one place. It provides a great opportunity to learn more about the Incan empire, and I was very impressed with the architecture of the site. I did not have a guide because we were not sure how much time we wanted to spend there, but I would definitely recommend one if you are into that sort of experience.

My favourite site in Cusco. This is a beautiful site which demonstrates very well the melding of Incan and Spanish culture. This is a must-see site because of the near-complete Incan buildings housed inside. Also, the large Incan bricks are incredible to behold.
interesting. Quite good to see. Not a lot there though + you do need a tour guide to explain it in detail or you would miss out
learned soo much here. again, go with a guide, you will walk away with a greater appreciation and a lot more info about what you are looking at.

Nice church on better Incan ruins. We didn't find anything special about this church; what is special about the site is that the church was founded on the old Incan site of Koricancha. As such, seeing the two next to and on top of each other gives you an historical insight into how the two cultures "co-exist" today. Walking around Koricancha will invariably give you an opportunity to take in the church.

A must visit to understand the Incans. This set of ruins is historically important for the reason that the Incans established this site as the heart of their empire, with its head at Sacsayhuaman, a short few kilometers up the hill. The stone work is impressive. We went with a guide and cannot imagine gaining a good understanding of the importance of the site without one.

Merging of the cultures and the walls. We came here as part of the City Tour, which is almost mandatory as a tourist in Cusco.Probably the most interesting aspect of this attraction is the merging of the two empires, ie. The Inka and the Spanish, as both are represented in this most sacred site. You will find superb examples of Inka architectural walls, sitting next to Spanish colonial architecture. There are also several colonial paintings and pottery, and of course the colonial gardens. As the years go by these sites are becoming more restricted, with many areas roped off that you could wander around freely a few years ago, and other items placed behind glass, probably at the behest of the Heritage Society.

If you love gaudy Catholic stuff it's great. I just happen not to. There is very little left of the actual temple. If it was $5, or free, I'd say go, but it's more expensive than that. You can't take pictures of most of it.

Lovely location, introduction to inca walls. This temple has largely been replaced by the Santo Domingo monastery which is built on top of it. But after the latest earthquake some remains have been restored and it is possible to see the inca building techniques in a number of small buildinsg within the compex. Also parts of the rounded surrounding inca wall is clearly visible outside.

Wonderful. This was the building that was stripped of its gold façade by the Spanish. The gold and silver used to decorate their temples and icons held no monetary value, it was only decorative. The gold was used to honour the Sun God. Very interesting tour, the Incan culture was much more advanced than the Spanish led the world to believe.
Seeing Inca construction up close. This site is incorporated into the Convento De Santo Domingo Del Cusco. It's more museum than archeological site but worth a visit.

Important Inca Heritage. This ancient Inca temple is just one of many ruins in Cucsco, but it is by far the most important one. If you want to get a feel for that civilization's greatness come here, take a guided tour and see the paintings that depict their history.

emple of the Sun (Coricancha). an important Inca temple complex located in the capital city of Cusco, Peru and dedicated to Inti, the sun god of the Incas.The complex was built on a natural hill in the sacred city of Cusco, between the Shapy-Huatanay and Tullumayo Rivers. It was said to have been constructed under the direction of the Inka ruler
Build on Inca Ruins. This church was built on the existing Inca wall as was discovered after an earthquake. As such it is a really good place to see Inca stone work as well as not a bad church.

Interesting and nice merge. The view of Koricancha is really amazing and strange at first, two completely different architecture style together, the old inca wall and the spanic church, it makes it a unique place, even tough I would prefer to see the old inca temple untouched by the spanish conquerors, the tour inside the church worth it, the details of the spanish and the strong and raw inca construction, makes you go back in time and try to imagina how was it a long time ago.Also there you can find the smallest stone used by the incas in a construction, and of course a lot of people touching it for it supposed energy.I really recommend Koricancha, the tour is not so long and you have plenty of time to see the whole place, Have Fun and enjoy it !!!

Incan engineering at its best. The walls of the old temple were built more than 600 years ago. Cusco has been razed to the ground by 2 earthquakes: one in 1650 and one in 1950. These walls still stand. I absolutely agree with other reviewers, to understand the nuance and the detail of what you're looking at, go with a guide. But go.

You do need a guide to understand this fascinating site. There is a model of the Inca era version of this attraction inside and it is useful to see it to understand the nature of how the Spaniards tried to adapt it to their own culture and religion. There are some of the finest examples of Inca wall building.

A Beautiful Legacy. This place chokes me up for a multiplicity of reasons. First, it boasts exquisite architecture the subtleties are at first hard to notice but once shown, are hard to get out of your mind. Second, the meaning of the site. It was their most holy temple, built on top of an older pre-Incan site, it housed not only representations of their theology, and the holy families, but also their ancestors in the form of mummies. Third, the history of the site. This proud legacy was abruptly stamped out by the Catholics who started ripping down the site to use for their church (which is built around it) and they burned the Incan ancestors forcing the inhabitants to watch. If you are in Cusco you have to see it.

Don't miss this site. Again, local guide with a terrific knowledge of the building. I can not really add to the previous comments but to say, if visiting get a local guide and enjoy the marvels of the Inca's.

Easy to see ruin. Great to see such an interesting ruin right in the heart of the town. We hired a English speaking guide at the entrance for 30S and it was worth it as there was no literature telling you about the place. It is small, doesn't take long, but very interesting history.

Worth checking out (was there in September 2012). My friend and I visited this temple with a nominal fee. The tour guide was a little too expensive so we opted to check it out ourselves. We probably spent a good couple of hours if not less. It was a very close walking distance from Plaza des Armes and worth checking it out. Has a great view of Cusco too!

Spanish church on top of Inca temple (in September 2012). My friend and I went to Santo Domingo Church. We paid the admission fees but had decided to forgo the guided tour. It was a little pricy for what we were willing to pay if I recall but from what I saw of the guided tours there, they sounded informative. The stonework that remains in this church is stunning and the view from the top is breathtaking. Also be sure to check out the museum next door. This was one of the very few museums/churches we visited and I would recommend visiting this site.

The place to be!. We were leaving really close to this Temple but have visited it only on last day of our adventure. It's amazing how 2 different cultures are moxed there and you easily see how techologies of Incas (or whoever constructed it) have been more advanced than Spanish.

Boring, crowded. Not much too see here and compared to the main cathedral in Cusco, this place just isn't that impressive. Our tour guide had to really play it up to keep anyone in our groups interest.
Temple of the Sun.. It is worth going up because there is a nice view over Cusco but the temple itself is interesting only. Don't forget that there you are about 3800 m up so you can tire fast.

Church built on Inca ruins. Like many of the buildings around Cuzco this Church was built on top of Inca ruins which still are available to see and support most of the structure. Some of these ruins were unveiled after an earthquake which they withstood but not "modern" structure that was built on top of it. Interesting place to learn about Inca architecture.

A Striking Merger of Cultures. The church of Santo Domingo, finished in 1654, was built on the site of the richest temple in the Inca empire, Qurikancha ("Golden Courtyard"). The temple was not only used for various religious rites, but served as an observatory for the high priests to monitor celestial activity. Some of the remaining chambers adjacent to the courtyard were dedicated to the moon and the stars, and to thunder and the rainbow. The Spanish colonialists intentionally chose this site, and destroyed most of the Inca temple in the building of the church, in order to further suppress the Inca religion. However, not all of the temple was destroyed. The original tightly interlocking, mortar free, stonework that remains is regarded as some of the finest Inca trapezoidal architecture in Peru. The temple was dedicated primarily to the Inca Sun God, and the main courtyard was covered with hundreds of gold sheets. All of the gold was later stripped and melted down to pay the Spanish a ransom for the life of the Inca leader, Atahualpa, who nonethelesswas later excuted by the Spanish following a mock trial.

Acceptable. since i had already been to machu picchu by the time the travel agency took me to the coricancha, it wasn't so impressive. Ok, it wasn't impressive at all. It was quite disappointing after seeing the lost city, in comparison to it of course. Ah, and it was crowded. Apparently, because of it's location (inside cusco) it is to easy for the tourists and agencies to get there, and they DO GET THERE. Believe me.
Peru Tour and Inca Trail. I like the plaices and templo of Qoricancha is beautifull I thing is much better all the entraces ticket pay just

crowded and our guide was not great, bad combo. The Coricancha, I am afraid, did not get our best attention. It was Sunday and packed. Our guide was not great, rushing us around and not waiting for the group to gather before launching in to her script. Maybe another set of circumstances would have improved my rating. Hard to say whether it was the Temple or the guide that deserves the average (or below) rating. Best to go yourself and see.

Worthless Museum. The Boleto Turistico gives you access to the Coriconcha museum, but not the site itself. The museum is five dingy, cramped, smelly rooms underground. Very little explanation, even in Spanish (almost no English) and when we asked how we get to Coriconcha, they told us we had to walk around the side, and pay an additional 10 soles per person to see the actual site. What a load of crap!

Koricancha. The navel of Cusco. His name would be written in Quechua: Q'orikancha.Formerly, the Incas Cusco said that would be the navel of the world. The Koricancha is therefore the most important religious center of Cusco.Currently, unfortunately is occupied by the Catholic Church and its income is regulated by such an order.Inside you can see the foundations of the original enclosures. Great quality of its walls with a finish that causes those who visit admirancion fine. I have visited many times, one of those hours I was and still provoke much admiration.If you want to know the local culture, you must visit the Koricancha.

Machu Picchu experience. The Temple of the Sun is one of the amazing sights at the Machu Picchu location. Part of the "Lost City of the Incas", it shows the stonework craftmanship of the Inca architests and work force. The entire city of Machu Picchu, located at the top of the mountain (about 6,500 ft) leaves one in awe and wonder, at what the Incas accomplished with very limited tools. A must for any world traveler. One of the 7 modern wonders of the world.
Interesting mix of colonial and Inca. A great place to start learning about the Incas and then the Spanish colonialism. We loved seeing the original Inca walls and temple area.
Must see. Students get half off on their tickets, must have id. Beautiful square. Great history, but don't need a guide. You can get a pamphlet at the entrance and work your way around.

Superb cathedral visit in Cuzco. Awe-inspiring trappings including huge silver altar and painting of Last Supper with meal consisting of guinea pig and corn beer. Be sure to go btween 6 and 9 am when admission is free, and enjoy the mass if so inclined.

Average Display of History!. We were not impressed with this piece of history. It didn't meet up to my expectations. The historical significance of this structure wasn't apparent during the tour. Looks nice from the outside, but the inside is boring.

Inca Hispanic blend at its best. This is a must see to understand the Inca-Colonial blend in Cusco both in architecture, history, culture. If you can look past the tragedy of the colonization you can see the beauty of blends

Inside you will find part of an Incan temple. The Spaniards built their Catholic church on top of an Incan temple. They used rocks from the temple to build their church. Inside you will find amazing architecture from both the Spaniards and the Incas. Also they have a collection of art and frescos. Outside they have a garden with all kinds of beautiful plants and flowers. I would defiantly suggest taking a guided tour. Our was about an hour.

Good introduction to ancient culture. A great tour and important to give you a foundation of the culture, & subsequent Spanish culture. It really put things into perspective but you need a guide. A great start to any Peruvian tour. You can see both architectural & technological developments if the Incas & Spanish.

Architecture Overview. A tour here gave us a splendid overview of the construction methods used in the 1500-1600s. Wow! We visited on a very rainy day , but that didn't hamper our tour since there were plenty of covered walkways. I'd say this is a must see for those who want to better understand the history of the area.

Don't try to enter. If you are thinking to visit ALL these nice churches around the Municpalidad of Cusco, be aware you will be charge before entering.ALL of them have a FEE. (I know you can bargain for a souvenir or so ...but to enter the house of God! - they will get your money.

One of the best places to see in Cusco!. We were not aware of this place until our server Manuel at the JW Marriott told us about it during breakfast. It was easy to find and with a 10 soles (each) admission a gem to find. You will be hassled at the front doors for a private tour of an additional 20 soles (each) - but we chose not to bother. It was relaxing and just beautiful. You could see the surrounding Mountains they gave a beautiful back drop. A must see!!

Gothic renaissance style. This ancient church is quite a sight. The architecture is worth commending. The building stands on the site of an Inca palace, and was built from stone blocks removed from the nearby Inca city of Sacsayhuaman by the triumphant conquistadors.The most famous artwork is a Last Supper painting by Marcos Zapata featuring a meal of local guinea pig served with an Inca corn beverage.

Great place to visit. This was once the most important temple in the inca empire, dedicated to Sun. One can only imagine how well this place would have been with gold in walls and floor. Spanish colonist built a church using some of the Incan walls and foundation giving it the unique blend.

Breathtaking!. This ancient catholic church is simply amazing. There are many very old churches in Cusco, but this one will just blow you away. The architecture, style, gold leaf and intricate detail are incredible, especially when you realize how old the structure is and the effort it would have taken back then to build such an amazing cathedral. It's worth seeing.

Loved the Gardens. The ancient Incan Temple of the Sun, Qorikancha, remains only in ruins and a curved sanctuary wall now, but the gardens terracing down from these heights to the street below are very relaxing and attractive. There's a convent sitting on top of the ruins now - delightful in its own right - and the entire area is worth a visit.
Great Incan Preview. we visited here on our first day of the visit.Provided such great grounding of culture, architecture and prepped us for the following 5 days
Lovely. Staring point for our tour. Great place to look through history and religion…..love beautiful old cathedrals for all the vastness, symbolic references

a "must see" in Cuzco city. The history of this site just sparks the imagination. We saw it in passing without really knowing what it was for days. Basically, Koricancha was the "Temple of the Sun" of the Incas at the time when the Spaniards first arrived. According to written records the temple was filled with life-size trees, lamas, people etc. solid gold statues. You could imagine the effect of this sight upon the gold crazy Europeans. To the Incans however, gold was not valued the same way. It had religious significance especially in association with the Sun god, Inti. Hence the whole temple was filled with gold. There is a legend that there was a giant gold disc, larger than an man, at one point. It was positioned in the temple such that when the sunlight hits it through some window opening, the disc would scatter the sunlight and bath the whole inside of the temple in a golden glow. This disc mysteriously disappeared between the time of the first party of Spaniards arriving and the main contingent. It has never been found .... I feel an Indiana Jones movie coming on. How cool is that?! Ok, I'm side tracking. Anyway as with everything else the Spanish conquistadors did to demoralize the locals, they dismantled most of the temple and built a Dominican monastery over the top of it. However, they did keep the foundation and some of the walls of the temple and just incorporated it into the monastery. So the effect is rather unique. You really get to see a good example of Incan building technology that is different than most other Incan ruins elsewhere. The Temple of the Sun was an important building in the heart of Cuzco, the capital of the Incan empire. The lines are much more uniform and regular than other places. It's just 10 Soles to enter here. It's well worth a visit.

Knowing San Martín de Porres. I read the history of San Martín de Porres, when i visited this Church, My knees was injured in Anamanti Island but i enjoy My vacation, the burn, pain, was cured. Visit and require the Help of San Martín, and wait the answer!

Beautiful views. For only 10soles this is a can't miss. Their art work on display is beautiful, both the catholic and Incan. The gardens were lovely, and they had lots of information on plaques throughout. We enjoyed it a lot.

Sunny View. This is a must see if you visit Cusco...We enjoyed it more than any of the other attractions. Very interesting juxtaposition of the Incan stones and the later Convent buildings. Definitely get one of the English speaking guides at the entrance. For just 30 soles ($10 or $5 for each of us) you'll get a succinct overview. We especially enjoyed the talented paintings of the saints and religious figures...done by students here and all attributed to "Anonymous". Touching.

"Two Temples in One". The name "Qoricancha" (Quechua for "Golden court-yard") suggesting that in Inca times the place, originally decorated with sheets of gold and silver, saw the emperor strolling among figures and animals in a garden of corn plants made from these metals and inlaid with precious stones... The Spaniards, having no use nor respect for this type of beauty, melted it all down to form bullion to be ship away. Only the smoothly curved shaped walls, amongst the finest in Inca architecture, remained, and served as the base to the Santo Domingo Convent, church and cloister. While the Inca structure stood both earthquakes (1650 and 1950), the church was demolished first and its later reconstruction badly damaged in the second instance.As we went to visit the site with our private guide, Angel, we were impressed by the Inca structure (oddly having as background the cloister and the bell-tower of the church). In any case, we enjoyed visiting the various temples (of the Moon, of the Sun, of Lightning, Thunder and Rainbow) while listening to the historic information provided by our guide.We also enjoyed the wall paintings depicting the "Four Corners of the Inca World" and "the Milky Way" with its magic spirit-animals aligned in constellations. A copy of the original big, golden plaque illustrating the Inca symbols is also in view.

Archaeologists dream. This temple and church is an utterly fascinating location to visit. The rumour that is used to be covered in gold is probably unfounded (further research may prove otherwise though?) but the Inka stonework is truly beautiful. The curved wall is a feat on engineering and pretty much unique. The staff are helpful, they even provided us with a ladder to help with our work, and the guides that are available for hire are well worth it. Mid-morning and afternoons are very busy, so come early and witness the crazy Cuzco rush hour whilst youre at it. Quite expensive to get in and not an option on the Cuzco 'tourist ticket' but worth a visit. The giftshop is hilariously tacky too!

One of my favourite sites in Cusco!. We had chosen to visit Koricancha as our first big site in Cusco. We hadn´t really read too much information on it so we decided to get a guide (you chose one out the front- we paid S./30 i think). 100% worth it! There is not really any signs or descriptions about the building and original walls, and unless you had read information on it previously- it would seem rather dull. For us, we wanted to learn about the Inca beliefs before going to Machu Pichu and this was a good way to start. The tour was mostly on the bottom floor. The top floor is a art muesum now and we didn´t go up there although it is included in the entrance ticket. Unfortunately you cant visit the whole building as it is still being used as a convent in one section.I would highly recommend visiting the Koricancha as one of the more important sites in Cusco!

A wonderful experience. Hire a private guide to truly appreciate its significance and rich history. Many symbols involved in this place. Great place for pictures. Only downside was the great amount of school children attending the site during our visit. This as well as the other tourist groups created traffic jams inside the place. Also restrooms are not easily accessible. Place is not accommodating to people in wheelchair which is a shame.

A must in Cusco. This is the most important site in Cusco, the center of it all for the Incas. We hired a guide (30 soles) and highly recommend it to understand and appreciate the significance of the place.

Do not miss this!. We've visited our share of ruins and catholic monasteries, but in this place they share the same space which makes it quite unique and hauntingly beautiful. It costs almost nothing and is only a five minute walk from the Plaza de Armas. Try to go late in the afternoon to avoid the tour groups and soak up the tranquility and history of this unique treasure.
Fascinating place. We really enjoyed seeing this place, but we wouldn't necessarily recommend paying extra for a guide.

Easy to see while you are in Cusco. It's worth a visit if you are in Cusco anyway.It is a very important site, but for me, it didn't capture my imagination. We decided not to have a guide because we found it pricey (we were asked for 30 soles and the ticket price for two people was 20 soles) and thought that we would wander through on our own with the help of the Lonely Planet guide. It was nice to wander around. However, I felt like I really missed out on appreciating the site because the significance of different parts of the ruins aren't explicit to the non-historian. Maybe this site is worth getting a guide to get more out of the experience.

must see. imagining this temple the way it was originally covered in gold is amazing.. The Spanish really messed things up.There is good examples of original Inca architecture in here so I highly recommend see it

Temple of the Sun of the Incas (Coricancha) in Cusco, Peru. The Temple of the Sun of the Incas (Coricancha) is believed to be the most important temple of the Incan empire, and the most revered temple in Cusco. Unfortunately, when the Spaniards came, they built the Church of Santo Domingo on the site demolishing the temple, and using its foundation for the cathedral. From the outside, the walls of the original temple (clearly of Incan masonry technique of very closely interlocking stones without mortars) can be seen. Inside the site, are some of the temples (most probably reconstructed or restored) depicting the precise and incredible masonry building techniques of the Incas. Some of the structures have significant astronomical significance related to solstices and equinox, and the builiding techniques appear to have been made by tools beyond the capabilities of the Incas. When visiting the site, a guide is a must because there is a paucity of information about the items and structures within the site.Walking outside the Church of Santo Domingo, one encounters the other walls of the temple, again built in the characteristic Incan masonry technique. This site incorporates structures important and/or sacred to the Incas, similar to the House of the Sun at Machu Picchu and the Ollantaytambo Temple sites.If you are an Incan history buff, this is a must see attraction. It is very close to the Plaza Mayor of Cusco and the Cusco Cathedral.

Explains the story.. You can really appriciate the timeline of the area here, with both pre and post Inca buildings superimposed on the Inca remains. Really great to see how the Inca walls are put together.

Sacred Incan Site Imposed by Church. This Sacred Incan Site was replaced by a Catholic Church during the Conquest. You can still the remains of this Ancient Sacred Grounds though when you enter the church though. This site is located in the middle of Cusco, so it is easy to visit! Go visit!!!

Impressive Inca masonary foundations. Go visit this if you want to see the stone masonary skills of the Incas on full display. The Spanish wiped out the Inca temples and built their churches on top of the Inca foundations. The church fell down in the earthquake, the Inca foundations survived. They had to rebuild the church.Here you can see the incredible skills of the Incas working with stone; totally flush-fitting stones, smoothly bored holes through solid stones, and foundations that have survived many earthquakes for centuries.An absolute must-see - and it only costs 10 sol to enter.

I don't get why it's so highly rated. This place has minimal information and almost nothing to show of the original Inca structure that once stood here. Given, we didn't hire a guide, but there was almost no signage to tell us what we were looking at. There are no reproductions of the impressive original gold art that once decorated the walls here and made the site so important to the civilization that once used it. For the entry fee, I expected much more. I would not go back. Here's a tip. You can walk around the gardens on the exterior of Coricancha for free. I enjoyed that part the best anyway.

Interesting Inka Temples Inside. It all seems sad that the Catholic Church/Spanish tore down so much in their 'conquest' of the Inkas. After the earthquake in the 1950's you can now see how the cathedral was built over the top of Inka temples and with the use of Inka stonework from other sites. It is a fasinating look at the Inka Temples, stonework and how the stones interlock in a very sophisticated way.

Beautiful but touristy. Of course there would be lots of tourists - but I just wish they would talk more about the original Indian way of life- and not emphasize the Spanish influence so much. They were colonisalized after all, and should have so much pride in the incredible works of their ancestors - which even today's scientists can't fully explain!

Needs work. This is an extremely interesting site, but one thing that often frustrates me in foreign countries with amazing archeological sites is that the "interpretative underground museum" is deteriorating, with poor lights, or burnt-out light bulbs, outdated descriptive placards in ungrammatical English. I know that it can be difficult for these types of sites to fundraise, but there must be some wealthy Cuzcoans or Peruvians that could contribute some funds to this important interpretive center of their rich culture and history.

Impressive, you must visit while in Cusco. It is impressive and there is a lot of interesting artifact to see. But it was busy when we went, with numerous tours and you often felt pushed along by the tidalwave of people. We ended up departing sooner than planned, but were happy with what we saw.
very good. wasn't blown away.. some really cool stuff. I wasn't blown away, however. ps I'm not a big historical museum kind of guy.

Impressive. If you have studied an Inca history, then you know this place is the navel of the navel of the universe. It is the one place in town we found that sort of acknowledges the encroachment of the Spanish on the Inca Empire. For whatever reason here, the Spanish built over, but did not destroy much of the Inca work here, so this is an amazing place to see both Inca and Spanish work. Don't skip this place when in Cusco! Do skip the museum outside and downstairs though!

Interesting place!. It is nice to visit. Very interesting place!The temple provides a view of both June Solstice sunrise and the constellation of the Pleides which rises from here over the nearby peak of Huana Picchu. The Pleides are still important astronomical Andean Symbols relating to crop fertility.

So interesting!. This was so interesting because of the way the church covered up their use of the Quechuan temples! Definitely worth having a guide! You can also compare the building abilities of the Quechuan vs. the Spanish! Ha!

architecture of the Incas. We were only in Cusco for three days, our last day after returning back from Machu Picchu, in our last night, we decided to see the plaza the armas and Coricancha (the temple of the sun) we didn't need to guide, we just walk around and took great pictures. this place is amazing, Cusco has a lot of Inca History, which I could of stay more days to explore more. Since we went in the nighttime, there was not much to do except sightseeing and went inside the church.

historic visit. Get a guide as we did and learn of all the influences and nuances of the Incas and their culture.Was informative and interesting.Didnt like the crowds though, we had to wait a few times to get to certain objects of interest

Oh My!. The cathedral and convent are breathtaking. The artwork is fabulous. There are many interesting stories attached to the structure, and the architecture, which is a mixture of Incan and Spanish, is very interesting. It is lovely outside at night.

Great. This site is not as large as some of the others, but it is equally beautiful and interesting. There is some climbing involved, but not as much as the larger sites. It's manageable. Take your time.

super Interesting but avoid the Guides!. Really amazing place! Its an absolute must if you are really interested in the Incas and peruvian History! Just one piece of Advice....when you go to enter the Coricancha there are lots of guides there willing to take you on a guided tour! We thought what the hell its only 10 soles....but it was honestly the worst guided tour I have ever taken! The guide a lady..rushed us through the whole thing and didnt show us half of it! Infact she told us lots of things that were absolute rubbish.. they only want your money and the faster they go equals more people and more money! save yourself the money and buy a good book or just look on the net! lots of good informative blogs on the Coricancha!

Good to see. If you like the conquistadors and incas history, you should visit this site which mix incas palace and dominican monastery. There is not a lot of explanation inside and you can ask a guide at the entrance.
do it. make sure you get a guide , and get some on ethat isnt in a hurry. take your time going thru, ask lots of questions. i wish i had taken more pics.

A fun mixture of Spanish and Inca culture. A very interesting sight, with lots of insightful examples of mixture of Spanish and Inca culture (e.g. last supper picture with a guinea pig on a plate). Also , great views of the Cusco city from the balcony

Most important inca Site. The site had little Inca components left, a few stone walls on display but our guide, Jesus, said this was the most important site but not the most beautiful. The guide explained the design elements on the Incas which helped with resisting earthquakes. mortar free construction with trapezoid shapes. There were some impressive 16-18 century paintings.

A lesson in architecture. This iconic ruin, substantially restored and in excellent shape, is now part of the Monastery of Santo Domingo, not to be confused with the Cathedral Church of the same name in the same city.At one time it was the main shine of the Inca Empire and presided over by 4,000 priests. When religions clash, temples crumble, and this apparent masterpiece was almost eliminated by incorporation into a monastery serving another God but the Sun. Our excellent guide pointed out the main features of Inca architecture to be observed in what is left and restored of the original: the large carefully carved closely fiting mortar-free brick work inclined on a slight angle to resist earthquake damage; continued upwards with adobe plaster; and crowned with an inverted V-shaped wooden roof; the niches that held decorative and religious objects almost certainly of gold and precious stones; and the evidence of other decorative work in layers of gold probably adorning the walls. There is a lovely broad arcaded courtyard, and as you exit, the terraced landscaped lawns descend majestically to the street below.Many examples abound of the astronomical uses of this space, employing observance and analysis of shadows through slits and shafts shifting with the movement of the earth. Multiple smaller temples dedicated to deities other than the Sun were also part of the larger complex, and some traces still remain. Thus, while a mere shadow of its former glory, there is enough to provide great insight into how Inca Science and Religion worked in co-operation. What is no longer there is a loss that should never have occured.

The Inca church of Cusco. Built on the site of an Incan Temple, this is the most impressive building forming part of the awesome Plaza de Armas in the historic centre of Cusco. It fuses a great deal of Catholic theology with a smattering of Inca superstition. Completed in 1654 after 100 years of construction, using stones from neighbouring Inca temples in the hills around the city. It can be described as a an unorthodox Catholic church that show some interesting pagan Inca influences. The attractive facade has Gothic and Baroque elements. The interior is in the form of a Latin cross and contains many attractive features: a large silver alterpiece; authentic early Spanish paintings, one being a stunning crucifixion in the manner of Van Dyck: a dramatic wooden statue known as the Black Christ whose colour is the result of charring; and a host of later paintings by Inca artists working under Spanish supervision who nevertheless managed to infiltrate several of their works with Inca motifs. Sculptural references to the Inca religion, such as the Sun, and a large stone puma, are also to be found. The sheer size of the space is intimidating, and there is a handsome tower holding a large bell, now cracked, and used only occasionally. I believe that entrance is free but cannot swear to it. In any event, it is not to be missed.
One of the best places on Cusco. Opens only on afternoons. It is an catholic convento and church build on top of an Inka palace ... amazing... really a must on Cusco!

Historically important. I was somewhat disappointed by the items shown on display. Little is left from the glorious past and replaced by the Dominican church built on this site with nothing spectacular compared to the other churches in Cusco.

Really Fun During Inti Raymi. I recommend visiting in June for Inti Raymi. Waiting for the festival to begin at the Temple of the Sun was a little crowded, but we were still able to see all of the dancing and pageantry. It was a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
Bit pricey but worth it. Original stonework and temples since the Inca times, original paintings, loads of history, you could easily spend a good few hours in here.

Not much left to see. The Coricancha was the heart of the Inca empire and there's no doubting the historical significance of the place. Unfortunately you will need a vivid imagination to picture the building in its former glory, since the Spanish demolished much of the original structure. There are admittedly some very fine Inca walls still standing, but those are two a penny in Cusco!
Wasn't sure what to expect!. This is an church built on top of an Incan temple. Unfortunately the Incan remains are very few but still worth a visit if you have time.

Qelqa. Loved the golden 'Qelqa' and our guide, Arturo, made it much more interesting by explaining all about the way the Incas carved their double doors, the trapezoid windows and the way things lined up. Also about the way the Inca walls were designed to withstand earthquakes.
Worth your time to tour!. Take a guided tour to get the most out of your visit. We had a guide and it was part of our overall tour.

A Good Place to see the contrast between Inca and Spanish Building. This was well worth a visit. We found that the outside, which showed the relatively clumsy Spanish building on top of the beautifully done Inca stonework was really revealing. Apparently, the Inca stonework was hidden until an earthquake in the 1950's destroyed the Spanish cladding, but left the Inca walls intact and unruffled.Without all the gold that was said to decorate this temple in Inca times, you had to be prepared to use your imagination, but it is still atmospheric.We found the demonstration of how the Incas interlocked blocks of stone and the wall that survived the earthquake due to interlocking especially interesting.There is also an art gallery on the site, but we preferred to stick with the Inca era.Our guide was very helpful in pointing out key parts of the Temple.

Amazing stonemasonry. This was one of the stops with our private guide. I cannot imagine touring Cusco without some kind of guide as there is so much history tucked in every nook and cranny. The Temple of the Sun is definitely worth seeing. To see how the Inca's constructed these foundation walls so perfectly so many years ago... It's mind boggling! I wish I had taken notes or a recorder with me because I learned so much but retained so little!
a great place to learn about the INKA culture. you definitely need to participate in a guided tour. There you'll learn a lot about Inka architecture, religion and life.

Incredible stonework and interesting history. This site was included in a city tour and we really enjoyed the history and architecture of the site. As the original Incan site was covered with gold prior to the arrival of the Spanish in the 1530's, it must have been an incredible site in the bright Cusco sun. The stonework is incredible and shows the mastery of the Incas - the Spanish used it as the foundation of the Church of Santo Domingo. It has withstood earthquake damage over the years while the church has seen a lot of damage.
Incredible. This place inspires! It's amazing rocks and history can inspire you! It is very beautiful inside and it worth the visit!
Inca site and Dominican convent in one. The convent was built on top of this very important Inca temple which use to house a magnificent gold sun.A must when visiting Cusco city
Educational and eye opening. Great place to learn about Inca history and the effects of Spanish conquest. Must see in Cusco. Highly recommended.
Incredible Ruins. Must see for anyone visiting Cusco, it really showcases the amazing architecture of the Incas, and outside you can get a beautiful view of the mountains around the city.

Watched the Inti Raymi Festival and returned later. This is a very visually stimulating structure that is about a 10 minute walk from the Plaza De Armas. There is an excellent gift shop and Artist display that sells original works. The interior is well lit and shows excellent examples of both Inca and Colonial works. Well worth the cost and the time it takes to explore. Great place for taking memorable photos both inside and on the grounds of Coricancha. This is a must do place in Cusco.

Mixed feelings. This church offers a great way to understand how the Spanish conquest happened in South America. Inside the convent you find pieces of the most important temple of the Inka city, the temple of the sun (Coricancha). You can appreciate how the catholic church was literally built over the Inka temple as a way to show the power of the conquistadors.The church is beautiful but I left feeling angry for what was done to such a great culture in the name of religion.
The temple. This is unmissable when you come here as it is just the most fantastic place and well worth the money to go and see

Decent, need docent.. We did this as part of a larger 1/2 day tour. Sure you can take all the pics you like but it's really helpful in this case to have a guide pointing out some of the more interesting tidbits of the site--not only architectural factoids but things relating to culture of the time, what 'may' have been given the ruins and inability to 'rebuild' perfectly, and how sun, moon, sky all tie together in the meaning of the temple (Temple of Sun includes moon and stars stuff!)--seems a bit of a misnomer but think the site was actually more astronomically related than simply heliocentric :). I agree with others who said this place can get a bit crowded as some of the more interesting/photogenic places are small in size resulting in high peeps density. Good views from the back over Cusco and the eastern Mountains--probably neat looking during sunset. I forget the details of the 16-18 cornered stone (attached, maybe just gee whiz single stone) but guide made a big to-do over it near at one of temple entrances--lotsa nuggest beyond the old tales of gold and sun if you pay attention...

get it in tour. just ask firs aorund for better priceses, be careful because of the altitude, can get U sick, even if U got good fisical condition, the tour guide are well versed, it was like 10 dolars for each, and bilingual, we awere for the peruvian indians, they like to sell U they stuff, but the cualaty some times is not to good or they will tell U that is alpaca(type of wool) and most of the time is acrilic.the inca ruins are wounderful, must see

Great place to see in Cusco. This was an Incan temple, and then it was taken over by the Spanish and a Catholic Church was added to the front - so somewhat of a mixture of architectures. We spent a couple of hours wandering around looking at the Incan building & exhibits as well as artwork from the Catholic additions. We would have spent more time in the outside garden area but hadn't allowed enough time.

Ok, but can get really busy. Basically the Spanish built a cloistered church over the top of the main inca sun temple in Cuzco. The Spanish architecture is not all that impressive. Fortunately much of the inca side remains and they were incredible stone masons. But I found this site ruined by the mass of tourist groups that parade through. Plus there actually is not a lot to see here.
So pretty. The santo Domingo church is lovely. There are several smaller alters within the church that are just exquisite representations of Catholicism. It's free to go in, so why not?

A must see. Qoricancha is a wonder. The Spanish padres who came to settle after pizarro conquered the Inka opted to keep the bottoms of the temples and build their cathedrals above these foundations, so a lot of the original structure of Qoricancha are visible. Worth a peek!
A Must See. Real Incan walls exist here. Our guide encouraged us to touch the stones. Also a modern day painting showing the Incan beliefs regarding The Milky Way. Great view out the back.
very interesting short visit. Worth seeing for a short visit but need an English speaking guide. Fascinating to learn about how detailed the Inca engineering and building techniques were.
Great site!. Wonders built by the Incas! Don't miss it.Between June and August is the best time to visit Peru. Take a bus from Cusco to Puno!

Wonderful lessons. We were on a tour, so saw only the highlights of this terrific site. Whatever good other reivewers have written is true, plus, on one side is a garden with a wide variety of flowering plants. It is best to have someone who knows the history to interpret and expand on what is available here.

Great afternoon activity. This is a beautiful combination of museum and ruins, this is a must see if you are visiting Cusco. Tickets are reasonably priced, and there is much to see. It is a short walk from the main plaza.

Worth a see!. You can tour around this place without a guide. At the entrance they are sitting and will try to convince you to pay extra, but you really don't need to. The exhibits are well marked and have plenty of explanations to read if you are keen to know more. It was a nice stop and we were amazed at the age and sturdiness of this place. Sad that the Spanish destroyed so much when they came here.

Great site, terrible loss for us all.. Qoricancha is one of the best site you will see in Cusco; it must have been spectacular beyond understanding with the 700 sheets of gold hung with intricate carvings and depictions of Inca life. What wonders did the world lose when conquistadors melted those sheets into 2.4 tons of gold bullion split amongst the rude, crude and greedy conquistadors? Ollantaytambo and Moray are also worth seeing. Read how the Peruvian indians learnded to create 8000 varieties of potatoes, 800 varieties of corn and 80 types of Quinoa. That agricultural research at Moray largely enabled them to feed an empire of 100 million people. Other sites are not listed in the choices I could review.

Worth a Visit. We did a tour of this as part of a day tour in Cusco. The tour of this site provides some insights to the Incan history. Some of the items discussed really helped with understanding the other Incan sites and ruins we saw on our trip.

Very Interesting...need guide to appreciate it.. The perfection of the stone structure is amazing. It was brought to life by our guide as he talked about the upper world, the underworld and the world that the Incan ruler controlled that extended from his feet to the upper reaches of his extended arm. See how the alcoves were icons or items for the goods were constructed at the upper world height...love that stuff.

A Different Resurrection. Not far from the Cusco Plaza de Armas is this historically significant site. It is very interesting but hard to understand without a guide or a good written explanation. The Church of Santo Domingo rests on the foundation of the Incan Temple of the Sun. The Spanish had completely covered over the Incan temple using it as a foundation for the Church. An earthquake in 1950 exposed the ruins when the Spanish walls fell and the Incan ones held fast. Today, inside the church you can see the remains of the Incan temple walls, perhaps the finest example of Incan engineering and stonework. You can see how the Inca cut the stones to lock together and how the Spanish built directly on top of those walls. If you are in Cusco, you really need to see this site.
Must see in Cusco. Very interesting but make sure you have a good guide like Fredy from Peru Path so you understand the meaning of Cusco and the amazing Inca culture and how advanced they were.
Sun Temple of the Inkas****. Koricancha is recognized as a sun temple of the inkas, the place show the building where the incas offer different sacrifices to their good Sun.Theresita.Monaco.

Get a guide to show you around. I’m glad I visited the Qorikancha , however I was a little disappointed and would definitely get a guide / tour next time. It was still interesting and the gardens were lovely.

Must see sight in Cusco. Just seeing this place makes me want to go back in time and kick all the Conquistadores in the %$#. Can't believe they converted the center of the Inca civilization into a Monastary. It really must have been a site with all the gold and silver still in place.

Your time is better spent not coming here. This place was very meh. All the guidebooks I read seemed to rate this as a MUST see attraction, but I don't see what the fuss is about. I expected to be much more impressed, even though I had read a little about it beforehand and knew that basically there's not much left of the Qoricancha from the time the Incans were in power. The gardens are pretty and nice but nothing super special...I suppose if we did get a tour guide this MIGHT have been more interesting, but really I felt like there wasn't much to see and sort of wish we didn't waste our time or money (only ten soles BUT STILL) here. I thought the Cusco Cathedral was 100x more interesting and awesome and I wasn't nearly half as excited to see that as Qoricancha. The bathrooms are clean I guess

Same as Santo Domingo really. If you read the reviews on Santo Domingo - count it as the same as this. There's no reason to divy up the sites for they are 1 and the same. There are 3 temples remaining on site and you have no reason not to look in detail as to the fantastic masonry here - still standing - withstanding earthquakes.Thank heavens, that Peruvians take pride in their heritage and opened this site for all to be astonished. The precision with every detail put into these temples shows what fantastic engineers those indigenous people were.Must - see. MUST!

Temple of the Sun.... Spaniards being conquerors not of the Incan type, built on top of the Temple of Sun here - it is a spectacular looking church but what's inside is the best - remains of the original temples - still in splendid shape - a testament to the original masons. The angles, the use of perfectly chiseled stones without mortar - that they are still standing today leaves me in awe. The contrast between church and temple ruins is fantastic.If you come here, you see that the Spaniards were willing and able to force the indigenous people into destroying Sacsayhuaman to build the church with stones from their beloved temple. "Manan intindiqa chu." That's what I think in terms of the destruction that took place - even if the results are a beautiful and mixed church/monastery.

put it on your list. Both the museum and the temple are great things to see. The boletto (recommended) will get you into the Museum only, the temple is another 10 soles but worth it. I suggest getting a guide.

Astonishing, superb place.. I visited this in the first week on March. Nothing is disappointing in Cusco. all buildings, especially Santo Domingo are kept in good shape, fully functional. This is what I loved about Cusco, and Peru, they are very keen about their maintaining their culture and ruins. It is not only tradition, is a a fine mix of old and still functional. I love this building in particular, an old Inca temple gracefully turned into a church, but you wont know it unless you get in and see the old ruins, so well preserved. The structure itself has so much character, inside out, it is imposing from far away still friendly when you approach it. Awesome! Might get crowded at the entrance and it is not very cheap but once you get inside you'll know why. It is very well maintained, extremely clean considering the number of people visiting daily.A must stop while in Cusco.

Hope you like history. I expected an open area but this place is in the heart of Cusco, surrounded by narrow streets and traffic. There are vendors and people dressed in native garb that will charge you to take their pictures all around it, they came running when they saw our large group. On entry we went into the large central courtyard for the initial rundown of the history of the place as main Inca temple in Cusco that was then taken over and partial destroyed by the Spanish and rebuilt as theirs. I found the courtyard the most beautiful and interesting.We went from room to room with our guide giving us detailed history of each temple that was in each part of the place. The contrast between the Inca and Spanish architecture is evident in many places. The detailed history was a bit much for me, I would have rather wandered around more and looked at the impressive paintings under the archways. Don't miss the back gardens, you go out the front and around the outside. You can't go in but it is beautiful to look at, much prettier than the front in my opinion. This is a must see for visitors, but do some research yourself and maybe skip the guide unless you want an in-depth history of the place.
Interesting place. We enjoyed our tour here. It is very crowded. Easy to walk to from the Plaza de Armas.Try to go in the morning before the city tours start.

Fascinating history. A history lesson in one site. The temple of the sun, rainbow and thunder remains, showing the precision Inca masonry work that were revealed,after an earthquake under the Spanish monastery and church that was built over the top of them. Shows that the Incas knew how to build to minimise eathquake damage. Well worth a visit.

Wonderful and educational. I learned a lot at this terrific site and highly recommend visiting. If you are still getting used to the altitude and not staying nearby, take a taxi so you are not too tired by the walk.

Koricancha - Q'oricancha - The place of gold - Temple of Santo Domingo. Q'ori means gold, Cancha means a place, a enclosure of land. Q'oricancha was the most amaizing building ever dedicated to the mos important deity THE SUN!! consider by the Inkas as the most noblest of Gods. Tayta Inty = "Father Sun" along with Mother Earth - Pachamama = Pacha=Time, mama=Mother, both were essential to their profound spirituality.Q'oricancha housed amazing wealth to the eyes of the Spaniards but for the InKas these richness were nothing more then showing off reverence, worship and love. The Inkas believe that gold was the blood of the Sun - Inty and Silver of the Moon - Q'illa. The perls tears of Cochamama - Cocha=Sea - mama= Mother.As Pedro Cieza de Leon describes based on the actual description of the 3 first Spaniards whom set foot in Cusco commissioned by Francisco Pizarro who were sent to oversee the place of which they heard was immensely rich where they could find lots of treasures, gold, silver etc... The richness they witness was absolutely incredible, they couldn't believe their eyes. The people there (being the religious center of the Inka Empire) were dressed basically adorned in gold and precious stones without a care in the world... They welcome them and show the around to calm their curiosity...They were taking to the Q'oricancha - Temple of the Sun, what they had seen was something they couldn't be describe in words... In the Center of the building which it was quite big stood a circle that irradiate blinding light when the Sun set on the center. It was surrounded by a garden which contained replicas of all the natural products grown in all the Tawantinsuyo Empire. There was corn made out of gold exactly as the real one in size and beauty having pearls as kernels, potatoes imitating in gold to the real in color, size and variety, the plants of Q'uinwa - Quinoa - quinua. Q'iwicha, Ollucos etc. etc. all designed in perfect image of the real plants. The building it self was "wallpaper" with sheets of gold and silver.. Woman serve the Sun... Nustas and Mamaconas... Virgins of the Sun, young and old all were dedicated first to the Sun and the Inka their entire lives, chosen from early age, all beautiful, full of pride, well dressed in finery and adorned with gold and silver jewelery.
