Parents will look forward to have their daughters chosen cause was a deep honor to have at least one serving their God- Tayta Inti. As soon as Pizarro arrived chaos came... The Inka people realized for what they came for and tried to give them what they asked to save their lives but it was useless, The Spaniards and the Catholic Church was set to destroy this Empire from within as much as the had destroyed the Islands now Central America. From this Temple of the Sun came to Cajamarca the ransom paid by Atahuallpa to Pizarro for his life. The Spaniards still killed him under the excuse of him betraying their trust.The rest of the gold that was found in all the temples and palaces were melted and sent to Spain. The Disk of the Sun - Inti? nobody knows what happened to it. Pizarro didn't get to see it by then a lot of gold as Cieza describes were thrown into the lakes, hiding and buried who knows where. A lot of the Inka people run for their lives to the high mountains and plateaus, others threw themselves after tying themselves to their children, woman, animals and treasures from the high mountains to the abyss so was not to fall in servitude or be kill... The noble people of Peru couldn't understand the unquenchable thirst of Gold, how the Spaniards and the Catholic church in the name of their God will try to exterminate them... As later writers say... The people of the Inka Empire were living a dream... when the Spaniards arrived the woke up to a nightmare and they're still living it. They were left with nothing, taking away their identity and their pride... most of all their sense of belonging. What is left of what once was a great TEMPLE to the Sun Inti, now it's only a sad reminder of human greediness... A sad reminder of what once was a great culture to revere, learn from it and not to have destroyed as it was destroyed.My best regards to whom ever will read my comment.

Interesting history. Went as part of a City Tour in Cusco. Our guide was great (Beto)-very knowledgable and gave us a great tour. The place was a little crowded in the afternoon when we went, so if there is a morning tour, that might be better. The Inca stonework is amazing-still amazed that they could fit those stones together without mortar or modern tools.

The center of Incan Peru. Qoricancha is really spectacular. I like to take visitors to see the Incan walls lighted up on their first night in Cusco. The quality of the stonework is really amazing (stone walls without cement in place for 500 years in an earthquake zone). The tours inside are also quite interesting. This is a must see for any visit to Cusco.

Spectacular. We went to 2 free concerts by the Cusco Symphony Orchestra in Santo Domingo. The santuary itself if quite interesting, full of ornate carved wooden alters with many statues of the saint, a great illustration of colonial art. It was a fantastic location for concerts, The orchestra did a good job on Beethoven, Schubert's Unfinished, and some Brazilian pieces. The church, built on the foundation of Incan temples, with colonial art, and international music and visitors was a perfect illustration of the multiple cultures threated together in Cusco.

Amazing architecture. We came here with a group tour. It's amazing to see original Incan built walls still standing after numerous earthquakes. The smoothness and way the walls fit together without mortar is a sight to see up close.

Rolling Stones. The mystery of places like this is how and why they were built. No two local or other guides have the same answer, it seemed to us. No matter, it's a great site to explore. See Sacsayhuaman (remember it by "sexy woman", said the guide) at the same time by taking the half-day guided tour out of Cusco.

Interesting to see the merging of the building styles. What was once the center of the Incan Empire became another cathedral for the Spanish. The original temple base was unmistakeable and it was interesting to see the artistic imagery throughout refferencing the temple being the center of the Empire.

An interesting visit. This was the start point of our half day tour and enabled our guide to start our induction into Inca culture.What was so impressive was to see the amazing craft of the Inca in the building of walls and temples. Brilliant.

Interesting Bit of History. A must if one is to understand the relationship between the original Ketchua Indians and their Inka--and the Catholic Church and it willingness to wipe out the indigenous culture and replace it with cathedrals.

Yet another wonderful place in Cusco. The Peruvians are so good at preserving and presenting these wonderful sites, Unesco must recognise this and be proud, the carvings, the building techniques, the history, you can almost taste it.....

Amazing Building Styles. The unmistakeable Inca bulding techniques are so recognisable despite the Spanish additions, the light shining through the arches was very atmospheric, and nice views of Cusco, a Must!
Wonderful Church. If you want to know more about the colonial art during the Spaniard colonization, this church is an example of it. The paints, arquitecture as a whole is great.

The Center of the Incan Empire. The Temple of the Sun was the very center of Cuszo, which was the center of the Incan Empire. As with many of the Incan temples, the Spanish tore it down and used the base of the temple for a church. We were approached by a private guide at the entrance, who gave us a tour in good English for 30 soles. I'm very glad we were able to get a guide, as I don't think we would have quite understood the site without one. Definitely glad we added it to our Cuzco site seeing.

Great start to Cusco!. The Temple of the Sun was the first place that I visited while in Cusco. This was a sacred place for the Inca, however the Spanish attempt to wipe out what the Inca had and build a church on the site.Despite the Spanish attempt, the Inca building technique withstood the test of time.Had a wonderful guide who was very knowledgeable and able to answer questions. I was amazed how without cement how the Incas were able to place the stones such where even earthquakes had no impact. Also in two areas how the windows are in perfect alignment.Be advise if you are not on a tour group, try to arrive before or after. I was with a tour group and it was packed! Often had to wait for one tour group leave an area first. When leaving, no line for entrance. Also there is alot of uneven walking areas. In one section you have to step down quite low and step back up high. Some people did need assistance in these area.Also there is a small climb from the street to the entrance. Taxis can drop off at the door.There were also alot of vendors selling items, dressed in local items,etc. You will have to say "No thanks" alot.

Temple of the Sun. Very interesting - seeing how the church was built over the ruins. Amazing art work throughout. Seeing Cusco as the centre of the Inka Empire - this really helps understand some of the other Inka structures.

Well worth the visit. Make this your first stop before visiting any other inca ruin. This is the centre of the Inca empire and everything stems from this historical site. Get a guide here so that you understand the history and the precision of the Inca building techniques and mastery.

This is a perfect sample of high technology applied to civil engineering.. When you see through its perfectly aligned windows, you would imagine that some sort of laser level was used thousands of years ago to built them. How did they melt the stone? You have to see it.

Nice site in town with excellent galleries. Expect to pay for a guide if you want some understanding about the site. There are little bits in english but a good guide will be able to answer your questions. There is also an extra fee to enter this site as its not included on the tourist ticket.

Make sure to have a guide to enjoy the most!!!. Just imagine... this was the CORE AND CENTRAL POINT of the Inca culture in acient times...It's amazing to feel that in that place one of the most important culture of all times was based and it was the heart of its power... just make sure to hire a guide, they are plenty of them when you get for a visit... make sure to negotiate price...we took a 30-40 min very well explained for $20 soles.... ENJOY!!!

Former Indian Temple Converted by Spanish. An Incan temple stripped of its gold and silver and murals by the Spanish and converted into their HQ. No wonder the Incans at Machu Pichu decided to leave their city so it wouldn't become known by the Spanish. The blitzy city tours don't do the place justice.

Cathedral of Santo Domingo Cusco. The Cathedral of Santo Domingo dominates the Plaza de Armas (Square of the Warrior) in Cusco. It has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site. The cathedral was built on the site of the most important Inca Temple, the Temple of the Sun, or Korikancha. And it is one of many sites where the Spanish incorporated Inca stonework into the structure.The facade of the cathedral reflects the Spanish Baroque-style architecture. Inside are a number of important artifacts including the two altars, the sacristy, and the Black Christ:. The wooden crucifix is black from centuries of smoke and dust. It remains in that condition as it was not cleaned during restoration of the cathedral interior during the 1990s, when the burning of candles was ended.
Revealing place. Use a guide, the site is a maze inside and deserves to get in. Do not try to enter without a guide or you can get lost.

a cool place to contemplate a history-filled day in santo domingo. this is a beautiful cathedral, worth visiting to compare and contrast with european construction. a fantastic respite from the heat. don't miss the front facade

Worth a visit. By visiting this place, one learns more about the history of the Incas which came to an abrupt end with the arrival of the Spanish. The building is nice with an appealing courtyard, and the guide explains things that educates the visitor further about the Incas.

Temple of the Sun. The Temple of the Sun was a nice relaxing visit but put me in a state of pure awe and joy.I do not have the words to explain the intricate work of the Incas.It´s an experience that cannot not be omitted if you are visiting Cusco.Guides are available at the door (for a fee) and the entrance fee is inexpensive.Highly recommended.

So Much to See. In addition to the archtecture, the paintings were unbelieveable here. Look at the ceilings and the wood carvings as well. Beautiful! I personally loved the history with the Milky Way Galaxy and the Inka constellations.

What Architecture!. Just another beautiful site of several we visited. Words can't truly describe how you feel wandering through the history and architecture of these sites. Sculptures, paintings, wood carvings, it just keeps going.

A must see while in Cusco. was there beginning of March 2013. an large ancient temple turned into a convent. History at its best. Only 10 soles to get in (less than 3 dollars). It is a little crowdy at times due to large tourist groups and especially at the entrance where locals try to sell you things but well worth the hassle. see pictures attached

Very interesting...worth visiting. Qorinqancha was included in our half day city tour so it was a bit rushed by our tour guide and I would like to have explored a bit more. However, it is awe-inspiring to see how the Incas built their temples...extremely clever and our modern-day architects could learn a thing or two! It's an interesting mix of Inca ruin and Spanish influence since the latter destroyed most of it to build their own churches. Can get very busy at times and you have to run past all the street hawkers on the outside, but definitely worth a visit.

Well worth a visit. Well kept with a great collection of religious art (and, interestingly, when I was there also a collection of modern pieces), Qoriqancha (one of about 12 variant spellings I ran across) is a great place to see how the Spanish colonists literally built on top of Inca ruins when reframing Cusco. Don't miss the incredible Mudéjar style door on the way in.
Stunning. This was our first stop as we embarked on our tour of Cusco. Once again, the history is awe inspiring. The stones and general structure amazing. A must visit.
Amazing beauty. My girlfriend is Peruvian and she suggested we get a guide to explain about the church, well worth the small cost, lasted an hour and was fascinating

Imposing yet not as impressive as it should be.... The Qoriqancha was the ritual centre of Cuzco, which was the social and political centre of the Inca world. One might thus expect. Lot from it. Unfortunately, so did the Spanish, and they not only trashed the original structures but used the foundations for a monastery and church in order to utterly crush the Inca power structures. In this they were unfortunately successful. The foundations and lower courses are inca in design, and there have been rebuilds to the 'treasure houses' and other smaller structures in the covered courtyard area. The original Qoriqancha was a series of thatched buildings in a compound, which held most of the Inca's wealth down to gold llamas (allegedly). Little effort has been made to show how it was, however. The data available are a little half hearted, and there is one rather feeble reconstruction. Far too much attention has been paid to the colonial overburden, including religious robes and the enormously overrated and disappointing Cusco school paintings, which have a lot of highly academic explication which would be better spent on the Inca sections of the structure. So...disappointing. The gardens and outdoor areas are very pretty, however.

a must visit if you are in Cusco.... take a few extra moments...walk around the perimeter of the church...breathe in the calmness...take a look at the 'black' jesus...well the spanish understood that Jesus should be given a Inca avatar...unlike the Jesus of Michelangelo and Da Vinci...here Jesus was from the local people itself...
Alright. I wasn't that into the Temple of the Sun. I thought it was a little boring. There is good history here and I wouldn't go without a tour guide.
Don't miss this. The tour of this is a great way to introduce you to the mystery of the Inca's. Very crowded, but make sure you get a good guide and there are many!

Beautiful church, gallery and museum. Coricancha is now a Dominican monastery built after the Spanish invasion on the foundation of an Incan temple. There is a gallery of beautiful religious paintings, contemporary Peruvian art. There is some information about the Incas, a garden and a view of Cusco. The best museum I visited in Cusco!

Somewhere between a monastery and a museum. Interesting building & exhibits (to say the least). Provides info on the history of Incas and their building techniques. Does not take all that long to see it all so you shouldn't get bored and there are things for kids to enjoy too. Be sure not to miss the condor representation in the garden - many do!

Magical. A must see , while in Cuzco . Peruvian ( Inca ) history at it's best , in the heart of the city . Minutes away from the Plaza de Armas . My suggestion is that you must read about this monument BEFORE you visit it . !!

Ancient Inca Temple turned Church. I was not overly impressed with this structure, however I did enjoy hearing the history and the facts behind the structure and also seeing the remaining Inca artefacts inside. It's shame that the Spanish conquest came and destroyed such a incredible civilisation, and enforced their customs upon the Quechua people.

Great Local History. Inexpensive admission - wonderful colonial displays - well worth a visit. You could feel the tranquility that the monks experienced in the courtyard. Some excellent values on non woven handicrafts on the 2nd floor.

Go with a guide... A unique mix of 16th century Catholic church construction, using much of the Incan ruins as a foundation and incorporating it into the overall design. Make sure you have a knowledgable guide to reveal the uniqueness of this church.
Superb stonework. Truly impressive to see the intricacy and detail of the stonework which the Incas managed to achieve.
magical. our guide was outstanding and imparted so many interesting facts..........was particularly fascinated by the Inca water systems

Probably the best visit in Cuzco.. Ideal visit to really appreciate the conquistador 'imposition' on the Inca culture.
Again, a guided tour will be so valuable to understand the Inca culture.
In my view, the best sight/visit in Cuzco.
The First Inca Temple. One of the best stops on the trip! The history, the 16th Century oil paintings and the Spanish religious relics make this a highlight of Cuzco City.
Coricancha. Beautiful, what's left of it! Can only imagine what it was like in the time of the Inca when the interior was sheathed in gold.

A great example of fine Inca stonework. It is truly amazing to visit this site and witness how far superior the Inca era stonework was to that of the subsequent Spanish work. The colonial works surrounding the Inca temple have repeatedly succumbed to earth quakes over the centuries while the Inca work endures largely intact.
Great cultural site in Cusco. Saw as part of the Cusco city tour - really unique piece of architecture and guides are knowledgeable. Nice way to start the trip.

WHOW - and all that without knowledge of the wheel. This is a remarkable sight to see. But, a guide is a "MUST" It's so difficult to know what to look at first. A guide can sort that out. No matter how many books you read before you get here, a guide has the 'reasl' experience to point out 'what's-what'.!
History not to miss. Just loved to visit this sacred place. Easy to get around and well explained. You will not be dissappointed.

Up close and personal with history. The temple of the sun is literally inside a convent. This is what happens when you build great architecture and the Spanish decide they'd like to repurpose it. For a very reasonable fee, you can explore the temple, see the former water ways, admire the cathedral and enjoy the lawn.

A bit chaotic but interesting. This tour is not included in the boleto touristico but its not very expensive.
It's an interesting tour and many of the ruins have been excavated and are visible throughout.

Excellent first stop. This was a great primer on Incan history and the history of the area. I would recommend spending the extra cash and get a guide. Ours did a wonderful job of helping us to focus in the critical information in all the signs and things to read.

Coricancha. This temple - which Spanish built over and completely covered at the time of the conquest - has some of the most beautiful Inca stone work in Cuzco. Going with a guide is a must to really understand the Inca and Spanish history. Don't miss it!

Very interesting--worth a look if you are at all into the Inca history. This place looks impressive from the outside. It is at least worth walking over to get some great pictures. If you are at all into the history, art, or story of the Inca then I think you will enjoy stopping here. I do not think that you need a guide. We opted to see this as part of a tour but like most tours, I wished we had more time alone to explore the architecture and art.

Not all that worth seeing. Most of the temple of the Sun has been rebuilt. The outside of the building looks interesting, but the inside is really not all that interesting because most of it has been rebuilt. I could have skipped it and not missed much.

Impressive. See this before Macchu Picchu, but it is still impressive. It is a lot of walking and steep steps, which made it inaccessible to my 82 year old mother in law (who did fine at Macchu Picchu), but interesting and beautiful Inca temple.
Don't know how the moved those rocks!. This place was huge, rocks as well as grassed areas. This was a sacred ground for the Inca people. Lots to see.

Santo Domingo Church. I believe this is next to Coriconcha (sp). The alters in this church are breath taking. The down side is that you cannot take pictures. Go see this church!!! It is really nice. I was fortunate enough to be able to attend Sunday night mass here and it was great.

Coricancha. Worth the visit. Beautiful and informative. Make sure to visit the Cathedral that is attached, it is incredible. So much to see in Cusco and so little time. You could spend 3 weeks there and see something new every day

Very interesting as this was an Inca temple once.... ... but is a cathedral now (or atleast most of it is). The Inca stones are amazing to see as they did not use mortar but just perfectly cut stones without any iron tools.

Best historic site in Cusco!. Of all the churches and historic sites - this is the site to see. Beautiful setting and gardens. Both the magnificent and precise old Inca walls, and the setting, view, and gardens make you want to linger for a bit. There is a small museum underneath the gardens which is a separate entity.
You can wonder for hours. We were not sure what to expect, but this place is amazing. There is also a nice rotating art exhibit on the second floor.
A grand beauty. Loved every minute. A tremendous work of architecture, beautiful artwork, artifacts and history - a must see in Cusco, Peru!
Don't get to see much. There are some Inca walls, and blocks, but you don't really get to see much of a temple. It was pretty cool seeing these things inside the church buildings though.

Fascinating history. This Dominican church and monastery is now run by the Jesuits but it was built on Incan ruins, showing they knew its spiritual significance. Fascinating history and intro to the culture of the area incorporating Spanish culture into the indigenous belief system.

Beautiful example of Inca architecture.. The sun temple was one of the best example of spanish architecture built on the foundations left by Inca's. The incredible skill and craftsmanship of Inca work has outlasted the newer spanish buildings placed on top.

Must see. If there is one church/museum you should see in Cusco, this is it. The Inca stonework is of the highest level. The church is beautiful, but fascinating and heartbreaking to see how the Spanish trampled the indiginous culture.
You dont have to leave the city to find culture. You dont have to go out of Cusco city to find the incas ruins, you can enjoy it in the city , its a perfect structure from the incas time.

Great cultural immersion. Especially on weekends the Iglesias and nearby squares are centers for cultural activity. As with any country, it is worth your time to watch for a bit and respect cultural mores. Enjoy!

Very interesting experience. We saw this on a rainy day but this fact did not alter our opinion of this fascinating temple. The rocks fit together with tongue and groove back in the 1400s. you could not put a piece of paper between the rocks...the windows line up exactly. Thanks to Ideal South America

more than a church. this also gives you access to the museo arquelogico de qoricancha, there is a gallery room, nice gardens some inca stones so better than the cathedral but somehow felt like something was missing but along with the inca museum this is the best tourist attraction of this sort.
Coricancha. A short walk from our hotel, and an interesting introduction to Inca and pre inca history. Good labelling so we did not need a guide.
Busy. Not so impressive. The whole complex was very busy and it was hard to see much. Most of the Inca ruins were obliterated by colonial stuff- interesting in itself though obviously not inca!

Religious Ruins. What a contrast. Christianity and the Inka. The inca walls and remains of its temple are now the foundation of a Spanish colonial church. While the church itself is beautiful, one is still amazed by the inca stone work at its base. A perfect historical example of the clash of cultures and religions. It is a shame that all we can do now is imagine what the Inca temple once looked like.

Incomparable. This amazing temple deserves much more time that people give it. I wonder at the precision that created the building, and tied it into the cosmological order of All Things. The ceques that radiated out across the land through chapels and huacas and temples to empower all with the energy of the sacred centre. Breathe in the wonder of it. And wonder where such magic disappeared to in our own culture!

Must See if in Cusco. Europe meets Andes type of place. It used to be an Inca Temple which was transformed into a Roman Catholic institution. There is a fusion of both cultures and you can view construction on top of Inca Foundations. Amazing stone work that shows you how percise the Incas were in laying stone walls that needed no cement or mortar to hold together. Beautiful views of the remaining portion of the temple. Very nice place to visit to witness the clash of two civilizations where one imposed itself on the other.

Very interesting how the Incans kept their religon by incorporating Catholicism. Sign said no pictures but guides said that you could take pics of the Incan walls & outward looking - just not the pictures. It was an interesting temple but you need a guide to get anything out of it.

Amazing stone work!. I love the Inca walls still remaining. But don't expect to see a real temple - it is now a catholic church, built on the foundations of an Inka temple. But you can see the curved wall of the Inka temple still outside, at the base of the church. The workmanship was stunning, with the stones perfectly fitted. This is the must see sight in Cusco. For photos of what we saw on our visit, go to my travel blog at travelswithrarecat.blogspot.ca.

The Center of the Center of Inkan Empire. This is a very interesting place to visit with some incredible examples of Inkan architecture. It is in a fun part of Cusco, so you won't have to isolate a day for this visit as you must with some other excursions.

really cool church!. This church was great because it looks cool from the outside with a very old feel, there are beautiful gardens. Our guide was from condor travel and was great! this church in interesting because it has both spanish architechture and incan which was reveiled after the earth quake in 1950. Great historic site.

Great to understand Inca history. Go there in the afternoon, great for photos shooting... It can be paid independently for the entry, not necessary to buy the tourist collective ticket... A must see in Cusco

great inca ruins. I love the inca ruins and this is another one to tick off the list.
They are well maintained and offer you an insight into the amazing strength that the culture has at creating great structures.
nice. it is good to have a guide with you to explain many of the areas and artifacts inside this historical building

Great for a photo backdrop. Please read other reviews to learn about the interior...I merely took pics outside. Watch out for the Quechua women and kids out front...if you take their photo they want a "tip".

Nice!. Here you have the opportunity to learn a lot about the history and significance of this area. The museum is informative and the grounds are very interesting. I would certainly include this in my favorite Cusco sites.

Fascinating. This church was right across from our hotel. Beautiful courtyard. Stone construction was amazing - done with no mortar. The interior of the church is exquisite in all of its beautiful detail.
All of the gold and silver detailing was stunning.
Go and sit in here quietly for a while. The churches in Cusco are many and beautiful, I popped in and there was a wedding taking place, so beautiful ... the interiors are so ornate and beautiful.
Amazing ruins. These Incan ruins were explained by our guide and gave us an insite into the Inca life. They are quite high and it takes stamina and strength to reach the top, but is worth the effort.

dissapointed. I expected probably something else...
For me there was not so much to see and it all looked the same too. Way too crowded also....

Worth a visit, interesting history.. Worth a short visit with a guide for explanation. Have some great artifacts there. Preserved and maintained really well. Near city square so easy to combine with half day city tour.

Merging the old with the new old.. This site is a prominent view on the road into town from the airport. Obvious is the Incan precision stone foundation upon which the conquering Spaniards built their own structures. You can take a long time wandering the grounds or make it a quick trip to get a feel for the two empires this structure combines. A nice walk from the Plaza de Armas, this can be fit into an afternoon desire for a stroll around town. The ticket is 15 soles.

Church with a view. They did an excellent job of renovating this historical place Inca/Catholic..nice space & incredible views of Cusco. This time I also went to Convento de Catherina..worth the visit..you can add to ticket for 5 soles.
Top sight/site in all of Cusco. The Inca's main temple, converted to a seminary. Simply amazing architecture and history - do not miss.

definitely worth the visit. Qoricancha is a really cool site that today mixes the ancient (original Incan walls), the old (Spanish monastery) and the new (modern art gallery on the 2nd floor), making it both a museum and a current gallery at the same time. The stonework was incredible and in any other spot the monastery itself would be a major attraction. I'd recommend a tour too for the fantastic detail they can provide.
Fabulous!. No other words but a fabulous view! We hiked the two day Inca trail and our first view of Machu Picchu was at the Temple of the Sun.
Strong. Coricancha, the heart of the empire, with the temple of the sun. Exquisite construction in stone, solid and even now, as powerful as the empire was for so many centuries
Beautiful!!. Another site to see on the Incan Trail, you will love it!!!!! This is where we had lunch after our hike and we took some breath taking pics!
very interesting. Need a guided tour there in order to understand what was going on there. The surrounding are is nice
Impressive. We did not go inside but it is impressive to see from the street. It is within walking distance from the Plaza de Armas. I would imagine the festival in June is pretty amazing.
just some inca walls. Quite pricey to go in and there's not much to see, just more big stones. Upstairs was some more information and a weird art show.

must see. great site but could do with more information boards, interactive knowledge etc. we are independent travellers and even with a couple of books it was quite difficult to understand where you were in relation to site, of course the fact that it was plundered and built upon doesn't help but more could and should be done.
good history. time well spent, too many tourists, but good gardens, nd a good perspective before you see the other sites

Easy to get to. Hire a guide so you get more than just walking around looking at the Inca Wall part. The grounds are pretty, and there are some English translations in the church, but I would have gotten more out of it with a guide

Unbelievable sight at the end of a long trek. We worked hard to get there on the 4 day Inca Trail...it was worth every minute and we appreciated it that much more. The final Gringo Challenge steps were a great way to fight to the finish.

most amazing building in the city of Cusco. this is a must visit in Cusco, you will see the magnificent ancient construction that the Incas build before the spaniels come and crumble all of it down not before took all the gold and kill many Indians, well it woth it to come an see what they all did and accomplish the (incas) using nothing more and nothing else that rudimentary tools like harder stone than the one they were using to build their own buildings and some others tools made out of alienations with other metals..overall its well worth it and a unique experience well worth it. Besides its included in your ticket to city tour! so just do it!
Very interesting. How amazing to learn how the Incas built walls that withstood major earthquakes and still exist today. There is some beautiful artwork too
Part of City Tour. Very crowded but very impressive, only had 10 min to go to toilet and wander on own - would have liked more time

A stunning monument of Incan culture.. This is the must-see attraction in Cusco. The museum section contains frescos, other paintings, and simply stunning artifacts depicting the transition from Incan to Spanish culture in Peru. The building is beautiful and has the characteristic courtyard and Incan masonry. This is an absolute must for anyone wanting to appreciate Incan, Peruvian, or even Latin American culture.
Wonderful site. The Monastery has remnants of teh Quechua/Inca ruins as well as the embellishments/modifications that the Spanish added over the centuries.

Get a guide. The church is built over one of the oldest inca sites in the city and the remnants of the original inca temples are visible inside. The entry price is 10 soles each and a guide can be hired out the front for 10 soles extra per persons. Having an explanation while walking through really increases understanding of the site. Details I would not have noticed were pointed out to me and I learnt a great deal more about inca religious beliefs.

Crowded but Cool. The history of Coricancha is amazing and to know you are walking through a structure built by the Incas to worship the sun is really neat. I would recommend using a guide because it is hard to grasp the significance without one. But be careful when you go, because it can become so overwhelmed with tour groups that it is annoying to be inside.
Very interesting.. Very interesting to see the history of the Inca and Spanish blended together in this building. The gardens were pretty and we saw a couple of humming birds there.

A Must See. One of the largest attractions in town, we were lucky as our hotel was just outside so not much walking.Worth taking a guide to explain how the inca's built their temples and how the Catholics came and destoyed parts and built around others.However the more and more guides you speak to, the more you get confused for the conflicting info.
Amazing temple. Simply stunning with pretty gardens, this temple is definitely worth a visit. Such interesting history too. Recommended!

Neat, ancient, well documented. This site tells the story of the imposition of Spaniards on the Aztec monarchy. Qoricancha was the golden temple capital of Peru. Spaniards appropriated it for what it is today, a monastery/convent. Its been stripped of its gold and its hard to imagine what it must have looked like before the Spaniards, but walking through it and reading the story was really the only way to understand the juxtaposition of the two cultures.

Not just another temple.... Save some energy for this climb and then enjoy the views. Listen carefully to the story and you will be fully absorbed by the Inca's love of the sun and all it means to them.

Stunning temple of the Incas. We arrived at the Coricancha very early in the morning, and we were lucky because we met a young person who asked us to be our guide, so we acepted his offer. Inside the temple, we realized that there were only few people which was really great because we took pictures everywhere with out have to do a line, and even more, we learnt a lot with our guide, even some words in Quechua, such as Killa, which means Moon, or Inti, which means Sun. In Short, we made a right decision being early at the Coricancha to avoid a crowd of people and enjoy our tour .

the best to see in Cuzco. This is the remains of the major Inca temple in Cusco. The religious order that built on top of it has done an outstanding job of presevering and explaining the older culture. The finest stonework you will see anywhere - and it is only three blocks from the Plaza de Armas

A great starting point to explore Inkan culture. If you are interested in Incan culture and history, this is a great starting point at the centre of the city. The Spanish built a church on this sacred Incan site and although the gold that covered these walls are gone, there seem to be original elements from the Incas that have not been lost such as the interior walls and room, a few sacred stones that reflect the four elements, the passageway that aligns with the plaedian galaxy and the outside wall and corner that gives the name to this site - temple of the sun. If you are visiting this site, you should do some reading before, or you can miss some interesting historical elements. Nice view of the city from this vantage point.
Interesting. This was interesting and worth seeing for the Inka ruins and the great view of Cuzco though the Church was somewhat underwhelming.

Greati refraction of Incaand Christian architecture. Very good basis for seeing the Incan architecture styles using trapezoidal for stability and stones placed together. Makes for some very interesting photos.

Strange Inca temple forms the basis of a Dominican church. Quoricancha is quite hard to find, as you can see the old Inca temple walls from the main drag (Av el Sol) but the Spanish have built a Church on top of it, so it looks very strange. Head up to the main Church and you can enter from there. There are some informative panels telling you about what's going on, and the original Inca walls are very ompressive - although it does make you wonder why the Spanish just built a church around it...There's quite a bit of colonial art, and aret from the Cusco School, including a very impressive ivory carving of Christ on the cross.Upstairs is a modern art exhibit, but I can't comment on that as I didn't look at it!

Interesting, for low cost. I went to the Temple of the Sun in August of 2012. It was not very expensive to get in - I believe around 10-15 soles if I remember correctly ($4-6 USD). As a church, it is not too exciting, although they have a fair amount of artwork inside. The cool part is seeing the contrast between the Incan and colonial architecture, as it was an Incan temple that was demolished, and a church was built on top. The Incan foundations remain, and the craftsmanship on the stonework is pretty amazing. Not the most thrilling place in the world, but interesting to see for a couple bucks.

Okay but not as majestic as some. Perhaps I should have visited this ruin first, before the ones high up in the Andes. The adobe ruins were just not as impressive as the ones previously seen. However, there is evidence of great care being taken to preserve the site so that is good

Unhurried and informative. Informative tour by friendly English speaker who answered all our questions (included in price) - we did not have to wait and they took us through as a couple. Not easy to understand why you can't take photos of the painted murals on the courtyard walls - exposed to the weather and sunlight - but 'them's the rules' i suppose and I play with them.

It´s worth a visit. Rigth in the middle of Cuzco, easy to visit and a lot to learn and see.The museum inside is great and when we buy the city tour ticket the fee is included.It´s not allowed to take pictures inside but I couldn´t help taking some pictures of the inca mumies.

Nice walk. Don't miss out a visit to the Coricancha, very nice building and a lot of story in it.The entrance should be included in the Cusco Visitor Ticket, that can be bought at the Tourism Office in Avenida El Sol, just outside Plaza de Armas
The Old and the New. Not much to say other then it's a must see if you're in Peru. It's a great representation of what the Spaniards did when they took over.

You must visit. This Inca temple has been partly destroyed by the Dominicans who constructed their church and monastery on top of it. It was probably the most important temple as it was dedicated to the sun god.

Wow!. After Machu Picchu, this little museum cleared up a few lingering questions. Amazing to find the quality Incan temples inside, or destroyed by the surrounding colonial Catholic Church structure. Entrance fee was something like $3 and a guide will cost you between $ 3 and $10, depending on your group size and language needs. Ours was fabulous and well worth the extra money. Inside the signage is not such that anyone can glean the knowledge alone. However, working the center of the courtyard and accompanying ley lines is a different matter. Make sure to spend a few minutes here, aware and focused on the convergence in this spot of more ley lines than any place on the planet!

Beautiful and sad. Koricancha is what is left of the temple of the suns after the conquistadores destroyed it to build churches and houses. Only a few buildings are left and the art of the Incas architect is truly amazing. It is sad that so much of it was destroyed by invaders only looking for gold.

Really interesting!. This is the place where the spaniardsv took out tons of gold and silver. It has a fascinating history. We also saw the art gallery with Peruvian art. To be honest though, it was our 4th site in 4 hours and we were Pershing out. Perhaps if we had seen first, we might have more fascinated with it.

Beautiful Place!. This place provided our first glimpse of the famous Inca stonework and we were mesmerized. It's a beautiful place and we enjoyed walking around for a little more than an hour. Views of Cusco are beautiful from the outdoor areas.
History. Our guide was very informative and the history of the Incas was very interesting. We found the entire history of the Incan Empire to be incredible.
Interesting look at impact of conquest. Coricancha is "under" a church built by the Spanish conquerors, much of the original construction is still visible, though.
Must See. Really interesting place, we had a private guide and I recommend that for everyone as the history is interesting.

A bit of a bait and switch. I went there looking for the Temple of the Sun and expecting an inca site. It really is now mostly a catholic complex with a couple of inca structures still in lace.The cloister itself is interesting and worth visiting in itself but I do feel that the guidebooks are overselling the site by pitching it as an Inca temple.A few tips: on second level, go through the art exhibition and along the library: there is a little door that gives you roof access with cool views. I also recommend taking a look at the library itself: some of the materials owned by the monks might surprise you !

Should have been really cool. This is a very historic and important Inca site. I only wish I hadn't gone with a guided tour but rather made my way there on my own with a proper guide book with details and history. After paying for the entrance fee (because it's not included in the tourist ticket), we were in the site for about 20 minutes. It was very busy in there, and our tour guide cut corners (or so I assume) to get through it as quickly as possible. Of the four spiels she gave, I couldn't hear what she was saying for two of them and the next thing I knew, we were being herded out! This site is worth a visit, but I would recommend you go on your own armed with some literature to help you observe and learn on your own terms.

Excellent place. Here you can see the Inca architecture and admire the way they put those heavy stones the one over the other and the one clipping with the other. Especially the angles of the building were made from one block of stone. I'm not an architect and I cannot imagine how they were doing that.

Better if you know the history of the place. It's a beautiful structure that is very close to the main square in Cusco. You'd want to either have a guide or read about the history of the site before you go because it'll mean a lot more. You'll find out why the Spanish church is where it is, and why there are still so much remnants of the previous Inca structure still exists. I think part of going to these sites in Peru is to learn about the history of the country, and this is definitely one of the good ones to learn about.

Ruins hidden inside. Hidden inside Santo Domingo are incredible ruins. It is a must-see just to look at the perfect fit of the Incan stonework. Step up on the block and notice the perfect alignment of the trapizoidal windows. Restoration is still in process. Many Peruvains in traditional garb greet you ouside to pose for photos, for a fee of course. If you agree to hold their pet, be prepared to pay. It is easy to find from the Plaza de Armas.

BEST ENERGY IN THE WORLD. This was THE CENTER OF THE WORLD for the Incas. In fact, the corner where the most sacred mummys where in the times of the Incas.The problem with this place is that the Spanish during the invasion destroyed the place to make a church on top. I personally hate that church, specially because it is still in hands of the Catholics this place having such an importance in the past of the Incas.But you can still see part of the place and feel the EXTREME ENERGY it has. A MUST.

Best museum/site in city of Cusco. Qoricancha is a beautiful place to visit in the centre of Cusco. It was a perfectly built Inca building that the Spansh turned into a monastery. The two styles although dissimilar work well together. The only downside is the glass and metal modern roof. It's a five minute walk fom the plaza and about three dollars to enter. Do not confuse with the museum of Qoricancha which is actually on Avenida Sol.
Perfect for horse riding. Myself and my kids age 10 and 13 went horse riding. It was a lovely experience and you got to see a lot of the nature and findings.

Cusco’s single essential visit.. Although technically it refers to just the Inca Temple, “Qorikancha” for purposes of this review is a hybrid building containing groundwork elements of the Inca Sun Temple with the superimposed colonial church and convent of Santo Domingo. After the conquest of Cusco, Francisco Pizarro gave it to his brother Juan but the latter died soon thereafter and it was willed to the Dominicans who built a convent on top of the pilfered remains of the temple. The current structure is a striking hybrid of construction methods.We visited while on a walking tour of the city with a private guide who explained the remaining Inca structures and how they fit into what evidently was the richest temple in the empire. After entering the courtyard we visited many separate interior temples (thunder, rainbow, moon, etc.) with impressive stone architecture. There are also numerous mini-exhibits on astronomy and history (with English signage!) that complete your understanding of the building in the context of the Inca Empire before the conquest. The exterior of the building is impressive as well, with a garden facing the street that provides a good backdrop for the requisite tourist pictures.The building itself is not only interesting in its own right but functions as a visual metaphor for the Spanish “Conquest of the Americas” and all of the vibrancy associated with that collision of cultures. A must visit for even the most casual tourist.

Just to feel the ambience and get in the mood.. We did this without a guide. Just walking around and reading what we liked and feeling what we liked to without being told, was so serene and calm. The info is available in English. Enjoy it while getting acclimated.

Well kept museum. This museum has restored the ruins that remained after the church was built on top of it. The ruins inside are well maintained but were very busy when we were there. There are a few very unique walls and room designs within the museum that are work checking out.

Where Incan and Spanish history collide.. This temple was once plastered and built over by the Spanish. Since then it has been partially recovered and allows viewers to get a closer look at Incan architecture and tradition from the inside out. I also appreciated seeing the contrast between Incan and Spanish architecture. To get the full experience, pay extra for a guide.

Must-Visit. A great stop on the requisite City Tour. See the wonders of Spanish and Incan architecture and learn about Incan building methods and astronomy from well-maintained exhibits. Was very, very crowded both times we visited, but a good tour guide can make the best of this situation.
Worth visiting. Worth visiting on your stopover to getting to machu picchu. The 3 windows make for a good picture and learning a little bit about the Incan calendar and astrology is fun.
Skip this.. Not much to see or learn here. It was overpriced and crowded. The city tour forces you to go there and spend money. It wasn't worth the time.

Sun Worship. You really don't understand what was the original purpose of entering the church built over the temple. At least I didn't until I saw the scale model of what was...then it is awe inspiring.

Temple of the Sun God. Inca temple base that became a church and convent. Held Inca mummies of the nobles. Spanish took all the gold from the walls but was unbelievable during the height of Inca power. Wonderful art from the Cusco School of painting is displayed.

Beautiful Oasis. The Coricancha is a great landmark, and a good spot for a sit/picnic, and often, concerts. The museum is interesting, since the earthquake in 1950 uncovered the Inca ruins underneath. Worth a visit!!!
Interesting History. Usually very crowded but to learn how the Inca buildings were constructed and why they were built is very interesting. Smart people.
Excellent historical site! Great views of Cusco from the lookout.. Excellent site to visit in conjunction with the Sacred Valley; this is the navel of the Puma. Dedicate a couple of hours here.
a must when you are in Cusco!. Do go there, it is very impressive! Take a guide to explain you the little details, stories and legends!
One of the main attractions of Cusco. Good to learn the main site of the Inka empire. It's a 2 hours visit

Interesting. We had to see this place because of its historical significance. Sad to know that it was just a shell of its former self, and was stripped of all its gold and former glory. Definitely worth a visit, and it looks beautiful at night when the outside is lit up.
A must see!. Hire a tour guide if you can, it's worth having a knowledgeable, detailed description of what you're seeing!

Inca architecture. Personally, I was very touched to see the inca walls inside the church, it's a shame what the conquistadors did to the inca culture. Still the way the walls were put together makes one think how they did that.
Impressive inca wall.. Nice mix of Inca walls and colonial monastery. A bit light on artifacts.

sun temple. i think is a must but take a travel guide it will help you with answers and informations i liked the part of reconstruction
the paintings is a part of history but you have seen better ;-)

Worthwhile, But a Guide helps. Worth a visit, but to fully appreciate the Temple you need a guide. Even so, I would consider this a "must see" while in Cusco.
Nothing to dislike, although better signage in English would help.

must visit in Cuzco. Well worth it to get a guide. Someone at the gate very politely ask if we needed a guide, we paid about 25 sol. She also introduce us to Sacsayhuanma, which also turned out to be a beautiful visit.

Another Inca marvel!. This site was also on the city tour and was bustling with tourists. Because I'd read the history of the Spanish conquistadors, I felt awe and sadness at visiting this sacred site, knowing its tragic fate. It is splendid to walk past at night when it is lit up...a bit haunting, really.

Incredible Incas. The Coriancha was once the most elaborate and stunning Sun Temple. Meaning "courtyard in gold' in native Quechua, it once had a dazzling sun disc, its walls covered in panels, statues and alters-all in gold. Today ofcourse none of it is there, but one can imagine it all as one walks into the halls that house the remains- the walls, doorways and niches, mortarless and symmetrical, remnants of the Inca 's brilliant masonry. Plundered, its stones were used to build the Santo Domingo church which stand at the same site.
steep climb. mild but steep climb then awesome view of other sites and the city
nice ruins in the city. nice site to visit within the city. definitely get a guide to take you around, otherwise it will seem pointless.

Disappointed. From the name and descriptions in books i was really looking forward to seeing this. Unfortunately i was probably my biggest disappointment of the trip. There was nothing really spectacular and the Temple has been renovated (by the Spanish i think, not new renovation) so very little of the original structure is still there. i was thinking this was going to be magestic and it was basically an indoor museum.
Well explained bit of history. Spanish church on old Inka site. Good explanation of Inka constructions in museum. Gardens on terraces a nice touch.
Beautiful! A must see!. A little expensive for a tour of a church... but the woodwork and artistry are must sees in Cusco. Look for the painting of the Last Supper that features a roast guinea pig!
The Inca were master builders. This place is a prime example of an earthquake resistant building with magnificant craftmanship. A must visit.
Don'y miss it. More beautiful construction. Interesting museum of paintings from the Cusco school.
Great place. This place is well worth a visit, the structure itself is amazing.

Coricancha...A Must See. Few places in Cusco illustrate the cultural clash/exchange between the Incas and the Spanish better than Coricancha. You'll be impressed by the amazing stonework of the Incan architects and will be left wondering how grandiose it must have been before the Spanish arrived and plundered it. Likewise, the church and convent of Santo Domingo is impressive in its own right, complete with beautiful paintings all along the interior courtyard. While Cusco offers hundreds of amazing historical sights, I think Coricancha is the perfect example of both Incan history and colonial history as well. Well worth at least 2 hours for a visit.

Nice archeological site close in the city center!. Coricancha is a nice site worth the visit! You can go there individually (not having to buy the whole acheological site ticket). It's nice to wonder around and see the building but not much of expeditions to see.. The garden of the site is really fantastic to have a break!

Qorikancha, Temple within a church. Set up on a hill in downtown Cusco is the site of the Temple of the Sun or Golden Temple, now the Church of Santo Domingo. The church is built upon the old Inca foundations with sections of original wall remaining visible.Previously a walled Inca temple complex, several buidlings with impecable stone work remain inside the courtyard of the church. Once filled with gold life size statues, the Spanish spoke of the fabulous wealth found here. Interesting site to see clash of two cultures.
Beautiful and historic. Only viewed it from the outside- but spectacular at night!
Worth the visit. The natural beauty of this place is heart-warming. Please include in your itinerary

Qorikancha- Templ del Sol. Fanscinating clash of cultures to be witnessed here- Qorikancha (ancient Inka) and Santo Domingo (Spanish Catholicism) come together to form the perfect illustration of the clash of Andean culture with the Western Europe.
Incrediable history and artifacts. Beautiful! Learning how the incas built their temples to withstand earthquakes, capture the sun movements to calendarize the year. Wealth of knowledge and history.

Awesome Inca masonry. The Spanish conquistadores typically built a monastery over the most important Inca temple in Cusco, but much of the original masonry has survived in excellent condition, showing just how skilled the indigenous builders were -it looks as if it were built last week. There´s also the monastery with lots of big religious oil paintings in ostentatious gold frames, as if to try and offset the Incan remains, which in my opinion they fail to do miserably. Well worth a visit.
Solo Traveler. As a solo traveler, the Temple of the Sun was an ok place to visit. I suggest bringing a travel book and reading the history of the temple prior to going there.
Spectacular. A beautiful place to visit on a tour of colonial Cusco
Bad Guide. Bad tour guide, he was bored, boring and uniformed

Interesting combination of Inca & Church. It was very interesting to see how the church had used the Inca construction as a foundation for their building. In this way the ruins were at least partial preserved within the confines of the church. It showed the impressive building ability of the Incas.

Interesting to see the church built upon former Inca temple.. Spanish often built their church's on former Inca temple sites as a way of destroying the former empires greatest works as well as using the abundant building materials now available to use for their own needs. You can see many parts of the former temple incorporated in the newer church.
Beautiful combination of old and older!. The history of the Church is a fascinating as the place itself. Very beautiful.

The church to see. Built on Incan ruins, this is a fabulous combination of Incan and Spanish, with a beautiful courtyard and lovely garden. Visit during the day and then come back at night to take pictures of the outside, when it's lit up with golden light.

Too bad the Spanish destroyed it! Still impressing!. Beautiful place in the centre of Cusco, the heart of the Inka empire. It would have been great to see it in the Inka time before the Spanish came and destroyed it, took away all the gold and started building on top of the Inka constructions.
Fascinating!. I really enjoyed learning about this site. Our guide, Patty provided the modern Quechuan perspective, while objectively sharing what occurred among the Incas and Spaniards.
interesting. It`s a very small ruins and very interesting... it`s on the way to Sacred Valley

A Must-see in Cusco. As is was once the literal center of the Incan Empire, it really should be a must-see. If you don't have a detailed guide book I'd spring for one of the guides waiting outside, the temple means so much more with their explanations.
Visit to Koricancha. A good place to appreciate colonial architecture juxtaposed with Inca ruins.

Can see it from the road. This is basically a big plaza with inca ruins and a church built on top of them. It's a popular hang out spot and lots of people take pics. It's an easy walk from the plaza. Don't waste time or money on the museum unless you have the tourist ticket in which case you get in free. They just have some pottery and tools you can see elsewhere.
Best formed Inca Walls in Cuzco. Worth the entry fee. Best preserved Inca stonework around.
One of the coolest sites in Cusco!. We hired a guide and it helped a lot. Some great background info provided. You are able to wonder the site w/out a guide after the tour.

I peaceful destination in the middle of the city.. Be sure to go early - when we left, it was getting very crowded!If I had limited time in Cusco, I would not make this a priority - it has an interesting history, and was a quiet place to be, but I would see some of the other sites first.

In the heart of Cuzco. Well worth the visit, but hire one of the local guides standing outside the front door, so you know what you are looking at. Good historical opportunity; also houses a "convent" for monks.
Inca ruin with church inside. Nicely maintained large ruin jumbled in with Colonial building. Well displayed and full of history.
Sol. Holy place of Inca People.. Love it!! very close to cusco center..

don't judge a book by its cover. The outside does not look like much but you need to go inside the temple/cathedral to explore the ruins. It is quite fascinating. The courtyard and the mosaics are very beautiful. if you have a tour guide, get them to show you the twentieth century re-creation of the Incan wall. All the modern day engineering that we have could not build a perfect wall like the ancient Incas could...quite fascinating.

Incredible Inca quality construction. Well worth a visit and practically right across the street from the Libertador Hotel. We did not have enough time to visit the whole facility, so allow some time if you are on your own.
Impressive Spanish construction. As impressive on the outside as on the inside. My friend got to attend Mass there.
Inca Stonework exquisite.. Loved the Inca rock work. It was nice to know that their work was so skillfully done that it withstood the earthquake while the Spanish rock and mortar work crumbled.

Fascinating cultural site & beautiful church. Probably the most fascinating buidling in entire Cusco is the Iglesia de Santo Domingo. It's diverse history and the blend of inca and spanish architecture along with beautiful artwork of the two cultures make it to be a "must have seen" on a Cusco trip. You should consider taking a tour through the complex if your travellers guide doesnt provide enough information, in order to get the best and most informative experience.
Take the time. Get a guide, available at the entrance. For 20 soles, you will get the information & history & learn the pride of the locals. It is so worth it!
Nice Church. Nice church but not too much to see inside. Was nice because it was a very short tour and not a lot of crowds

Nice example of the Spanish attitude toward the Inca. It was really interesting to see how the Spanish had destroyed most of the Inca works and then built on top of them. Hard to believe how the Spanish behaved in Peru. Interesting to see that when a major earthquake hit the area, the Spanish buildings toppled while the Inca construction was mostly undisturbed. Well worth a visit.
Great view at night. The temple honestly does not say much, just some stones from the Inca era. The view during a full moon night with dim lighting was absolutely stunning.
The best Inca Imperial architecture on earth. Amazing & perfect square shape architecture. This is because the Inca Pachacutec -the most perfeccionist incan emperor- was his mentor.

Intriquing to see the original temples. The Inca holy ground is partially restored by the Dominicans, who centuries earlier, had mostly demolished it. They've done a great job. The original buildings were kept in many instances so the stonework and the characteristic Inca five-niche arrangement are there. There is solid information available on the displays and we felt we got the gist with our own guidebooks and, especially, the model of the original site. Don't miss (1) an especially beautiful collection of religious art on the east side of the site, (2) an introduction to Inca astrology on the south side and, further south, the vestments room (sacristy) for the church itself, which is not open to the public.

Truly a Must See!. This is the heart and hub of the Incan culture. Beautiful interior plaza and views of Cusco. Great place to learn about the culture and the temples and basic information about how they constructed such places.

Best 20 soles spent in Cusco. We paid 10 soles pp to get in and 10 soles pp to an english speaking guide ((Alfredo) that offered his services at the door. He provided so much more information than you read on the boards and the hour spent was terriic. We were amused by all th bemused bus groups that were rushed through with very little information being provided by their guides.
A Must See. Very interesting and spiritual. You can go several times and still see something special.
Good visit. Beautiful view of the place both from the outside as well the inside. It's a very big place to explore and take picture of.
easy to miss!!. located in cusco central. a must see. take a walk through after lunch some time.
Inka heritage in the middle of the city. Beautiful site right in the middle of the city, it is possible to have a nice side view from the Santo Domingo Church.

Unique, wonderful site. Qoricancha and the Convento de Santo Domingo is a must see. The combination of the Inca buildings and the convent is breathtaking. The Conquistadors did not totally destroy the previous temple, but incorporated it into the church. You will not see anything like this anywhere else. It is NOT included in the boleto touristico, but it is worth the 10 soles.
Nice temple with excellent views from outside. Nice temple with excellent views from outside. It is a shame that ruins indoors had beed destroyed by conquerors.
Beautifully carved stones. This is a nice preview to all the many Inka ruins in the sacred valley. Interesting to see how the Spanish just built right on top of it.

Great Place to visit!. It is a pity that this Temple was almost destroyed. but luckily you can still see and feel and interior of an Incan Temple.This is one of the most interesting places to visit in Cusco.Would recommend visiting it. It is kind of close to the Plaza de Armas, walkiing distance thru very nice streets.If you wish you do not need to go into the Church to visit the Temple.

Beautiful temple. It's a really beautiful temple! We didn't get a tour guide but still very impressed by it's architecture. The temple itself was gorgeous both inside and outside. I would say this is definitely a must visit if you are in Cusco. We walked to the temple from Plaza de armas and it was about 15 to 20 minutes walk in a lovely weather. We found some local souvenir shops on the way and if you walk a bit further you will see a Post Office (in case you want to send a postcard like we did)
nice. what a beautiful place, it hurts so it was before because of insurance was phenomenal, even so this exellent very harmonic,
fascinating. Excellent half day trip to learn more about incan history!!

Should be included in the boleto touristico. A fascinating place to see Cusco's layers, but this should really be included in the boleto turistico. Another 20 soles almost pushed me over the limit....

Good way to spend a couple of hours while in Cusco. This is a good museum that covers many different eras and topics. It also has beautiful gardens and landscaping that accentuate the artistry of the setting. Walk through the museum and spend a couple of minutes on the back balcony enjoying the sunshine.There are good restaurants and shops near the museum, so don't rush to the next tourist sight. Spend some time in the neighborhood.
Inca engineering. The fastidiousness with which the incas built their temples is a true testament to the ingenuity. The site is inspiring in many ways.

Fusion between worlds.... The thing that I found really interesting of this place is the fact that you can see the perfection of the Incas and compare with the techniques of the Spanish...at the end, you will learn many things about architecture of the Incas that nowadays have application. TIP: do not hirea guide outside, they have guides inside included in the tour

Beautiful Place. This "Temple" is placed high on a hill in the middle of Cusco, it has impressive artifacts as well as paintings that you are not allowed to take photos of. The view from the patios of the temple are a beautiful view of the city. It is worth seeing while in Cusco. There is also a nice courtyard in the center with a traditional "clown" as I called them. It is a statue about 9 ft tall and has one of those long nosed crazy masks on.
Temple of the Sun. Interesting stop during visit to Cusco. Worth the time and convenient to city center. Hard to visualize what it looked like.
Its an okay place. This pace was okay nothing compared to all the great cathedrals we have visited in Europe. Visit if you have the time.

Stunning :D. Visited this site on a guided tour who gave us an informative history of the church which was built on Inca foundations. I simply loved the courtyard and the gorgeous views of the town. Worth seeing and not to be missed.
Not to be missed!. A site totally worth seeing, preferably with a guide.

Impressive site, need a tour guide. Generally, many sites provide the ability to self-tour but not htis one. While we were certainly able to admire this impressive Temple, we would have learned more with some form of guide.

Don't skip this while in Cuzco!. We had some hours to kill and decided to go and visit the Coricancha on our last day there. This site is the Santo Domingo Church as well - because it is built on the foundation from the Sun Temple. It is a great way to see some Inca structures up close - and it's covered in case it's raining. There are many paintings in the Santo Domingo as well - and some great flower gardens and views.
Centrally located Spanish church. Classic church with Inca and Spanish components on the Plaza de Armas in Cusco. Worth a visit!

Where it all began for the Incas. The most important location for the Incas was largely destroyed by the Spanish, although important sections remain. Fascinating mix of architecture, design and history.

Interesting blend of inca and Spanish design. Really worth seeing. You will find that, even if they are practically in the same building, you can't see Coricancha with the ticket to enter the church. And, more irritating even, if you want to see Coricancha, you need to buy the 70 soles ticket to see all the inca sites in the Sacred Valley. You can't buy an individual ticket for each site. The place is really nice (particularly like the art from the Escuela Cuzqueña, how they used the influence from the European artists and added their indigenous touch. Impressive also how they built on top of the inca constructions, using them as foundations for their religious buildings.
Temple of the sun. This temple was worth seeing and with a paid guide obtained upon entrance, more then a gave an appreciation for Inca capabilities

Fascinating. We had a guide who gave a very good explanation of the history of the site. from The Temple of the Sun (Koricancha) to a Catholic church which was built on the ancient walls and now a museum.

Heartbreaking. I wish we had been able to spend longer here and that our guide had spoken better English. Most of what I know about this I have found out from my own research and it is heartbreaking to think of what the Spanish destroyed. It must have been unbelievable magnificent in its heyday.

Interesting place. Visited it as the last stop on a day-long Sacred Valley tour. Guide told an interesting story about how the natives use the cathedral but hang onto their own religion. Wasn't aware that this place was once a Shining Path stronghold.
Another Must See. This is a site with a lot of Inca history and some of the best quality Inca walls in Cusco. Well worth the time.
church and Incan site. one of the central attractions of Cuzco; should not be missed.

Don't miss this chance. The main thrill about visiting Santo Domingo is the chance to examine the interior ruins of the Inca palace -Coricancha.The stone work is amazing.Don't miss the 14 angle stone.
Impressive!. How could Kechuas built those places at that age!!! Very impressive!
Grab a Guide. Need a tour guide to know the history and details of this place. Recomended!
Temple Of The Sun. Worth taking the time to see. The huge blocks of granite and how they built this place is hard to believe.

A Well Done Museum, Worth a Visit. Built on top of the Koricancha, the largest Incan temple of the sun, in 1532, Iglesia de Santo Domingo was a monastery, a convent, and a university where Spanish priests could learn the local Quechua language, required before they could do missionary work.It was badly damaged in the earthquake of 1650, but was restored about 30 years later. Today, it is a museum, and quite a good one at that. This is one of those places that is best to visit without a guide so you can take your time. There is adequate signage, and the place is quite beautiful. It's amazing how it fits so perfectly into the ancient Inca temple. This will take you an hour or two to visit, quite worthwhile.

Avoid the late afternoon in high season -- too many people!. The stonework of the Korichancha is quite impressive. But if you go in the late afternoon during the high season, you barely get a chance to look at it! We went with a guided group tour, as did apparently the rest of the city of Cusco. The was barely room to move around, and it was too loud to hear anything. We had to push people to get a look at the stones. So, while this site is almost certainly worth seeing, try to see it when the crowds are lower, or you may wish you hadn't gone at all.

Beautifull and really interesting for understanding the history of Cusco. The church and the Inca ruin are beautifull. The history of this site is really interesting. Good to start with that in order to understand to construction and history of Cusco.

A Must See in Cuzco. I completely agree with the other reviewers - one of the best sites in the city of Cuzco. I visited several museums on my last day in Cuzco, Qorikancha was the last and certainly did not disappoint. This museum was very modern, cool and informative. The main part of the museum explained the importance of the site as the Capitol building of the Inka Empire with explanations of the Inca Walls that make up much of the convents foundations. They had additional exhibits displaying Christian art from the 14-18 centuries, much of which produced over the years at their on-campus art school. Not to lose the kiddos, there was also an exhibit of contemporary Peruvian art - it was a small section but very hip and completely unexpected.
Amazing!. It's absolutely incredible to walk past the Inca stone walls into the Coricancha. this building houses an art collection, great gardens, and changing exhibitions. It's a must-see.

My favorite place in Cusco. The church was indeed lovely. But the rest of the site is even more spectacular. The remains of the Incan temple, the garden outside and the modern art gallery upstairs were all fascinating. A must-see for anyone visiting Cusco.

My favorite place in Cusco. This was the most intersting place to tour in Cusco. There are Incan ruins, a Spanish church, beautiful gardens, and a modern art gallery. One of our favorite parts was the large mural that depicted the various constellations as the Incans saw and named them. Altogether a must-see.

Reverence. On our arrival to Cusco, our "angel" guide took us on a walking tour of Cusco. We spent most of our afternoon in Santo Domingo Church. It was beautiful. From the Inca/Spanish mixture to paintings that hung on the walls, to the courtyard in the middle of it, to the beautiful gardens and blue skies.What a beautiful country! They are trying to preserve it, and with more education and knowledge I know they will succeed.If you get a chance, read "Last of the Inca Kings", it brought home to me, the rich history of this church, and all the surroundings!
The best of inca ruins. While the church is interesting to see, the most impressive part is the inca ruin within the church. You will see stone work that is just amazing.
